description: The Information Technology Infrastructure Library (ITIL) was created to help businesses manage their IT operations more efficiently and reliably. The ITIL framework provides a collection of practices that businesses can choose to adopt that focus on aligning IT operations with the goals of the business. These practices range from creating new service offerings to day-to-day operations and managing incidents. Many organizations choose to follow ITIL because it prevents them from having to "reinvent the wheel" when it comes to IT processes and operations. The ITIL Foundations certification is designed to introduce the candidate to the general processes in ITIL and how they can be used to benefit an organization.

This one.

453
00:22:50,230 --> 00:22:54,350
Here's my quick outline that we'll be
using during the show as we go through.

454
00:22:54,350 --> 00:22:56,890
And you'll see I've divided them
up into these big sections.

455
00:22:56,890 --> 00:23:01,180
Service Strategy, Service Design,
Service Transition, Service Operation, and

456
00:23:01,180 --> 00:23:02,770
Continual Service Improvement.

457
00:23:02,770 --> 00:23:04,120
Those are not names that I made up.

458
00:23:04,120 --> 00:23:04,990
Those are books.

459
00:23:04,990 --> 00:23:09,380
So with ITO they have a physical book
called Continual Service Improvement.

460
00:23:09,380 --> 00:23:11,530
And in it is the entire framework for

461
00:23:11,530 --> 00:23:14,080
how to properly implement
continual service improvement.

462
00:23:14,080 --> 00:23:16,470
Now the books are huge.

463
00:23:16,470 --> 00:23:18,070
They are 300-400 pages each.

464
00:23:18,070 --> 00:23:19,460
Some of them are a little bit longer.

465
00:23:19,460 --> 00:23:20,980
They're pretty expensive too.

466
00:23:20,980 --> 00:23:24,940
The whole set of five books will run
you a little over 500 US dollars.

467
00:23:24,940 --> 00:23:27,850
So they're not inexpensive books.

468
00:23:27,850 --> 00:23:31,070
We don't need to know the whole book for
ITIL foundation.

469
00:23:31,070 --> 00:23:32,990
We just need to know
what's in those books.

470
00:23:32,990 --> 00:23:35,020
Right.
The general concepts around them.

471
00:23:35,020 --> 00:23:37,590
So we'll break it down this way,
all right?

472
00:23:37,590 --> 00:23:40,310
So each of these are the different
components that we're going to go through

473
00:23:40,310 --> 00:23:42,170
as we're learning what ITIL is and

474
00:23:42,170 --> 00:23:46,220
what areas contain what functionality,
all right.

475
00:23:46,220 --> 00:23:49,190
So that's important to keep in
mind as we get ready to study and

476
00:23:49,190 --> 00:23:50,520
we get ready to move into that.

477
00:23:50,520 --> 00:23:53,880
And then when we take the certification
it will be pulling from all these areas.

478
00:23:55,500 --> 00:23:57,050
You know, I feel like I'm
leaving something out, Ronnie,

479
00:23:57,050 --> 00:23:59,830
there was something else I wanted
to mention here at the end.

480
00:23:59,830 --> 00:24:00,920
>> I don't know of any.

481
00:24:00,920 --> 00:24:02,040
>> You can't read my mind?

482
00:24:02,040 --> 00:24:02,770
Shoot.

483
00:24:02,770 --> 00:24:04,435
Well, I can't read my own mind either.

484
00:24:04,435 --> 00:24:07,970
[LAUGH] Seems like there was one
more thing I wanted to mention,

485
00:24:07,970 --> 00:24:10,990
but I guess we'll see that later.

486
00:24:10,990 --> 00:24:12,620
So, yes that's basically it.

487
00:24:12,620 --> 00:24:15,400
Our show will cover all that you
need to know to pass the exam.

488
00:24:15,400 --> 00:24:16,930
Which is always important.

489
00:24:16,930 --> 00:24:18,750
You'll be able to jump in and
take that and

490
00:24:18,750 --> 00:24:20,770
hopefully pass on
the first try if you study.

491
00:24:20,770 --> 00:24:23,460
It's not the most challenging
exam that you'll encounter.

492
00:24:23,460 --> 00:24:27,900
So, which is kind of a pleasant
surprise compared to some of the ones

493
00:24:27,900 --> 00:24:28,410
we go through.

494
00:24:29,530 --> 00:24:33,200
All right, well, ladies and gentlemen
that's probably enough about ITIL.

495
00:24:33,200 --> 00:24:35,490
If that sounds like something
that you are interested in,

496
00:24:35,490 --> 00:24:38,130
maybe if you think that this is something
that you want to learn more about,

497
00:24:38,130 --> 00:24:39,896
then you're in the right place.

498
00:24:39,896 --> 00:24:44,270
And you'll want to jump into our episodes,
which, well by the time you see this,

499
00:24:44,270 --> 00:24:45,000
might be completed.

500
00:24:45,000 --> 00:24:47,100
But we're actually about to start
here in just a few minutes,

501
00:24:47,100 --> 00:24:50,132
so I hope to see you there.

502
00:24:50,132 --> 00:24:53,166
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Introduction to ITIL
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,578 --> 00:00:34,130
All right.

3
00:00:34,130 --> 00:00:35,756
Good morning, good afternoon and

4
00:00:35,756 --> 00:00:38,684
good evening and welcome back
to another episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:38,684 --> 00:00:41,296
I'm your host Don Pezet.

6
00:00:41,296 --> 00:00:42,190
Mr. Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:42,190 --> 00:00:42,920
How's it going Ronnie.

8
00:00:42,920 --> 00:00:44,310
>> It is going swell today.

9
00:00:44,310 --> 00:00:47,640
I finished watching the entire
collection of Glee.

10
00:00:47,640 --> 00:00:49,750
And so I'm ready for today's show.

11
00:00:49,750 --> 00:00:52,790
>> That's normally the type of thing
we don't want people to find out about.

12
00:00:52,790 --> 00:00:53,475
>> That's true.

13
00:00:53,475 --> 00:00:55,910
>> [LAUGH] Let's get that recorded.

14
00:00:55,910 --> 00:00:59,650
I'm totally clipping out that and
posting it on the web.

15
00:00:59,650 --> 00:01:00,150
>> Yes.

16
00:01:01,210 --> 00:01:01,750
>> All right.

17
00:01:01,750 --> 00:01:05,320
Ladies and gentlemen, we are kicking
off our ITIL foundation today.

18
00:01:05,320 --> 00:01:08,120
So always fun to start a new
certification on the show.

19
00:01:08,120 --> 00:01:09,890
We always get excited about it.

20
00:01:09,890 --> 00:01:10,720
We're gonna be diving in.

21
00:01:10,720 --> 00:01:12,830
This is our introduction episode.

22
00:01:12,830 --> 00:01:16,880
We're gonna take a look at what
the ITIL foundation certification is.

23
00:01:16,880 --> 00:01:20,110
And what we need to know to
be successful on the exam.

24
00:01:20,110 --> 00:01:24,600
For a lot of you viewers this will
be your first exposure to ITIL.

25
00:01:24,600 --> 00:01:27,980
Many of you may have heard the term thrown
around or seen it as a requirement on

26
00:01:27,980 --> 00:01:32,420
a job posting but
not had actual exposure to the process.

27
00:01:32,420 --> 00:01:34,270
And so this is the starting point.

28
00:01:34,270 --> 00:01:37,160
This is the very beginning for
someone learning and

29
00:01:37,160 --> 00:01:40,620
taking that first step on a career
that involves the ITIL frame.

30
00:01:41,760 --> 00:01:43,160
Let's start.

31
00:01:43,160 --> 00:01:44,470
At the very beginning.

32
00:01:44,470 --> 00:01:47,040
What the heck is ITIL?

33
00:01:47,040 --> 00:01:50,780
It stands for the Information
Technology Industry Library.

34
00:01:50,780 --> 00:01:52,670
Although you'll never
hear anybody say that.

35
00:01:52,670 --> 00:01:53,720
They just call it ITIL.

36
00:01:53,720 --> 00:01:58,060
And what it is a collection of

37
00:01:58,060 --> 00:02:03,530
advice that helps you to build up
the IT department for a company.

38
00:02:03,530 --> 00:02:04,160
All right?

39
00:02:04,160 --> 00:02:06,830
And it really stems from things
that happened earlier on.

40
00:02:06,830 --> 00:02:11,600
Back in the 1980s, it was really uncommon
for companies to have an IT department.

41
00:02:11,600 --> 00:02:14,580
If you had computers at all,
it was usually mainframe based, and

42
00:02:14,580 --> 00:02:17,480
you relied on the vendors
like IBM to support it.

43
00:02:17,480 --> 00:02:20,220
And so
you didn't normally have an IT department.

44
00:02:20,220 --> 00:02:24,360
If you did, it was a copy repair man,
it wasn't computers.

45
00:02:24,360 --> 00:02:28,150
Well, in the 90s, having an IT
department became pretty common.

46
00:02:28,150 --> 00:02:31,200
And a lot of organizations were
having to figure out how to run that.

47
00:02:31,200 --> 00:02:32,880
How do you run an IT department?

48
00:02:32,880 --> 00:02:37,620
How do you properly deal with the finances
and the expenses, the operations,

49
00:02:37,620 --> 00:02:40,400
picking what services people want and
which ones not to, and

50
00:02:40,400 --> 00:02:44,752
so the IT framework was
created to help with that.

51
00:02:44,752 --> 00:02:47,235
To say you're going to
have an IT department?

52
00:02:47,235 --> 00:02:49,945
Here's some of the things
you should consider doing.

53
00:02:49,945 --> 00:02:53,085
And it is a collection
of a ton of information.

54
00:02:53,085 --> 00:02:56,615
And it saves you from having
to reinvent the wheel.

55
00:02:56,615 --> 00:03:00,305
Why go through that process of creating
an all new IT management structure,

56
00:03:00,305 --> 00:03:03,730
when other people have done it,
and been very successful with it.

57
00:03:03,730 --> 00:03:04,300
>> Yeah.

58
00:03:04,300 --> 00:03:08,690
The British government is the one that
really started off the idea of coming up

59
00:03:08,690 --> 00:03:13,250
with ITIL, because of all of the different
ways that their departments within

60
00:03:13,250 --> 00:03:16,430
the British government were starting
to say that they needed IT departments.

61
00:03:16,430 --> 00:03:17,790
But they didn't know exactly what to do.

62
00:03:17,790 --> 00:03:20,240
So everybody started coming
out with their own model.

63
00:03:20,240 --> 00:03:21,870
And what ended up happening
they said wait a minute.

64
00:03:21,870 --> 00:03:25,810
We've got to actually do what
we call best practices on this.

65
00:03:25,810 --> 00:03:27,430
Because if we don't,
we're gonna end up with so

66
00:03:27,430 --> 00:03:30,360
many little departments,
they're not gonna be able to integrate.

67
00:03:30,360 --> 00:03:34,020
They're not gonna be able to communicate
with each other what the actual

68
00:03:34,020 --> 00:03:35,110
problem is.

69
00:03:35,110 --> 00:03:36,890
So when they came up with ITIL.

70
00:03:36,890 --> 00:03:38,840
It really did start out
as a foundation model.

71
00:03:38,840 --> 00:03:42,270
It was a huge body of knowledge so big and

72
00:03:42,270 --> 00:03:46,690
they created so many different little
tiny divisions of everything they needed.

73
00:03:46,690 --> 00:03:49,400
And then they started kinda
narrowing it down and

74
00:03:49,400 --> 00:03:54,320
refocusing saying what's really important
is what the end user really needs.

75
00:03:54,320 --> 00:03:58,070
What the end user really wants or
the customer really ends up doing.

76
00:03:58,070 --> 00:04:02,550
So this is really a customer oriented type
of framework that we're talking about.

77
00:04:02,550 --> 00:04:05,870
>> And the nice thing about it being
a frame work is that means you get to pick

78
00:04:05,870 --> 00:04:07,950
and choose the components that you want.

79
00:04:07,950 --> 00:04:10,200
When you read through
one of the ITIL manuals,

80
00:04:10,200 --> 00:04:12,450
you'll see there is a ton of stuff.

81
00:04:12,450 --> 00:04:16,570
And some of it does not apply
to your company and that's okay.

82
00:04:16,570 --> 00:04:18,150
You leave those parts out.

83
00:04:18,150 --> 00:04:19,530
You take the parts you need,

84
00:04:19,530 --> 00:04:23,630
the parts that apply to your company and
you use those and you use them to help

85
00:04:23,630 --> 00:04:27,240
guarantee that you're doing things at
least within the best practices model.

86
00:04:27,240 --> 00:04:29,460
And then the parts that don't apply to
your company you just leave out and

87
00:04:29,460 --> 00:04:30,270
you don't worry about them.

88
00:04:30,270 --> 00:04:34,300
So while it can look very daunting in
the beginning, it's a lot of information,

89
00:04:34,300 --> 00:04:39,600
you'll usually only apply a subset of
it and it typically goes really well.

90
00:04:39,600 --> 00:04:41,670
Now Ronnie,
you mentioned the United Kingdom and

91
00:04:41,670 --> 00:04:43,030
this is where this all came out of.

92
00:04:44,040 --> 00:04:46,710
So it is a product of Great Britain.

93
00:04:48,020 --> 00:04:50,290
I always mix up the terms for the country.

94
00:04:50,290 --> 00:04:54,290
We're here in the United States and
our understanding of British government is

95
00:04:54,290 --> 00:04:57,322
poor at best if you've read
any of our history books.

96
00:04:57,322 --> 00:05:00,860
[LAUGH] It is a product
of the UK government.

97
00:05:00,860 --> 00:05:03,980
But it is something that's
available to the entire world.

98
00:05:03,980 --> 00:05:06,920
And we've seen a lot of acceptance
in other places, like right here in

99
00:05:06,920 --> 00:05:10,410
the United States, where on
the West Coast it is really common for

100
00:05:10,410 --> 00:05:14,880
companies to use the ITIL framework to
dictate how their IT departments operate,

101
00:05:14,880 --> 00:05:16,690
and integrate inside of a company.

102
00:05:16,690 --> 00:05:20,070
So even if you're in Asia,
Africa, Australia,

103
00:05:20,070 --> 00:05:23,250
wherever just because this is
a product of the UK doesn't mean

104
00:05:23,250 --> 00:05:26,680
it's not gonna be something used in
your country, so keep that in mind.

105
00:05:26,680 --> 00:05:30,220
But it also means that it gets
really confusing to figure out

106
00:05:30,220 --> 00:05:32,550
who's making this stuff available.

107
00:05:32,550 --> 00:05:35,890
Because it was developed by the government
it was originally controlled by what was

108
00:05:35,890 --> 00:05:40,320
called the Office of
Government Commerce or the OGC.

109
00:05:40,320 --> 00:05:44,100
And that's a element of the UK government.

110
00:05:44,100 --> 00:05:47,990
And they're the ones who basically
bound all this information together and

111
00:05:47,990 --> 00:05:51,560
starting dealing with the various
parties that handle ITIL.

112
00:05:51,560 --> 00:05:54,540
Now England, or the United Kingdom,

113
00:05:54,540 --> 00:06:00,090
is not a communist government, so it's
not like they run businesses themselves.

114
00:06:00,090 --> 00:06:03,550
A lot of this gets contracted
out to other entities, so

115
00:06:03,550 --> 00:06:08,020
you'll see more company names mentioned
in there other than the UK government and

116
00:06:08,020 --> 00:06:11,080
that's where the line starts to get
a little blurred and it gets confusing.

117
00:06:11,080 --> 00:06:14,290
I know when I first started with ITIL I
had a really challenging time when I'd

118
00:06:14,290 --> 00:06:16,300
go out on the internet and do searches for

119
00:06:16,300 --> 00:06:20,270
information and I would see websites and
not know if they were real.

120
00:06:20,270 --> 00:06:23,240
Is this really the actual ITIL site or

121
00:06:23,240 --> 00:06:25,620
is this some other person that just
bought up their own ITIL site.

122
00:06:25,620 --> 00:06:26,590
I don't know.

123
00:06:26,590 --> 00:06:30,390
And so they've really had to make a big
push to tighten up on that, to make

124
00:06:30,390 --> 00:06:34,640
sure that all the information was really
restricted down to a handful of vendors.

125
00:06:35,920 --> 00:06:37,650
What the UK government did,

126
00:06:37,650 --> 00:06:41,750
is they created a partnership
with a private entity.

127
00:06:41,750 --> 00:06:46,390
So you kind of spun off a separate
company that is not the government.

128
00:06:46,390 --> 00:06:47,470
It's not a private company.

129
00:06:47,470 --> 00:06:51,660
But it's a partnership or
a cooperation between two.

130
00:06:51,660 --> 00:06:56,480
And so the new company that runs
this is a company called Axelos.

131
00:06:56,480 --> 00:06:58,810
And when you go out on the Internet and
you start searching for

132
00:06:58,810 --> 00:07:04,460
information on ITIL, anytime you see
Axelos, A-X-E-L-O-S, when you see

133
00:07:04,460 --> 00:07:09,590
that name right there you know that
you're on the official ITIL information.

134
00:07:10,670 --> 00:07:14,290
In fact, for
years the actual web address for

135
00:07:14,290 --> 00:07:19,080
the ITIL site was this,
www.itil-officialsite.com.

136
00:07:19,080 --> 00:07:21,770
And I know, it sounds kind of funny.

137
00:07:21,770 --> 00:07:24,170
But it says it's official right there,
so it's got to be official.

138
00:07:25,200 --> 00:07:27,720
When you go to that,
it really just redirects now.

139
00:07:27,720 --> 00:07:33,660
If I type in that URL and hit Enter, see
how it just changed to axelos.com/itil.

140
00:07:33,660 --> 00:07:37,440
Axelos is the organization
that is in complete and

141
00:07:37,440 --> 00:07:39,410
total control of the ITIL framework today.

142
00:07:40,950 --> 00:07:45,002
Now it's a partnership between, actually
two different companies that you usually

143
00:07:45,002 --> 00:07:47,880
won't see their name mentioned
anywhere on the site.

144
00:07:47,880 --> 00:07:50,337
Axelos does a great job
with their branding and

145
00:07:50,337 --> 00:07:52,671
making sure they don't create confusion.

146
00:07:52,671 --> 00:07:57,117
But it's a partnership between
they call it the HM government,

147
00:07:57,117 --> 00:08:02,304
her majesty's government, so
the government arm of the United Kingdom,

148
00:08:02,304 --> 00:08:04,963
and another company called Taffeta.

149
00:08:04,963 --> 00:08:07,296
And you'll see Taffeta PLC which is.

150
00:08:07,296 --> 00:08:11,453
A public limited company, so
Capita is more of a private type

151
00:08:11,453 --> 00:08:15,867
organization that is working in
tandem with the UK government.

152
00:08:15,867 --> 00:08:18,801
And that way they can do sales, and
revenue, and all that stuff that

153
00:08:18,801 --> 00:08:22,190
the government does not normally do,
because there's not a communist.

154
00:08:22,190 --> 00:08:25,740
So [LAUGH] I'm sure that there's other
political models that do that too, but

155
00:08:25,740 --> 00:08:27,760
basically that's what theses entities are.

156
00:08:27,760 --> 00:08:29,880
Most of us won't ever have
to deal with that though.

157
00:08:29,880 --> 00:08:34,090
AXELOS should be your primary source
of information, regarding ITIL.

158
00:08:35,520 --> 00:08:39,980
When you sit down, and take that ITIL
exam, the questions, the data that's being

159
00:08:39,980 --> 00:08:44,860
covered on that exam, has all been
designed and set forth by AXELOS.

160
00:08:44,860 --> 00:08:49,970
But then, they in turn partner with other
companies to handle things like training,

161
00:08:49,970 --> 00:08:53,740
course development,
exam proctoring, and so on.

162
00:08:53,740 --> 00:08:58,910
So, you might be where you find yourself
dealing with information from AXELOS, but

163
00:08:58,910 --> 00:09:01,360
you never actually pay them a single dime.

164
00:09:01,360 --> 00:09:03,960
And instead you deal
with other organizations.

165
00:09:03,960 --> 00:09:08,395
And I'm a great example of that, where all
the various books that I've purchased over

166
00:09:08,395 --> 00:09:11,330
the years for ITIL,
I bought them all from Amazon.com.

167
00:09:11,330 --> 00:09:12,500
That's where I bought them.

168
00:09:12,500 --> 00:09:17,810
And the exams I usually take through
a testing vendor named EXIN.

169
00:09:17,810 --> 00:09:21,730
And EXIN is not AXELOS, but

170
00:09:21,730 --> 00:09:25,850
AXELOS has authorized EXIN to
proctor exams on their behalf.

171
00:09:25,850 --> 00:09:28,400
So you may develop a very
close relationship with

172
00:09:28,400 --> 00:09:32,350
one of these directly approved
partners as you go and get certified.

173
00:09:32,350 --> 00:09:36,700
In fact, here we're covering
the ITIL Foundation certification.

174
00:09:36,700 --> 00:09:37,960
It's your starting point.

175
00:09:37,960 --> 00:09:40,530
And you can do your
ITIL Foundation training anywhere.

176
00:09:40,530 --> 00:09:43,220
So we're doing it right here on ITProTV.

177
00:09:43,220 --> 00:09:49,100
But, ITProTV is not one of the officially
accredited vendors that AXELOS deals with,

178
00:09:49,100 --> 00:09:50,550
they don't even know who we are.

179
00:09:50,550 --> 00:09:54,098
And so, we're not allowed to do
any of the higher level training.

180
00:09:54,098 --> 00:09:57,227
If you wanna go to the intermediate and
higher levels,

181
00:09:57,227 --> 00:10:01,600
you've gotta go to an official,
accredited, authorized AXELOS vendor.

182
00:10:01,600 --> 00:10:02,720
And if I remember correctly,

00:10:47,360 --> 00:10:51,180
Ronnie, you mentioned these all of

Ronnie, do you know what it was in

00:10:56,760 --> 00:10:58,088

00:10:58,088 --> 00:10:59,770

00:10:59,770 --> 00:11:02,640

204
00:11:02,640 --> 00:11:07,750
So, it was the transition from mainframes

205
00:11:07,750 --> 00:11:09,760
So in the 80s, most companies,

206
00:11:09,760 --> 00:11:12,330
if you had computers your computers
were just dummy terminals.

207
00:11:12,330 --> 00:11:14,070
And they connect it to a mainframe.

208
00:11:14,070 --> 00:11:17,010
And that mainframe,
you developed software on it, and so on.

209
00:11:17,010 --> 00:11:18,824
And that was basically what people did.

210
00:11:18,824 --> 00:11:21,940
And if you needed a product you
usually didn't develop it in-house.

211
00:11:21,940 --> 00:11:24,840
You contacted a vendor and
purchased it and that was it.

212
00:11:24,840 --> 00:11:28,540
So there wasn't a lot of room for
mistake in that model.

213
00:11:28,540 --> 00:11:33,020
You really couldn't go wrong cuz it
wasn't you developing the technology.

214
00:11:33,020 --> 00:11:35,990
But, towards the end of the 80s,

215
00:11:35,990 --> 00:11:38,210

became a lot more common.

216
00:11:38,210 --> 00:11:42,270

217
00:11:42,270 --> 00:11:45,300

00:11:45,300 --> 00:11:46,800

00:11:46,800 --> 00:11:52,030

00:11:52,030 --> 00:11:55,820

221
00:11:55,820 --> 00:11:59,510

222
00:11:59,510 --> 00:12:01,060

223

00:12:03,620 --> 00:12:07,810

225
00:12:07,810 --> 00:12:12,200

226
00:12:12,200 --> 00:12:16,010

227
00:12:16,010 --> 00:12:19,560
And so that's what really

228
00:12:19,560 --> 00:12:21,630

229
00:12:21,630 --> 00:12:25,640

00:12:25,640 --> 00:12:27,060

00:12:27,060 --> 00:12:30,650

00:12:34,200 --> 00:12:40,320

00:12:40,320 --> 00:12:44,700
So you saw the initial releases of ITIL,

00:12:44,700 --> 00:12:47,180

00:12:57,128 --> 00:12:58,680

00:12:58,680 --> 00:13:03,710
But then when they started looking

242
00:13:03,710 --> 00:13:10,100

we're not trying to be practice-specific.

243
00:13:10,100 --> 00:13:13,790
We're not trying to zoom in
on one particular vendor.

244
00:13:13,790 --> 00:13:17,280
What we want is something that
can be actually provided across

245
00:13:17,280 --> 00:13:20,730
entirety of companies,
regardless of what they're doing.

246
00:13:20,730 --> 00:13:22,650
And so it's not one specific vendor,

247
00:13:22,650 --> 00:13:27,260
it's not any proprietary information,
or any one system.

248
00:13:27,260 --> 00:13:30,050
And so they started dropping them,
or I shouldn't say dropping,

249
00:13:30,050 --> 00:13:33,120
condensing them into what was
only essential the framework.

00:13:33,120 --> 00:13:34,930
And that's why a lot of people like it.

251
00:13:34,930 --> 00:13:35,650
>> Yeah.

00:13:35,650 --> 00:13:39,660
So, that initial form nobody

00:13:39,660 --> 00:13:41,640

It's basically like this

00:14:03,466 --> 00:14:05,411

00:52:31,245 --> 00:52:31,835

the FCC was getting involved and

00:52:35,885 --> 00:52:38,930

1052
00:52:38,930 --> 00:52:41,250
So it's nice to be able to

00:52:41,250 --> 00:52:42,520

00:52:42,520 --> 00:52:46,470
The larger your organization is the more

00:52:49,170 --> 00:52:53,510

00:52:56,750 --> 00:52:58,290

Versus other departments

a change in procedure

And if it doesn't work out,

In IT we do.

So risk managers are pretty

1065
00:53:11,780 --> 00:53:15,300
These are all things that are involved in

1066
00:53:15,300 --> 00:53:19,980
with, even before we actually spend out

1067
00:53:19,980 --> 00:53:21,980
So all part of portfolio management.

1068
00:53:23,600 --> 00:53:26,750
And beyond that we've got our other ones.

00:53:26,750 --> 00:53:29,050
If we decide that we're going
to move forward with one,

1070
00:53:29,050 --> 00:53:31,030
then we actually move forward with it,

1071
00:53:31,030 --> 00:53:33,380
And we'll see more of

1072
00:53:33,380 --> 00:53:36,260
In that section of the show that's where
we're going to dive into that kind of

1073
00:53:36,260 --> 00:53:37,440
creation process.

1074
00:53:37,440 --> 00:53:41,990
But for our portfolio management, this is
where we're approving that service to move

1075
00:53:41,990 --> 00:53:46,340
forward, transitioning it into the design
stage, and letting the development go.

1076
00:53:47,590 --> 00:53:49,760
And we're just keeping track of that.

1077
00:53:49,760 --> 00:53:52,540
Part of portfolio management
is simply managing metrics.

1078
00:53:52,540 --> 00:53:56,460
By keeping track of how much money has
been spent, how much progress is going on.

1079
00:53:56,460 --> 00:54:00,560
And even once a service is active and
deployed, we still track it.

1080
00:54:00,560 --> 00:54:03,966
It's all part of governance, making sure
that service is running as expected.

1081
00:54:03,966 --> 00:54:05,812
That's delivering the way
we anticipated it.

1082
00:54:05,812 --> 00:54:11,620
And if it isn't,
taking some kind of corrective action.

1083
00:54:11,620 --> 00:54:15,400
So those are some examples of
things we do with new projects.

1084
00:54:15,400 --> 00:54:20,090
For the existing ones, we're going to

1085
00:54:20,090 --> 00:54:25,010
A service catalog, it might be

00:54:25,010 --> 00:54:29,080

1087
00:54:29,080 --> 00:54:32,560

00:54:32,560 --> 00:54:34,670
That can be really hard for

1089
00:54:34,670 --> 00:54:38,420
For us it's easy, ITProTV,

00:54:38,420 --> 00:54:42,310
You can come to our website and you can

00:54:42,310 --> 00:54:43,470
it's very, very simple.

00:54:45,320 --> 00:54:47,910
But if you take a company like Symantec.

00:54:47,910 --> 00:54:51,600
Symantec has so many services

00:54:51,600 --> 00:54:54,220
IBM has so

00:54:54,220 --> 00:54:57,420
You go to their web pages,
like if you go to Symantec's web page,

1097
00:54:57,420 --> 00:55:00,530
I can name 15 different

00:55:00,530 --> 00:55:03,940
But if you go to their home page,

00:55:03,940 --> 00:55:05,930
They have a little menu

00:55:05,930 --> 00:55:07,290

1101
00:55:07,290 --> 00:55:09,740
And then we'll guide you to the group
of products we sell that might help

00:55:09,740 --> 00:55:10,550
you achieve that.

00:55:10,550 --> 00:55:12,030
It's so confusing.

1104
00:55:12,030 --> 00:55:14,148
So, the more and
more services your company offers,

00:55:14,148 --> 00:55:15,524
the more difficult this becomes.

00:55:15,524 --> 00:55:18,598
So you got to have a catalog to
keep track of what you offer and

1107
00:55:18,598 --> 00:55:20,965
make sure that it's all aligned.

00:55:20,965 --> 00:55:23,325
And that where companies like

00:55:23,325 --> 00:55:24,487
HP is restructuring right now.

00:55:24,487 --> 00:55:27,515
They're dividing into two companies

1111
00:55:27,515 --> 00:55:29,665
And they were so
far out of alignment they said,

1112
00:55:29,665 --> 00:55:32,085
you know what,
we just can't bring this back in line.

00:55:32,085 --> 00:55:33,645
We'll split into two companies.

00:55:33,645 --> 00:55:38,080
Imagine what a nightmare that must be,

1115
00:55:39,270 --> 00:55:41,480
So normally, when you see a company

00:55:41,480 --> 00:55:43,940
it means that they've made it to the point

00:55:43,940 --> 00:55:46,970

1118
00:55:46,970 --> 00:55:48,000
And that's a good thing, right?

1119
00:55:48,000 --> 00:55:49,220
They're doing portfolio management.

1120
00:55:49,220 --> 00:55:52,150
They just didn't do it early enough

00:55:52,150 --> 00:55:54,580
now they're using it to correct,
they're saying, we got all these services.

00:55:54,580 --> 00:55:57,050
If it's not in line with what we
want to do, let's branch it off.

1123
00:55:57,050 --> 00:56:00,840
IBM, where they sold their laptop
division and desktop division to Lenovo,

1124
00:56:00,840 --> 00:56:03,180
and now they've sold their
server division to Lenovo.

1125
00:56:03,180 --> 00:56:06,460
They're saying hardware manufacturing
is not in line with what we want now.

1126
00:56:06,460 --> 00:56:09,210
It's in line with what we wanted
ten years ago, but not today.

1127
00:56:09,210 --> 00:56:12,381
So let's sell that off to somebody else,
and we'll focus in on what we want to do.

1128
00:56:12,381 --> 00:56:15,725
So your existing services
may transition to retired

1129
00:56:15,725 --> 00:56:18,313
services if you decide to sell them off.

1130
00:56:18,313 --> 00:56:19,512
Or you maintain them.

1131
00:56:19,512 --> 00:56:22,330
That's part of maintaining our portfolio.

1132
00:56:23,820 --> 00:56:28,160
All right, so that whole process
is called a service life cycle.

1133
00:56:28,160 --> 00:56:33,230
When we select a service, we design it,
we employ it into our environment,

1134
00:56:33,230 --> 00:56:34,410
we integrate it.

1135
00:56:34,410 --> 00:56:37,890
And then we maintain it,
we do the operations and run it.

1136
00:56:37,890 --> 00:56:39,880
And then, eventually, retire it, right?

1137
00:56:39,880 --> 00:56:41,490
That's all part of the life cycle.

1138
00:56:41,490 --> 00:56:45,860
And, portfolio management
tracks every piece of that.

1139
00:56:45,860 --> 00:56:47,360
All right,
what have I left out here, Ronnie?

1140
00:56:47,360 --> 00:56:48,600
I know there's some more stuff.

1141
00:56:48,600 --> 00:56:51,300
>> Well, we've already talked about
what we're currently offering, and

1142
00:56:51,300 --> 00:56:55,155
then also how we might end up
choosing to retire a service?

1143
00:56:55,155 --> 00:56:56,805
But, what about bringing on a new service?

1144
00:56:56,805 --> 00:56:58,795
That's where we're actually
headed at this point,

1145
00:56:58,795 --> 00:57:03,365
is to take a look is evaluating
a potential new service, and whether or

1146
00:57:03,365 --> 00:57:06,300
not we want to bring that
into our portfolio as well.

1147
00:57:06,300 --> 00:57:10,900
So, when we talk about what service we
wanna bring, we always want to define it

1148
00:57:10,900 --> 00:57:15,150
in terms of utility and possibly,
even the idea of warranty.

1149
00:57:16,280 --> 00:57:21,120
>> And these two, everybody thinks about
them when you offer a new service.

1150
00:57:21,120 --> 00:57:23,120
But, you can actually apply
these to your existing services,

1151
00:57:23,120 --> 00:57:25,720
too because things in
the environment might change.

1152
00:57:25,720 --> 00:57:27,490
While it did provide utility and

1153
00:57:27,490 --> 00:57:29,920
warranty in the beginning,
down the road it doesn't.

1154
00:57:29,920 --> 00:57:32,900
So, let's break apart these ideas
to understand what they are.

1155
00:57:32,900 --> 00:57:35,140
That first one, utility, right?

1156
00:57:35,140 --> 00:57:38,310
I usually describe that really simply is,

1157
00:57:38,310 --> 00:57:42,105
does this service contribute
to the costumer's need, right?

1158
00:57:42,105 --> 00:57:44,365
Is this providing what
the customer's asking for?

1159
00:57:44,365 --> 00:57:45,985
It may or may not.

1160
00:57:45,985 --> 00:57:51,135
And the term you'll hear associated with
this more commonly is, fit for purpose.

1161
00:57:51,135 --> 00:57:55,165
The service I'm providing, is it fit for
what the customer's purpose is.

1162
00:57:55,165 --> 00:57:56,075
What they want.

1163
00:57:56,075 --> 00:57:58,885
So, if I have a customer that
comes to me and says, Don.

1164
00:57:58,885 --> 00:58:04,210
I really need a series of videos,
some kind of online training.

1165
00:58:04,210 --> 00:58:06,340
That'll teach me how to use Lotus 123.

1166
00:58:06,340 --> 00:58:11,350
And I say, well, shoot, Lotus 123,
that's really old spreadsheet software.

1167
00:58:11,350 --> 00:58:15,460
And I don't think we're gonna do a video,
but we have some Excel videos and

1168
00:58:15,460 --> 00:58:16,780
a spreadsheet's a spreadsheet.

1169
00:58:16,780 --> 00:58:19,170
So, maybe I'll just send them
over to the Excel videos instead.

1170
00:58:20,210 --> 00:58:22,490
Well, a spreadsheet's a spreadsheet.

1171
00:58:22,490 --> 00:58:27,640
But, on the utility side, am I providing
something that meets their purpose?

1172
00:58:27,640 --> 00:58:28,918
And in that case, I'm not.

1173
00:58:28,918 --> 00:58:31,580
That Lotus 123 has different
command structures,

1174
00:58:31,580 --> 00:58:33,730
different functions than what Excel does.

1175
00:58:33,730 --> 00:58:37,000
And so, what they learn from
my video won't match up with

1176
00:58:37,000 --> 00:58:38,100
what they actually wanted.

1177
00:58:38,100 --> 00:58:43,830
It's not fit for purpose, so that goes
back to respecting your customer's needs.

1178
00:58:43,830 --> 00:58:48,560
What your customer wants,
we gotta make sure we live up to that.

1179
00:58:48,560 --> 00:58:49,840
And then warranty.

1180
00:58:49,840 --> 00:58:54,160
So warranty says,
once we give them the service.

1181
00:58:54,160 --> 00:58:55,990
Does it actually perform as planned?

1182
00:58:55,990 --> 00:58:58,510
Does it deliver on what we promised?

1183
00:58:58,510 --> 00:59:00,520
And they call this fitness for use.

1184
00:59:01,640 --> 00:59:03,500
Are they actually able to use it?

1185
00:59:03,500 --> 00:59:07,380
So for example, I used to have
a really good example on this,

1186
00:59:07,380 --> 00:59:12,200
but let's say that somebody asks for
a hammer.

1187
00:59:12,200 --> 00:59:13,600
That they need a hammer.

1188
00:59:13,600 --> 00:59:15,500
So, we decide to offer a new service,

1189
00:59:15,500 --> 00:59:17,150
we're gonna manufacture hammers and
sell them.

1190
00:59:17,150 --> 00:59:19,000
All right.
So, we're gonna meet this customers need,

1191
00:59:19,000 --> 00:59:20,550
by providing them with a hammer.

1192
00:59:20,550 --> 00:59:24,365
And so, as we start to do our design
we go to our engineers and we say,

1193
00:59:24,365 --> 00:59:28,515
look guys we need to increase our
profit margin as much as possible.

1194
00:59:28,515 --> 00:59:32,775
So, I want you to use the cheapest
components absolutely possible,

1195
00:59:32,775 --> 00:59:34,740
just the bare minimum.

1196
00:59:34,740 --> 00:59:37,780
Because they asked for
a hammer that could drive in a nail.

1197
00:59:37,780 --> 00:59:39,680
Let's be specific.

1198
00:59:39,680 --> 00:59:42,580
We're gonna drive in a nail just one.

1199
00:59:42,580 --> 00:59:47,510
Give us the strength in that hammer,
to drive in just one nail.

1200
00:59:47,510 --> 00:59:48,990
We don't care beyond that right?

1201
00:59:48,990 --> 00:59:51,200
If you can pound in one nail
that's a successful hammer.

1202
00:59:51,200 --> 00:59:53,410
So we design it, and
we give it to the customer.

1203
00:59:53,410 --> 00:59:56,010
Now technically, the utility is there.

1204
00:59:56,010 --> 00:59:57,120
Does it perform?

1205
00:59:57,120 --> 00:59:57,640
Yes.

1206
00:59:57,640 --> 00:59:59,970
I can use this hammer to bang in one nail.

1207
00:59:59,970 --> 01:00:04,860
But, when I set that second nail up and
I go to bang it in, the hammer breaks.

1208
01:00:04,860 --> 01:00:07,090
It was only good for
one nail and that's it.

1209
01:00:07,090 --> 01:00:12,320
Now the customer has an expectation, that
they need a hammer that can bang in nails,

1210
01:00:12,320 --> 01:00:15,270
and they need to be able to bang
in more than just one nail,

1211
01:00:15,270 --> 01:00:17,000
and if it breaks before that.

1212
01:00:17,000 --> 01:00:20,380
Yes it had the utility,
that matched what they asked for, but.

1213
01:00:20,380 --> 01:00:22,730
It didn't, it wasn't fit for

1214
01:00:22,730 --> 01:00:26,980
their use what they wanted to use it for,
driving in repeated nails.

1215
01:00:26,980 --> 01:00:32,300
So, that's a symptom of projects that
don't have detailed requirement lists.

1216
01:00:32,300 --> 01:00:35,903
So, a customer won't specify that they
won't say, I need you to make me a hammer,

1217
01:00:35,903 --> 01:00:39,130
and it needs to be able to
drive in at least 2000 nails.

1218
01:00:39,130 --> 01:00:41,540
And that needs to be our
mean time between failure,

1219
01:00:41,540 --> 01:00:44,580
that we can do two thousand nails before
something goes wrong with the hammer.

1220
01:00:44,580 --> 01:00:46,100
And now we design it,
people don't think that way.

1221
01:00:46,100 --> 01:00:47,450
They say I need a hammer.

1222
01:00:47,450 --> 01:00:50,710
It's kind of built in that assumption
that it's gonna work for a long time.

1223
01:00:50,710 --> 01:00:52,700
It's a hammer,
there's no moving parts, right?

1224
01:00:52,700 --> 01:00:57,240
So that's a problem, and as we define
our services we can skip all we want.

1225
01:00:57,240 --> 01:00:59,830
But, what's that gonna do to
the value of the customer?

1226
01:00:59,830 --> 01:01:01,080
And what's that gonna do long term,

1227
01:01:01,080 --> 01:01:02,590
in terms of the value of
the services that we offer?

1228
01:01:02,590 --> 01:01:03,160
It's going to hurt it.

1229
01:01:03,160 --> 01:01:04,300
It's not gonna be very effective.

1230
01:01:06,130 --> 01:01:07,910
So, utility and warranty.

1231
01:01:07,910 --> 01:01:10,370
Those are two pieces
that factor into this.

1232
01:01:10,370 --> 01:01:13,320
When we're picking a service to offer,

1233
01:01:13,320 --> 01:01:17,710
we may not have enough information to
do utility and warranty at that point.

1234
01:01:17,710 --> 01:01:19,970
But in the design phase,
we definitely will.

1235
01:01:19,970 --> 01:01:23,530
So, when we're designing that service
to offer, we need to focus on that.

1236
01:01:23,530 --> 01:01:26,240
And then when we actually
offer the service,

1237
01:01:26,240 --> 01:01:29,130
we know we've lived up to the utility and
warranty that we designed.

1238
01:01:29,130 --> 01:01:31,300
And we've even backed that with
an express warranty, right?

1239
01:01:31,300 --> 01:01:34,390
One that we've written on paper that says,
we will warrant this,

1240
01:01:34,390 --> 01:01:38,450
if it breaks within 2000 hits of a nail,
then send it back and we'll replace it.

1241
01:01:38,450 --> 01:01:43,200
We back up our warranties, but
we need to keep monitoring beyond that.

1242
01:01:43,200 --> 01:01:46,390
Because maybe three years from now,

1243
01:01:46,390 --> 01:01:48,690
something happens in the construction
industry, and they say what?

1244
01:01:48,690 --> 01:01:51,120
We're gonna go to all galvanized nails.

1245
01:01:51,120 --> 01:01:52,500
I'm making this up Ronnie.

1246
01:01:52,500 --> 01:01:55,130
I don't actually know if nails
are galvanized or not, but so

1247
01:01:55,130 --> 01:01:59,265
maybe we've got all galvanized nails, and
all of a sudden our hammer that could do

1248
01:01:59,265 --> 01:02:03,390
2,000 nails before, now can only do
1,000 because the nails are harder.

1249
01:02:03,390 --> 01:02:05,920
And so I need to keep an eye on that, and

1250
01:02:05,920 --> 01:02:10,010
say well the construction industry
has changed, now I need to change.

1251
01:02:10,010 --> 01:02:12,360
My service needs to change
to match up with that,

1252
01:02:12,360 --> 01:02:15,000
to maintain the level of utility and
work that we used to have.

1253
01:02:15,000 --> 01:02:18,440
That happens all the time, and we're
seeing that with like gas mileage in cars,

1254
01:02:18,440 --> 01:02:21,943
where the EPA here in the US is
forcing certain miles per gallon to

1255
01:02:21,943 --> 01:02:25,480
improve car efficiency.

01:02:25,480 --> 01:02:28,860
So, your car might have met all
the standards before, and now it doesn't.

1257
01:02:28,860 --> 01:02:32,790
So we've gotta reevaluate,
that's all part of portfolio management.

1258
01:02:32,790 --> 01:02:36,850
And this is another area that's really
being handled at the top by management.

1259
01:02:36,850 --> 01:02:38,900
This is what they do,
it's how they make their money?

1260
01:02:38,900 --> 01:02:43,760
And as the hands on person, the doer,
you're just operating within this

1261
01:02:43,760 --> 01:02:48,150
realm as you keep the services running and
moving along, all right?

1262
01:02:48,150 --> 01:02:49,960
So, that is basically
portfolio management.

1263
01:02:49,960 --> 01:02:51,090
It's really important, right?

1264
01:02:51,090 --> 01:02:54,130
I mean, this is really one of
the main aspects of management inside

1265
01:02:54,130 --> 01:02:54,679
of an organization.

1266

1267

1273

1274

1275

1276

>> [CROSSTALK] I can't get my mind in

The service strategy processes

26

27

And moving through the final three
processes in service strategies.

28
00:01:09,300 --> 00:01:14,490
So, our very next process is financial
management, for IT services.

29
00:01:14,490 --> 00:01:17,780
Now, that last little bit is important.

30
00:01:17,780 --> 00:01:21,080
There is financial management for
your company as a whole.

31
00:01:21,080 --> 00:01:23,120
ITIL does not address that.

32
00:01:23,120 --> 00:01:27,280
Remember it's the information
technology industry library.

33
00:01:27,280 --> 00:01:28,950
It's IT, not your company.

34
00:01:28,950 --> 00:01:32,110
So, every company does finances different.

35
00:01:32,110 --> 00:01:33,770
Often times,
they don't even have control over it.

36
00:01:33,770 --> 00:01:37,850
The government steps in with regulations,
and other things that they have to follow.

37
00:01:37,850 --> 00:01:42,110
But inside of IT, there's various
recommended practices we can follow.

38
00:01:42,110 --> 00:01:46,430
And they almost all center around
the fact, that IT departments rarely,

39
00:01:46,430 --> 00:01:48,090
make any money.

40
00:01:48,090 --> 00:01:51,900
Most of the time an IT department
is what's called a cost center.

41
00:01:51,900 --> 00:01:53,300
We generate cost.

42
00:01:53,300 --> 00:01:56,250
We would cost money to operate,
we swallow money.

43
00:01:56,250 --> 00:01:59,880
But we don't actually generate a product
that we then turn around, and sell.

44
00:01:59,880 --> 00:02:02,980
So, most of the time we're
providing supporting services,

45
00:02:02,980 --> 00:02:07,680
enhancing services, that aren't
the true service the customer buys.

46
00:02:07,680 --> 00:02:10,860
And I know I've given examples of that in
other shows, but just to kind of recap it.

47
00:02:12,000 --> 00:02:17,430
If our customers want to get
a email invoice every month.

48
00:02:17,430 --> 00:02:19,980
So, they can invoice of what
they spent with us, and

49
00:02:19,980 --> 00:02:21,950
then they use that to pay the bill.

50
00:02:21,950 --> 00:02:25,700
Well, the service they're getting from us,
maybe we're a cellphone company.

51
00:02:25,700 --> 00:02:27,930
So, they get the cell phone service.

52
00:02:27,930 --> 00:02:32,150
And they get the bill, and they pay
the bill, so that causes money to come in.

53
00:02:32,150 --> 00:02:34,120
But it's the cell phone
service they're paying for,

54
00:02:34,120 --> 00:02:36,730
not the fact that we sent them the bill.

55
00:02:36,730 --> 00:02:39,410
So, the IT department is not
directly generating that revenue,

56
00:02:39,410 --> 00:02:42,840
we're just generating a part of it,
a service that supports that happening.

57
00:02:42,840 --> 00:02:45,410
If we didn't send the bill,
would the customer pay it?

58
00:02:45,410 --> 00:02:46,030
Probably not.

59
00:02:46,030 --> 00:02:48,655
They need to get a bill to know,
to pay, so it's essential.

60
00:02:48,655 --> 00:02:51,000
No, don't ever think
that it's not essential,

61
00:02:51,000 --> 00:02:54,020
it's just not directly generating revenue.

62
00:02:54,020 --> 00:02:57,480
As we manage our finances inside of
IT we need to keep that in mind, and

63
00:02:57,480 --> 00:03:01,140
we need to be very
transparent about our costs.

64
00:03:01,140 --> 00:03:03,060
Because here's what happens if your not.

65
00:03:04,150 --> 00:03:05,570
Your company has a strategy.

66
00:03:05,570 --> 00:03:08,530
They have a goal,
they're trying to achieve.

67
00:03:08,530 --> 00:03:12,510
And everything we do in IT needs to
be in alignment with that strategy.

68
00:03:12,510 --> 00:03:17,720
Well, if they don't give us enough
funding to achieve the goal.

69
00:03:17,720 --> 00:03:20,560
So, we need money to achieve the goal,
to work in the strategy.

70
00:03:20,560 --> 00:03:23,490
And if they don't give us
enough funding to do it,

71
00:03:23,490 --> 00:03:25,490
we can't work within the strategy.

72
00:03:25,490 --> 00:03:28,090
And if that happens,
as an IT department, we're failing.

73
00:03:28,090 --> 00:03:31,140
And they'll look at that, and they'll
view it as bad performance on our part.

74
00:03:31,140 --> 00:03:33,280
And we'll get blamed.

75
00:03:33,280 --> 00:03:36,390
But the actual cause of
the problem was not that we didn't

76
00:03:36,390 --> 00:03:38,090
choose to operate within the strategy.

77
00:03:38,090 --> 00:03:39,840
We just couldn't,
we didn't have the funding.

78
00:03:39,840 --> 00:03:42,970
And so, if we're tracking our expenses.

79
00:03:42,970 --> 00:03:45,170
How our funds are being distributed.

80
00:03:45,170 --> 00:03:48,140
We can report that back, and
we can say hey guys we are not gonna

81
00:03:48,140 --> 00:03:51,200
be able to meet the strategy,
cuz we don't have enough money.

82
00:03:51,200 --> 00:03:54,730
And when that happens, there's really
just two actions that you can take.

83
00:03:54,730 --> 00:03:55,410
Action number one,

84
00:03:55,410 --> 00:03:58,110
is to increase the funding,
that's not what we want to happen.

85
00:03:58,110 --> 00:04:01,870
But option number two,
is we can re-evaluate our strategy.

86
00:04:01,870 --> 00:04:05,100
And we can say, hey, we've got this
strategy's goal, and it's great,

87
00:04:05,100 --> 00:04:06,330
we'd love to hit it.

88
00:04:06,330 --> 00:04:07,390
But, we just can't afford it.

89
00:04:07,390 --> 00:04:10,640
We can't afford to offer, what we want.

90
00:04:10,640 --> 00:04:13,470
And so, we've got to re-evaluate
our strategy, and reduce it.

91
00:04:13,470 --> 00:04:16,400
So that, we can operate with
the money that we have.

92
00:04:16,400 --> 00:04:17,395
A lot of people have great visions.

93
00:04:17,395 --> 00:04:23,351
I would love for ITProTV to be free.

94
00:04:23,351 --> 00:04:26,100
I would love for you guys to be
able to watch our stuff, and

95
00:04:26,100 --> 00:04:27,197
not have to pay a dime.

96
00:04:27,197 --> 00:04:28,428
I think that would be awesome.

97
00:04:28,428 --> 00:04:32,446
I think that we would have hundreds of
thousands of users, and tons of activity,

98
00:04:32,446 --> 00:04:33,875
and it would be really cool.

99
00:04:33,875 --> 00:04:37,980
But you can't keep the lights on for free.

100
00:04:37,980 --> 00:04:40,360
So, you've got to have some way
to generate the revenue, and

101
00:04:40,360 --> 00:04:43,060
so your model changes,
your strategy changes.

102
00:04:43,060 --> 00:04:46,918
And you end up with a company that
is viable versus the one that you

103
00:04:46,918 --> 00:04:48,072
actually wanted.

104
00:04:48,072 --> 00:04:50,312
And that's part of what
strategy comes down to.

105
00:04:50,312 --> 00:04:53,808
But with IT, it's just really
important to keep track of that,

106
00:04:53,808 --> 00:04:57,110
cuz if we're not keeping track
of where our funds are going,

107
00:04:57,110 --> 00:04:59,476
then we may not be getting enough funding.

108
00:04:59,476 --> 00:05:01,481
And we're not meeting the strategy, but

109
00:05:01,481 --> 00:05:05,267
all the company is able to see is that we
didn't stay in line with the strategy.

110
00:05:05,267 --> 00:05:07,680
We're doing something wrong.

111
00:05:07,680 --> 00:05:08,920
So, that's why it is so important.

112
00:05:08,920 --> 00:05:11,865
And that's why we have financial
management, just for IT services.

113
00:05:11,865 --> 00:05:12,810
>> Yeah.

114
00:05:12,810 --> 00:05:17,550
A lot of times the financial management
part really does help us to make sure,

115
00:05:17,550 --> 00:05:20,740
that when we design something,
when we develop it, and

116
00:05:20,740 --> 00:05:24,680
we deliver it, that we do have the money
that we need to be able to do so.

117
00:05:24,680 --> 00:05:27,270
If we don't,
we have to figure out how to procure it.

118
00:05:27,270 --> 00:05:30,060
We may also in the financial
management part,

119
00:05:30,060 --> 00:05:33,530
take a look at what we can do effectively,
and well.

120
00:05:33,530 --> 00:05:36,150
And then what we can't do effectively,
and well either.

121
00:05:36,150 --> 00:05:38,820
So, we may take on something a little
bit too big for what we need,

122
00:05:38,820 --> 00:05:40,660
and well, wait a minute, that's too much.

123
00:05:40,660 --> 00:05:43,700
So, knowing what we can do, and
what we can't do is an important part.

124
00:05:43,700 --> 00:05:48,590
As well as knowing, what the value
that we want to present is worth.

125
00:05:48,590 --> 00:05:53,130
Sometimes we go well,
I wanna present this, and this.

126
00:05:53,130 --> 00:05:54,420
But I wanna charge this for it.

127
00:05:54,420 --> 00:05:57,120
Just like what Don said,
we want this to be free, but

128
00:05:57,120 --> 00:05:59,210
right now we can't keep our eyes on it,
if it is.

129
00:05:59,210 --> 00:06:01,610
So, it may not be able to be something.

130
00:06:01,610 --> 00:06:05,315
And these are all part of somebody that
actually is able to come into your

131
00:06:05,315 --> 00:06:08,772
company, or a part of your team,
that can manage those finances,

132
00:06:08,772 --> 00:06:10,968
to help put that into clear perspective.

133
00:06:10,968 --> 00:06:14,150
It also helps us to meet a lot of
those business needs that we have.

134
00:06:14,150 --> 00:06:17,102
>> Yeah.
And if you've done any project management,

135
00:06:17,102 --> 00:06:19,349
in project management you have a scope.

136
00:06:19,349 --> 00:06:22,643
And part of what defines that are these
three, they call them the project

137
00:06:22,643 --> 00:06:25,676
constraints, and they really
apply to even non-project stuff.

138
00:06:25,676 --> 00:06:32,932
You have schedule, budget, and resources.

139
00:06:32,932 --> 00:06:36,148
I'm sorry, is requirements there?

140
00:06:36,148 --> 00:06:37,582
>> No.
>> So here, it will be a little different.

141
00:06:37,582 --> 00:06:41,902
But basically, when you want to make
one of those three things better,

142
00:06:41,902 --> 00:06:43,703
the other two have to suffer.

143
00:06:43,703 --> 00:06:45,305
They are all inter-related.

144
00:06:45,305 --> 00:06:48,411
And so, when we do our
financial management for IT,

145
00:06:48,411 --> 00:06:50,888
we are tracking three different things.

146
00:06:50,888 --> 00:06:54,563
We're tracking our money, so
where the dollars are going?

147
00:06:54,563 --> 00:06:59,045
We're tracking our time, how long things
take, and time often reflects money.

148
00:06:59,045 --> 00:06:59,985
Time is money.

149
00:06:59,985 --> 00:07:03,220
If you have an hourly employee,
that's absolutely true.

150
00:07:03,220 --> 00:07:05,990
And then lastly, we have our resources.

151
00:07:05,990 --> 00:07:08,210
And the resources are typically people.

152
00:07:08,210 --> 00:07:09,010
But they don't have to be.

153
00:07:09,010 --> 00:07:12,220
They could be other things like equipment,
or facilities, or whatever.

154
00:07:12,220 --> 00:07:13,030
But it's typically people.

155
00:07:13,030 --> 00:07:19,860
So, we're tracking how those things are
being used, within the realm of finance.

156
00:07:20,860 --> 00:07:25,530
And it's all because we need to make sure
that the time we spent providing services,

157
00:07:25,530 --> 00:07:29,180
the money we spent on those services,
and the people we have working on those

158
00:07:29,180 --> 00:07:32,990
services, are all doing things that are in
line with our overall company strategy.

159
00:07:34,160 --> 00:07:36,860
So, the way we see that
in actual practice,

160
00:07:36,860 --> 00:07:39,940
to put it in accounting terms,
we see budgeting.

161
00:07:39,940 --> 00:07:43,840
Budgeting, that's controlling
who gets money when.

162
00:07:43,840 --> 00:07:47,330
I might have a million dollars sitting
in my bank reserves, for the year.

163
00:07:47,330 --> 00:07:49,290
So, I've got a million dollar budget.

164
00:07:49,290 --> 00:07:51,310
When do I take money out of that?

165
00:07:51,310 --> 00:07:54,310
I need to take money out to
support services that build to

166
00:07:54,310 --> 00:07:55,420
the companies strategy.

167
00:07:55,420 --> 00:07:58,355
I don't need to take money out, for things
that don't align with that strategy.

168
00:07:58,355 --> 00:08:03,000
So, budgeting is just being a traffic cop,
controlling the flow of money.

169
00:08:03,000 --> 00:08:06,273
It's normally coupled with accounting
We're just keeping track of that, right?

170
00:08:06,273 --> 00:08:09,903
So once the money goes out, it gets spent,
we get our receipt back and

171
00:08:09,903 --> 00:08:14,640
the other information so we tally what
happens after the money was spent.

172
00:08:14,640 --> 00:08:18,140
>> Accounting is an important part of this
process because it gives us the ability to

173
00:08:18,140 --> 00:08:20,910
forecast into the future
about what we might need for

174
00:08:20,910 --> 00:08:23,190
the next development that comes along.

175
00:08:23,190 --> 00:08:26,540
If we don't have that accounting part,
we may go oh just set aside this and

176
00:08:26,540 --> 00:08:28,590
they're like but there's no justification.

177
00:08:28,590 --> 00:08:32,250
So accounting is a very important part
of the project along with the budgeting.

178
00:08:32,250 --> 00:08:36,690
Which leads us to the last part,
which is the charging.

179
00:08:36,690 --> 00:08:37,915
.
>> And charging is where things get

180
00:08:37,915 --> 00:08:38,990
tricky, right.

181
00:08:38,990 --> 00:08:41,140
If you're an IT company.

182
00:08:41,140 --> 00:08:44,380
If your company's service is
something that's IT related,

183
00:08:44,380 --> 00:08:48,680
then when we talk about charging,
we're talking about billing the customer.

184
00:08:48,680 --> 00:08:53,300
So if you work for Facebook, right?

185
00:08:53,300 --> 00:08:55,560
They provide a website,
that's their service.

186
00:08:55,560 --> 00:08:58,860
Their IT department runs that website and
you can throw ads on it.

187
00:08:58,860 --> 00:09:02,700
And if you want those ads,
the IT department will take those ads and

188
00:09:02,700 --> 00:09:05,710
host them and send you a bill for
the clicks or whatever that you got.

189
00:09:05,710 --> 00:09:07,620
So in that case you're
charging an external customer,

190
00:09:07,620 --> 00:09:08,920
it makes absolute sense.

191
00:09:10,010 --> 00:09:13,870
But, if you're going way back to
the beginning of the last show,

192
00:09:13,870 --> 00:09:16,560
we were talking about the type one,
type two, and type three customers.

193
00:09:16,560 --> 00:09:20,100
If it's a type one or type two situation,
those are internal customers.

194
00:09:20,100 --> 00:09:23,130
Type one being one business unit,

195
00:09:23,130 --> 00:09:27,540
type two being multiple business units
that we're basically selling to.

196
00:09:27,540 --> 00:09:31,960
And in those cases we don't necessarily
send them a bill saying well,

197
00:09:31,960 --> 00:09:36,100
here's how much time we spent and here's
how much that service cost and so on.

198
00:09:36,100 --> 00:09:42,250
Instead we keep track of how much of our
budget was used to achieve that goal,

199
00:09:42,250 --> 00:09:46,030
so that at the end of the year when
we're planning next years budget and

200
00:09:46,030 --> 00:09:49,060
we say, all right we need
a million dollars for 2015,

201
00:09:49,060 --> 00:09:53,080
our budgets going to be a million
dollars across the year, all right?

202
00:09:53,080 --> 00:09:53,850
Where does that come from?

203
00:09:53,850 --> 00:09:54,900
Where does that money come from?

204
00:09:54,900 --> 00:09:58,470
It's not coming from the customer it's
coming from the other business units.

205
00:09:58,470 --> 00:10:03,100
So in the marketing department,
if they accounted for,

206
00:10:03,100 --> 00:10:06,290
let's say 200,000 of our expenses, right?

207
00:10:06,290 --> 00:10:07,440
So if marketing accounted for

208
00:10:07,440 --> 00:10:12,570
that percentage of our expenses, then
in their budget, they put that flag in

209
00:10:12,570 --> 00:10:16,280
there that says this amount of money goes
to IT to cover the services that we use.

210
00:10:16,280 --> 00:10:19,530
So it's making sure that it
doesn't create the impression

211
00:10:19,530 --> 00:10:21,690
that IT is spending all of this money.

212
00:10:21,690 --> 00:10:24,340
All of our money should be in alignment

213
00:10:24,340 --> 00:10:27,930
with services that are being provided
to facilitate our overall strategy,

214
00:10:27,930 --> 00:10:32,520
other business units and so
it should be all able to be matched up.

215
00:10:32,520 --> 00:10:33,800
So at the end of the year when they say,

216
00:10:33,800 --> 00:10:37,100
man the IT department spent a million
dollars, we should cut back on that.

217
00:10:37,100 --> 00:10:37,970
Right?

218
00:10:37,970 --> 00:10:40,130
IT doesn't make us any money,
let's cut it back.

219
00:10:40,130 --> 00:10:42,830
But then they look at it and they say well
this portion actually goes to marketing,

220
00:10:42,830 --> 00:10:45,510
and this portion comes from accounting,
this portion comes from sales.

221
00:10:45,510 --> 00:10:48,510
So if we cut those back,
we're actually cutting back on marketing,

222
00:10:48,510 --> 00:10:51,270
we're actually cutting back on sales,
not cutting back on IT.

223
00:10:51,270 --> 00:10:54,190
IT, they'd probably like it
if they had less servers.

224
00:10:54,190 --> 00:10:58,850
>> They'd probably like it if they
had less phones on the help desk so

225
00:10:58,850 --> 00:11:02,290
they didn't get so many calls or whatever,
just kind of send them to voicemail.

226
00:11:02,290 --> 00:11:05,890
So, in those scenarios it's
kind of counterproductive to

227
00:11:05,890 --> 00:11:08,760
cut the IT budget when it's actually the
other departments that's source of it, but

228
00:11:08,760 --> 00:11:10,760
you don't know that unless you track it.

229
00:11:10,760 --> 00:11:15,340
And that's what financial management for
I.T. services is all about.

230
00:11:15,340 --> 00:11:15,900
All right.
And

231
00:11:15,900 --> 00:11:19,460
I just kind of threw a few personal notes,
I don't know that I mentioned this in

232
00:11:19,460 --> 00:11:22,700
this show, but we use these show notes
to keep track of what to talk about.

233
00:11:22,700 --> 00:11:24,910
And I'll post the show
notes with each episode.

234
00:11:24,910 --> 00:11:28,040
So they'll be posted beneath the video,
you'll get a chance to see them.

235
00:11:28,040 --> 00:11:35,570
But basically we just take our expenses,
we have a number attached to them, right.

236
00:11:35,570 --> 00:11:39,330
And if it's something like we had to buy a
server, attaching a number is really easy.

237
00:11:39,330 --> 00:11:43,460
But if it's something like doing
Windows updates on a server,

238
00:11:43,460 --> 00:11:45,960
we got to qualify that in the time
it took the person to work on it.

239
00:11:45,960 --> 00:11:50,690
So we just have to assign a value, right,
we need to quantify, assign a cost.

240
00:11:50,690 --> 00:11:52,340
To everything that we do and

241
00:11:52,340 --> 00:11:56,160
map that to what part of
the business it occurred in, right?

242
00:11:56,160 --> 00:12:00,040
And then that also needs
the map to one of our services,

243
00:12:00,040 --> 00:12:03,319
everything should be supporting a service
that our company offers to the customer.

244
00:12:05,050 --> 00:12:09,690
So we identify those, and
we manage them, we control it.

245
00:12:09,690 --> 00:12:11,880
But then the key pieces is
we then communicate it.

246
00:12:11,880 --> 00:12:14,570
We send that information
back up to the higher ups.

247
00:12:14,570 --> 00:12:17,010
And so
when they are planning the strategy.

248
00:12:17,010 --> 00:12:17,870
They can then plan for

249
00:12:17,870 --> 00:12:19,990
that over the next year and and
do the forecast and the runners.

250
00:12:22,320 --> 00:12:24,980
So this is all a part of
our overall strategy.

251
00:12:24,980 --> 00:12:26,830
That's why it's in
the service strategy section.

252
00:12:26,830 --> 00:12:31,660
And it's really just one piece of a bigger
financial management policy that your

253
00:12:31,660 --> 00:12:33,490
whole company will have.

254
00:12:33,490 --> 00:12:34,610
ITIL doesn't address that.

255
00:12:34,610 --> 00:12:37,270
So you got this big financial policy.

256
00:12:37,270 --> 00:12:41,030
The IT financial management
needs to fall within that.

257
00:12:41,030 --> 00:12:43,920
And a lot of times they're
completely separate and

258
00:12:43,920 --> 00:12:46,660
we're just kind of keeping track of
it as its own independent process.

259
00:12:46,660 --> 00:12:49,130
But the money is part of
that bigger strategy.

260
00:12:49,130 --> 00:12:54,085
So it may or may not be a part of the
overall company's financial management.

261
00:12:54,085 --> 00:12:55,700
All right.

262
00:12:55,700 --> 00:12:57,340
That's about it for financial management.

263
00:12:57,340 --> 00:12:59,070
We don't need to dive
too much more into that.

264
00:12:59,070 --> 00:13:01,170
There is more that's available out there,
but

265
00:13:01,170 --> 00:13:03,690
for the ITIL foundations
that's all we need to know.

266
00:13:05,410 --> 00:13:08,350
All right, our next process
group is demand management.

267
00:13:08,350 --> 00:13:10,890
And this is the first topic that
we're going to cover that's not

268
00:13:10,890 --> 00:13:12,500
really on the exam.

269
00:13:12,500 --> 00:13:16,960
If you look at the ITIL foundation
outline that they make, the syllabus.

270
00:13:16,960 --> 00:13:19,900
There's some entities
to just skip over but

271
00:13:19,900 --> 00:13:23,920
I find that it's good to understand
what all's there just to be aware.

272
00:13:23,920 --> 00:13:26,980
So demand management is one of those,
this is a weird one.

273
00:13:28,210 --> 00:13:28,970
Because, and

274
00:13:28,970 --> 00:13:32,190
one of the main reasons I want to
cover it is people confuse this a lot.

275
00:13:32,190 --> 00:13:33,100
When we're talking about demand,

276
00:13:33,100 --> 00:13:34,930
we're really talking about like supply and
demand.

277
00:13:34,930 --> 00:13:35,840
Okay?

278
00:13:35,840 --> 00:13:41,720
If your customer really wants a service
from you, but you're too busy.

279
00:13:41,720 --> 00:13:45,700
You don't have the capabilities to
handle that, you can't meet the demand.

280
00:13:45,700 --> 00:13:46,220
Right?

281
00:13:46,220 --> 00:13:49,920
And so you've got customers who would
find value with your service, but

282
00:13:49,920 --> 00:13:51,280
you can't serve them.

283
00:13:51,280 --> 00:13:53,190
And now they're not finding value and
they're just going to go and

284
00:13:53,190 --> 00:13:54,320
find somebody else.

285
00:13:54,320 --> 00:13:56,560
So, you're hurting your company.

286
00:13:56,560 --> 00:13:59,670
Demand is something
that has to be managed.

287
00:13:59,670 --> 00:14:03,430
But when people hear about this,
they always mix it up.

288
00:14:03,430 --> 00:14:05,010
It's real easy to mix this up and

289
00:14:05,010 --> 00:14:08,560
fuse it with a similar topic
which is capacity management.

290
00:14:08,560 --> 00:14:10,870
And they're two different things,
all right?

291
00:14:10,870 --> 00:14:13,330
Let's talk about
the difference real quick.

292
00:14:13,330 --> 00:14:14,760
I don't know if I put this in my notes or
not.

293
00:14:14,760 --> 00:14:17,239
But it is important to
understand from the beginning.

294
00:14:18,320 --> 00:14:22,270
Let's use, what's big in IT lately,
the new iPhones.

295
00:14:22,270 --> 00:14:25,300
So depending on when you watch this show,
this might not be timely.

296
00:14:25,300 --> 00:14:29,640
But just last month, Apple launched
new iPhones, they do it every year.

297
00:14:29,640 --> 00:14:32,330
And so they launched the iPhone 6 and 6+.

298
00:14:32,330 --> 00:14:35,130
Well, you know people want those phones.

299
00:14:35,130 --> 00:14:40,440
People really want that phone and
they'll have lines out their store doors

300
00:14:40,440 --> 00:14:43,490
at 4 AM in the morning when the stores
open when they have a new phone available.

301
00:14:43,490 --> 00:14:45,380
>> And people will be crying
>> Yeah,

302
00:14:45,380 --> 00:14:46,410
they'll cry if they get it
>> Yeah

303
00:14:46,410 --> 00:14:48,330
>> Crying with happiness that people love

304
00:14:48,330 --> 00:14:49,870
their phones
>> [LAUGH]

305
00:14:49,870 --> 00:14:51,660
>> I'm not that passionate but

306
00:14:51,660 --> 00:14:53,060
apparently a lot of people are.

307
00:14:53,060 --> 00:14:57,190
So Apple has to do demand
management to handle that.

308
00:14:57,190 --> 00:15:02,440
Now, they could do capacity managing,
capacity just says hey we anticipate

309
00:15:02,440 --> 00:15:06,200
selling two million phones
in that first month, so

310
00:15:06,200 --> 00:15:10,730
let's ramp up our factories and let's get
two million phones manufactured, right?

311
00:15:10,730 --> 00:15:14,370
Now, if I have people that want 2 million
phones, I've got 2 million phones.

312
00:15:14,370 --> 00:15:16,600
I met the demand, and we're done, right?

313
00:15:16,600 --> 00:15:18,400
That's capability management.

314
00:15:18,400 --> 00:15:23,370
Do we have the capability of
meeting the demand as it is, okay?

315
00:15:23,370 --> 00:15:26,400
That's not what demand
management is all about.

316
00:15:26,400 --> 00:15:27,860
Capability management is kind of separate.

317
00:15:27,860 --> 00:15:30,270
And we don't really tackle that with ITIL.

318
00:15:30,270 --> 00:15:35,210
Instead, what we say is,
sometimes we can't meet the demand.

319
00:15:35,210 --> 00:15:36,980
We just can't do it, all right?

320
00:15:36,980 --> 00:15:38,920
And, so we've got to find someway,

321
00:15:38,920 --> 00:15:42,020
not to change our capability
because we can't do anything.

322
00:15:42,020 --> 00:15:44,410
But instead to change demand.

323
00:15:44,410 --> 00:15:45,030
All right.

324
00:15:45,030 --> 00:15:47,230
And there's several ways to handle that.

325
00:15:47,230 --> 00:15:48,650
And I've dealt with this personally.

326
00:15:48,650 --> 00:15:52,100
So I don't really do consulting anymore.

327
00:15:52,100 --> 00:15:54,010
I used to do a lot of consulting.

328
00:15:54,010 --> 00:15:58,460
I did teach classes and then sometimes
I'd go out to companies privately and

329
00:15:58,460 --> 00:15:59,330
help them out.

330
00:15:59,330 --> 00:16:01,440
I still help two companies now.

331
00:16:01,440 --> 00:16:04,200
But I got to the point where
I just didn't have time.

332
00:16:04,200 --> 00:16:06,512
There's not enough time in the day for
me to be able to support that.

333
00:16:06,512 --> 00:16:09,310
And I couldn't add more time in the day.

334
00:16:09,310 --> 00:16:12,886
I've got a wife and two kids and
I need to spend time with them.

335
00:16:12,886 --> 00:16:14,011
I just couldn't do it.

336
00:16:14,011 --> 00:16:19,200
So what I did is I didn't just tell
people, hey, I'm not doing it anymore.

337
00:16:19,200 --> 00:16:22,700
Instead, I increased my rate.

338
00:16:22,700 --> 00:16:27,250
I said, all right, instead of charging x
amount of dollars, I'll just double it.

339
00:16:27,250 --> 00:16:28,200
I'm gonna double that amount.

340
00:16:28,200 --> 00:16:30,860
Now most people are going to hear that and
say, I really need help, but

341
00:16:30,860 --> 00:16:32,300
I can't afford that.

342
00:16:32,300 --> 00:16:34,800
And they'll go somewhere else,
or if they say,

343
00:16:34,800 --> 00:16:37,430
I really need help and
I'm willing to pay that.

344
00:16:37,430 --> 00:16:38,480
Then I'll look at it and say, well,

345
00:16:38,480 --> 00:16:40,200
if you are willing to pay
that I'm willing to do it.

346
00:16:40,200 --> 00:16:42,920
There's a level that I'm willing to meet.

347
00:16:42,920 --> 00:16:45,790
And that didn't adjust my capability.

348
00:16:45,790 --> 00:16:48,670
I can't work any more or less.

349
00:16:48,670 --> 00:16:51,770
I still can still work
the same amount of time, but

350
00:16:51,770 --> 00:16:54,670
I get less demand because
it's a higher rate.

351
00:16:54,670 --> 00:16:57,220
And that's a technique that
a lot of companies use.

352
00:16:57,220 --> 00:16:58,700
It's demand management.

353
00:16:59,850 --> 00:17:02,750
Just separate those ideas in your mind.

354
00:17:02,750 --> 00:17:04,928
Capability, that comes down to logistics,
right?

355
00:17:04,928 --> 00:17:07,800
How many factories you have,
how many employees you have,

356
00:17:07,800 --> 00:17:11,545
all of that stuff, that's logistics and
we don't deal with that with ITIL.

357
00:17:11,545 --> 00:17:15,067
But, demand, that's something your
marketing team, your accounting team,

358
00:17:15,067 --> 00:17:17,204
these are all things that
people can influence.

359
00:17:17,204 --> 00:17:20,078
If there's not enough demand for
your product,

360
00:17:20,078 --> 00:17:24,298
maybe you've created something like,
well, like ITProTV, right?

361
00:17:24,298 --> 00:17:28,298
It's not like we have a tangible good,
so we don't have an inventory to track,

362
00:17:28,298 --> 00:17:29,145
we have videos.

363
00:17:29,145 --> 00:17:33,078
And we have enough bandwidth to
support millions of customers all at

364
00:17:33,078 --> 00:17:34,570
the same time.

365
00:17:34,570 --> 00:17:38,741
But we don't have millions of customers,
so we need to increase demand to make more

366
00:17:38,741 --> 00:17:41,680
customers, to fill up that
available space that we have.

367
00:17:41,680 --> 00:17:42,315
And then, hopefully,

368
00:17:42,315 --> 00:17:43,948
have the problem where we run
out of space, need to add more.

369
00:17:43,948 --> 00:17:47,152
So, in that scenario,
we want demand to go up.

370
00:17:47,152 --> 00:17:49,171
You may want it to go up or down, but

371
00:17:49,171 --> 00:17:51,904
that's what demand
management Is all about.

372
00:17:51,904 --> 00:17:55,455
Now the tools we use to do that,
there are several different ones.

373
00:17:55,455 --> 00:18:00,170
But one of the main things is we need to
take a look at our business patterns.

374
00:18:00,170 --> 00:18:02,620
Demand is a fickle thing,
it comes and goes.

375
00:18:02,620 --> 00:18:03,415
It might be seasonal.

376
00:18:03,415 --> 00:18:08,370
Right?
If you look at the the US Postal Service,

377
00:18:08,370 --> 00:18:12,410
or really any parcel service that's
out there, the holiday seasons,

378
00:18:12,410 --> 00:18:16,230
when it gets to be around Christmas time,
people ship a lot of packages.

379
00:18:16,230 --> 00:18:18,330
So they know that there
will be more demand for

380
00:18:18,330 --> 00:18:20,680
their service during the holidays.

381
00:18:20,680 --> 00:18:21,380
All right?

382
00:18:21,380 --> 00:18:24,050
And because they know
that they can predict it,

383
00:18:24,050 --> 00:18:26,310
then capability management
becomes practical, right?

384
00:18:26,310 --> 00:18:27,680
They can deal with that.

385
00:18:27,680 --> 00:18:30,990
But what if you're a website and
your site goes viral, right?

386
00:18:30,990 --> 00:18:32,860
Your videos get out there and
people are really hitting it and

387
00:18:32,860 --> 00:18:34,040
your run out of bandwidth.

388
00:18:34,040 --> 00:18:37,080
Well, you might not be in a position
where you can increase capability.

389
00:18:37,080 --> 00:18:40,110
And so that's where you have to
start kind of adjusting that demand,

390
00:18:40,110 --> 00:18:42,670
managing it, making the video protected,
make people have to pay for it,

391
00:18:42,670 --> 00:18:45,610
whatever, and now you start
controlling that access to get to it.

392
00:18:45,610 --> 00:18:49,180
This is all a tool of the trade,
all right?

393
00:18:49,180 --> 00:18:56,050
So that business patterns, ITIL calls that
a PBA, a pattern of business activity.

394
00:18:56,050 --> 00:18:59,950
And they're predictable, they're things
that we know that are going to happen.

395
00:18:59,950 --> 00:19:02,290
But keep in mind there's always
some things that are unpredictable.

396
00:19:02,290 --> 00:19:04,650
Sometimes stuff just happens randomly.

397
00:19:04,650 --> 00:19:09,560
You know, some celebrity on TV wears
the shoe that your company sells, and

398
00:19:09,560 --> 00:19:11,200
all of a sudden demand for it skyrockets.

399
00:19:11,200 --> 00:19:13,640
You didn't know it was gonna happen,
it happened incidentally.

400
00:19:13,640 --> 00:19:15,990
And now you're the bigwig, right?

401
00:19:15,990 --> 00:19:18,890
There was a story I read
years ago about Mountain Dew,

402
00:19:18,890 --> 00:19:22,240
where there was this report that said one
of the food colorings in Mountain Dew

403
00:19:22,240 --> 00:19:25,040
actually contained some kind of steroid.

404
00:19:25,040 --> 00:19:28,160
And there's different kinds of steroids,
but

405
00:19:28,160 --> 00:19:31,230
in most people's minds they think weight
builders, like oh, I'm gonna get strong.

406
00:19:31,230 --> 00:19:33,710
And sales for
Mountain Dew actually went up.

407
00:19:33,710 --> 00:19:37,130
And, the report was kind of a scathing,
negative report, but sales went up.

408
00:19:37,130 --> 00:19:40,780
And they didn't know that was
gonna happen it just happened and

409
00:19:40,780 --> 00:19:42,090
they have to manage that, right?

410
00:19:42,090 --> 00:19:45,910
So sometimes demand is unpredictable and
we don't get the PBA for that.

411
00:19:47,610 --> 00:19:51,960
All right, now when we come to managing
demand, where does demand come from?

412
00:19:51,960 --> 00:19:54,190
Well, it's always the result
of some activity.

413
00:19:54,190 --> 00:19:57,030
Some activity happens, and
usually we're the ones who take it.

414
00:19:57,030 --> 00:19:59,840
And it's either going to create
increased demand or decreased demand.

415
00:19:59,840 --> 00:20:03,311
So the outcome of an activity
is gonna manipulate that demand.

416
00:20:03,311 --> 00:20:07,316
And if I raise my price,
that's the activity I take.

417
00:20:07,316 --> 00:20:10,680
The outcome is that my service
is more expensive, and

418
00:20:10,680 --> 00:20:15,900
as a result less people will find
it valuable, reducing the demand.
