00:44:11,640 --> 00:44:13,850
And then if we fail to
live up to the SLAs.

874
00:44:13,850 --> 00:44:17,830
BRM is the one that is going to handle
the mediation to get us back in line.

875
00:44:17,830 --> 00:44:20,740
But there again, not actually going to
do the work to put us back in line,

876
00:44:20,740 --> 00:44:24,130
that's going to be the SLM side,
the service level management.

877
00:44:24,130 --> 00:44:27,270
You may find over time that
your SLAs need to change.

878
00:44:27,270 --> 00:44:29,770
That's another thing that
you've gotta evaluate.

879
00:44:29,770 --> 00:44:32,430
A customer may come to you with a set
of requirements that are valid for

880
00:44:32,430 --> 00:44:34,370
that point and time in their company.

881
00:44:34,370 --> 00:44:37,270
And so you create a service
that's of great value to them.

882
00:44:37,270 --> 00:44:42,300
But as the years go on, maybe
the company grows or their needs change.

883
00:44:42,300 --> 00:44:45,760
And while you provided great
value in the beginning

884
00:44:45,760 --> 00:44:48,940
now you're not quite
providing that same value.

885
00:44:48,940 --> 00:44:52,500
And so it does need to be reevaluated and
renegotiated.

886
00:44:52,500 --> 00:44:54,770
You're SLAs may need to change for a time.

887
00:44:54,770 --> 00:44:59,160
So maybe you've done business with
this customer for a long, long time.

888
00:44:59,160 --> 00:45:02,970
Back when dial up phone systems
were used and so you had

889
00:45:02,970 --> 00:45:07,020
an SLA that stated things like, you'll
have this amount of phone lines available.

890
00:45:07,020 --> 00:45:11,615
Well does that create any value today when
nobody uses dial up networking anymore,

891
00:45:11,615 --> 00:45:13,215
not on a regular basis?

892
00:45:13,215 --> 00:45:13,785
It doesn't.

893
00:45:13,785 --> 00:45:17,215
And so there's extra things in the SLA
that might be driving up costs,

894
00:45:17,215 --> 00:45:19,025
cuz you're maintaining those
lines that aren't needed anymore.

895
00:45:19,025 --> 00:45:21,965
And so that just needs to be revisited
with the customer each year.

896
00:45:21,965 --> 00:45:23,985
As you say, well,
let's take a look at these SLAs,

897
00:45:23,985 --> 00:45:26,490
and do you guys still need
these dial up lines anymore?

898
00:45:26,490 --> 00:45:30,700
If we remove that we can actually reduce
costs, which will create value for you.

899
00:45:30,700 --> 00:45:35,149
Or if you find it valuable to have those
lines in place as a backup connection or

900
00:45:35,149 --> 00:45:36,760
whatever we can keep them.

901
00:45:36,760 --> 00:45:38,470
It's what the customer needs,

902
00:45:38,470 --> 00:45:42,080
not necessarily what you can provide
that will keep that relationship tight.

903
00:45:43,620 --> 00:45:48,580
And that's really what the whole process
of business relationship management is.

904
00:45:50,120 --> 00:45:51,810
The key concept to remember, the phrase.

905
00:45:51,810 --> 00:45:53,180
If you just remember one phrase for

906
00:45:53,180 --> 00:45:56,860
the exam,
it's value creation through services.

907
00:45:56,860 --> 00:45:57,840
That's not something I'm making up,

908
00:45:57,840 --> 00:46:01,720
that's a quote straight from
the service strategy guide.

909
00:46:01,720 --> 00:46:03,730
Value creation through services.

910
00:46:03,730 --> 00:46:05,890
If your company doesn't
create any services,

911
00:46:05,890 --> 00:46:08,690
then you're not doing anything of
value that your customers'll want.

912
00:46:08,690 --> 00:46:10,675
There's nothing for them to buy.

913
00:46:10,675 --> 00:46:12,345
And if you do create services,

914
00:46:12,345 --> 00:46:15,185
you want them to be ones that
the customers actively want.

915
00:46:15,185 --> 00:46:18,365
That they're not just forced to
purchase for some various reason.

916
00:46:18,365 --> 00:46:21,645
So creating value by offering
the services the customer wants.

917
00:46:23,367 --> 00:46:26,107
Well Ronnie I think we've pretty much

918
00:46:26,107 --> 00:46:28,467
covered service strategy
as much as we need to.

919
00:46:28,467 --> 00:46:29,927
Can you think of anything
else to throw in?

920
00:46:29,927 --> 00:46:34,853
>> No just make sure you pay attention to
the phrases we specifically mentioned.

921
00:46:34,853 --> 00:46:37,363
Because a lot of it does have
to deal with terminology so

922
00:46:37,363 --> 00:46:41,053
we want to make sure that we learn that
but we want to keep a context too.

923
00:46:41,053 --> 00:46:46,543
Scenarios and context are very important
because that's what this is really about.

924
00:46:46,543 --> 00:46:49,661
Is the beginning of making sure
we understand strategy and

925
00:46:49,661 --> 00:46:52,980
how it plays into all the services
that we're gonna provide.

926
00:46:54,750 --> 00:46:57,040
>> All right, well ladies and
gentlemen this is a pretty good spot for

927
00:46:57,040 --> 00:46:58,180
us to wrap this one up.

928
00:46:58,180 --> 00:47:01,710
So let me just remind you guys if
you have questions on any of this,

929
00:47:01,710 --> 00:47:05,070
live during the show you
can go to itpro.tv/live.

930
00:47:05,070 --> 00:47:06,950
You'll see that chat
box beneath the video.

931
00:47:06,950 --> 00:47:10,380
You can post your question there,
we monitor and answer during the show.

932
00:47:10,380 --> 00:47:11,820
If you have questions after the show.

933
00:47:11,820 --> 00:47:15,030
like when we're showing reruns,
you can always go to the Q&A forums.

934
00:47:15,030 --> 00:47:18,305
Hit the link at the top of the page that
says Q&A, it'll take you right in there.

935
00:47:18,305 --> 00:47:20,885
Post your question and we monitor and
answer it after the show.

936
00:47:20,885 --> 00:47:22,575
Take advantage of those resources.

937
00:47:22,575 --> 00:47:23,825
They are there for you.

938
00:47:23,825 --> 00:47:26,675
I hope you guys enjoyed today's show.

939
00:47:26,675 --> 00:47:28,045
Signing off for ITProTV.

940
00:47:28,045 --> 00:47:28,715
I'm Don Pezet.

941
00:47:28,715 --> 00:47:29,755
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

942
00:47:29,755 --> 00:47:31,440
>> And we'll see you next time

943
00:47:31,440 --> 00:47:41,440
[MUSIC]

944
00:47:43,221 --> 00:47:49,220
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Service Design
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,459 --> 00:00:10,459
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:15,568 --> 00:00:23,125
[SOUND]

3
00:00:23,125 --> 00:00:33,771
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,771 --> 00:00:36,039
All right.
Good morning, good afternoon, and

5
00:00:36,039 --> 00:00:39,280
good evening and welcome back
to another episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:39,280 --> 00:00:41,720
I'm your host Don Pezet,
back again with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:41,720 --> 00:00:42,560
How's it going, Ronnie?

8
00:00:42,560 --> 00:00:44,290
>> It is going well today.

9
00:00:44,290 --> 00:00:49,240
I did not get yelled at by M&M on
the red carpet, so I'm pretty good.

10
00:00:49,240 --> 00:00:50,860
>> That is a common
occurrence around here.

11
00:00:50,860 --> 00:00:51,480
>> I know.
>> But we've

12
00:00:51,480 --> 00:00:52,228
managed to dodge it this time.

13
00:00:52,228 --> 00:00:53,780
>> That's right.

14
00:00:53,780 --> 00:00:58,320
>> [LAUGH] We're jumping back into
the wonderful world of ITIL and today,

15
00:00:58,320 --> 00:01:01,350
we're gonna be tackling
our second service area.

16
00:01:01,350 --> 00:01:04,130
We're actually diving into service design.

17
00:01:04,130 --> 00:01:07,420
So by this point you should of already
watched our material on service strategy

18
00:01:07,420 --> 00:01:11,620
as a company figures out what
services they want to implement to

19
00:01:11,620 --> 00:01:14,970
create their vision,
their overall goal for the company.

20
00:01:16,110 --> 00:01:19,550
Once you figured that out,
now you need to make that happen, and

21
00:01:19,550 --> 00:01:22,670
service design is the first
leg of that journey.

22
00:01:22,670 --> 00:01:26,182
That's where we start to evaluate
both the methods that we can use to

23
00:01:26,182 --> 00:01:29,757
create that service and ultimately
deliver it, but there's a lot of

24
00:01:29,757 --> 00:01:34,580
planning that goes into that process and
that's what falls under service design.

25
00:01:34,580 --> 00:01:38,690
>> Yeah, service design is really what
moves us from the strategy, in which we're

26
00:01:38,690 --> 00:01:42,150
just talking about what we really want
to accomplish as our overall goal and

27
00:01:42,150 --> 00:01:46,950
our mission,
to now putting those visions and

28
00:01:46,950 --> 00:01:51,240
those particular purposes with feet
on them and plans that we make.

29
00:01:51,240 --> 00:01:55,010
So we're moving from strategy to
planning now, and we're gonna make sure

30
00:01:55,010 --> 00:01:58,010
that we cover everything that
we need to in our design phase.

31
00:01:58,010 --> 00:01:59,840
So as we move further on,

32
00:01:59,840 --> 00:02:02,540
we're really not having to go
back to the drawing board again.

33
00:02:02,540 --> 00:02:04,410
So here's our drawing board.

34
00:02:04,410 --> 00:02:07,440
>> There's a saying that I have a lot,

35
00:02:07,440 --> 00:02:10,702
which is there is no
substitute to good planning.

36
00:02:10,702 --> 00:02:13,240
Now, I also have another saying-
>> [LAUGH]

37
00:02:13,240 --> 00:02:13,810
>> That I hope,

38
00:02:13,810 --> 00:02:17,400
I don't usually have to say which is,
let's chalk this one up to poor planning.

39
00:02:17,400 --> 00:02:22,510
I've said that one more than once too,
but basically, if you have a proper

40
00:02:22,510 --> 00:02:26,400
plan in place for an implementation,
then things should go nice and smoothly.

41
00:02:26,400 --> 00:02:29,930
If anything goes wrong,
you should already have your contingencies

42
00:02:29,930 --> 00:02:33,210
planned to be able to correct that and
get back in line.

43
00:02:33,210 --> 00:02:35,840
If you take the time
to do proper planning,

44
00:02:35,840 --> 00:02:38,470
you will increase your
odds of being successful.

45
00:02:38,470 --> 00:02:41,550
Now, you can overdo it and
that's where we have to be careful there,

46
00:02:41,550 --> 00:02:44,240
you can over plan and
you end up wasting time and

47
00:02:44,240 --> 00:02:47,650
resources on something that
should've already been done.

48
00:02:47,650 --> 00:02:50,350
I know, there have been some funny
comic strips about that over the years,

49
00:02:50,350 --> 00:02:55,090
but you can be paralyzed by fear,
and not move a project forward, and

50
00:02:55,090 --> 00:02:56,560
that can be very negative.

51
00:02:56,560 --> 00:02:58,460
So we've got to find that right balance,
and

52
00:02:58,460 --> 00:03:01,660
we'll talk a little bit about
that as this show goes on.

53
00:03:01,660 --> 00:03:06,140
One key thing that I wanna point out here,
is it's really easy in our minds

54
00:03:06,140 --> 00:03:10,160
to think of service design as
only designing new services.

55
00:03:10,160 --> 00:03:14,028
But we're gonna reach back to this a few
times, especially towards the end of

56
00:03:14,028 --> 00:03:17,659
the series when we get into continual
service improvement because CSI,

57
00:03:17,659 --> 00:03:21,710
Continual Service Improvement, is all
about looking at your existing services

58
00:03:21,710 --> 00:03:23,763
and saying, how do we make them better?

59
00:03:23,763 --> 00:03:25,070
How do we keep them relevant?

60
00:03:25,070 --> 00:03:28,480
How do we keep them producing value for
our customers?

61
00:03:28,480 --> 00:03:33,018
And the way you do that is typically
through change, and any time you implement

62
00:03:33,018 --> 00:03:37,110
a change to a service, you really
jump right back here to your design.

63
00:03:37,110 --> 00:03:39,809
And you say okay,
this is the change that we want to do,

64
00:03:39,809 --> 00:03:41,406
what's the best way to do that?

65
00:03:41,406 --> 00:03:43,200
And you put your plan together.

66
00:03:43,200 --> 00:03:47,380
So it's not just creating new services,
it's modifying the services that you have,

67
00:03:47,380 --> 00:03:52,070
and you even go one step further and
say, if it's time to retire a service,

68
00:03:52,070 --> 00:03:56,390
to take it out of production, you need
to go and do a design for that too.

69
00:03:56,390 --> 00:04:00,433
What's the best way to remove
this service from production and

70
00:04:00,433 --> 00:04:03,337
impact our customers
as little as possible?

71
00:04:03,337 --> 00:04:06,840
And some companies historically
have done a great job of that

72
00:04:06,840 --> 00:04:10,790
where a transition happens and
most of us don't even notice.

73
00:04:10,790 --> 00:04:15,380
Other companies have had some missteps and
a transition occurs and

74
00:04:15,380 --> 00:04:16,590
it's a big debacle.

75
00:04:18,130 --> 00:04:22,442
So some examples of that would be
like here in the United States with

76
00:04:22,442 --> 00:04:23,910
the HDTV switch over.

77
00:04:25,010 --> 00:04:27,940
We had analog TV for
a long time, for years and

78
00:04:27,940 --> 00:04:30,750
years, and
they wanted to switch over to digital TV.

79
00:04:30,750 --> 00:04:36,290
So for a period of like two years, they
did all sorts of public announcements and

80
00:04:36,290 --> 00:04:38,480
warnings, they even sent
letters in the mail.

81
00:04:38,480 --> 00:04:41,990
They made these little converter box
available to people that requested them.

82
00:04:41,990 --> 00:04:43,240
They took all these steps and

83
00:04:43,240 --> 00:04:47,740
when the cut over finally happened,
most people weren't affected at all.

84
00:04:47,740 --> 00:04:50,720
Worst case scenario, you had some
really old TVs that no longer work, but

85
00:04:50,720 --> 00:04:52,510
it was a nice, smooth transition.

86
00:04:52,510 --> 00:04:54,420
They did a good design for

87
00:04:54,420 --> 00:04:58,750
how to implement that new service,
it was done very smoothly.

88
00:04:58,750 --> 00:05:03,590
Other examples, though, might be like
Apple, when Apple rolled out their new

89
00:05:03,590 --> 00:05:07,440
Apple Maps program,
people were up and arms about this.

90
00:05:07,440 --> 00:05:10,570
Prior to that you had
Google Maps on an iPhone or

91
00:05:10,570 --> 00:05:15,330
iPad, and Apple decided to switch
out to their own mapping system,

92
00:05:15,330 --> 00:05:19,900
introducing a new service and
phasing out the old, retiring Google Maps.

93
00:05:19,900 --> 00:05:24,110
When they did that, their new
service wasn't at feature parody,

94
00:05:24,110 --> 00:05:27,320
it didn't offer the same
features as what Google Maps had.

95
00:05:27,320 --> 00:05:31,770
So most of the users viewed
that as a step backwards.

96
00:05:31,770 --> 00:05:33,880
And so that impacted the customers.

97
00:05:33,880 --> 00:05:36,690
So retiring a service
requires good design.

98
00:05:36,690 --> 00:05:38,550
You've gotta make sure we take that step.

99
00:05:38,550 --> 00:05:41,360
A lot of people don't pay attention to
that and they say, that service is done,

100
00:05:41,360 --> 00:05:42,370
let's just go flip the switch.

101
00:05:43,620 --> 00:05:49,137
Then you end up in a situation that
is really gonna create negative PR,

102
00:05:49,137 --> 00:05:51,768
and potentially reduce income.

103
00:05:51,768 --> 00:05:55,714
>> Yeah, so when we take a look then,
at designing new processes, and

104
00:05:55,714 --> 00:05:59,940
then having to make changes to
the processes that we're already doing or

105
00:05:59,940 --> 00:06:03,650
the services that we're providing and
also retiring it.

106
00:06:03,650 --> 00:06:06,590
Don, it sounds a lot like project
management at this point.

107
00:06:06,590 --> 00:06:10,460
When we start with the initiation,
and then the execution and

108
00:06:10,460 --> 00:06:14,180
the monitoring and then moving into
closing phases sounds very similar.

109
00:06:14,180 --> 00:06:15,035
>> It really does and

110
00:06:15,035 --> 00:06:19,830
ITIL as a whole, does match up in
a lot of ways with project management.

111
00:06:19,830 --> 00:06:22,980
So this area particularly, service design,

112
00:06:22,980 --> 00:06:28,406
it really is probably the most closely
aligned phase with project management.

113
00:06:28,406 --> 00:06:32,933
And what you have to remember is that
what project management does, let's say,

114
00:06:32,933 --> 00:06:37,795
you follow the PMI's PMBOK, and that's the
way that you do your project management or

115
00:06:37,795 --> 00:06:42,570
you follow any of the various other
project methodologies that are out there.

116
00:06:42,570 --> 00:06:49,480
That when you follow those it is
designed to help you take a simple,

117
00:06:49,480 --> 00:06:55,950
short term activity and take it from start
to completion within a certain budget,

118
00:06:55,950 --> 00:07:00,010
within a certain time frame,
within a certain amount of

119
00:07:00,010 --> 00:07:04,800
requirements that you have to meet, and
those are all just temporary endeavors.

120
00:07:04,800 --> 00:07:07,610
So project management doesn't account for
our day to day,

121
00:07:07,610 --> 00:07:10,750
our ongoing activities,
it doesn't handle that.

122
00:07:10,750 --> 00:07:12,090
ITIL does both.

123
00:07:12,090 --> 00:07:17,420
ITIL covers your ongoing, your day to
day activities, that are not projects,

124
00:07:17,420 --> 00:07:20,980
but it provides some of the framework for
project management.

125
00:07:20,980 --> 00:07:22,996
But it leaves a lot of this open-ended,

126
00:07:22,996 --> 00:07:26,920
and the reason it does that is because
they want you to be able to pick

127
00:07:26,920 --> 00:07:31,850
whatever project management methodology
you want and snap it on top of ITIL.

128
00:07:31,850 --> 00:07:36,865
So you may use ITIL for your service
management, your overall service

129
00:07:36,865 --> 00:07:42,560
management, but then you use the PMI for
your project management or PRINCE2 or

130
00:07:42,560 --> 00:07:47,673
one of the other project management
methodologies that are out there.

131
00:07:47,673 --> 00:07:50,185
You just choose which one is appropriate
for your organization and you snap it on.

132
00:07:50,185 --> 00:07:51,714
So as we go through design,

133
00:07:51,714 --> 00:07:55,835
this really does match up with
the planning phase in project management,

134
00:07:55,835 --> 00:08:00,086
and if you're a project manager,
just- Try and align that you might have,

135
00:08:00,086 --> 00:08:04,600
how does my project management methodology
match up with the design here.

136
00:08:04,600 --> 00:08:07,900
And we'll see we've got eight different
processes we're gonna tackle, and each

137
00:08:07,900 --> 00:08:10,720
one does match up with a lot of the stuff
that we do inside of project management.

138
00:08:12,468 --> 00:08:18,070
All right, so all of this integrates
just into our overall change process.

139
00:08:18,070 --> 00:08:20,690
Any time you introduce a new service,
it's a change.

140
00:08:20,690 --> 00:08:23,008
Any time you modify an existing service,
that's a change.

141
00:08:23,008 --> 00:08:25,922
Any time you remove a service,
that's a change.

142
00:08:25,922 --> 00:08:31,170
And so any time you make a change,
we go into service design, all right.

143
00:08:31,170 --> 00:08:35,764
And we have like five steps that we
move through when implementing change

144
00:08:35,764 --> 00:08:39,831
in a business, and
ITIL calls these out specifically, right,

145
00:08:39,831 --> 00:08:43,400
we start with the business process change.

146
00:08:43,400 --> 00:08:44,840
Right, so we identify a change.

147
00:08:44,840 --> 00:08:48,030
There's a process that we have in place,
or a process that we need,

148
00:08:48,030 --> 00:08:51,040
and we're going to do
a change to fix that, right.

149
00:08:51,040 --> 00:08:55,310
So step two,
we figure out what our requirements are.

150
00:08:55,310 --> 00:08:57,440
I know I've mentioned
that in other episodes.

151
00:08:57,440 --> 00:09:00,290
Understanding your requirements
is really important.

152
00:09:00,290 --> 00:09:02,090
If you don't know what
you need to achieve,

153
00:09:02,090 --> 00:09:06,470
if you don't know it specifically
with unambiguous terms,

154
00:09:06,470 --> 00:09:10,430
then our two main problems are gonna
be one, how do we know we're done?

when that happens it becomes an agreement.

00:45:02,561 --> 00:45:05,507
But if it's non negotiable,
it stays a requirement.

833
00:45:05,507 --> 00:45:11,470
And you'll see, I think I gave
the example of the bank didn't I?

834
00:45:11,470 --> 00:45:14,460
I worked for a bank and
we were FDIC insured.

835
00:45:14,460 --> 00:45:18,305
So here in the US, the FDIC is a part
of the Department of Treasury and

836
00:45:18,305 --> 00:45:19,680
they insure banks.

837
00:45:19,680 --> 00:45:24,020
So if a bank ever goes bankrupt then

838
00:45:24,020 --> 00:45:26,560
anybody who had deposits in that bank,
they're insured.

839
00:45:26,560 --> 00:45:28,673
They can get their money from
the government because the bank

840
00:45:28,673 --> 00:45:29,635
doesn't have it anymore.

841
00:45:29,635 --> 00:45:31,200
Right, so it's insurance.

842
00:45:31,200 --> 00:45:33,380
So we were FDIC insured, and

843
00:45:33,380 --> 00:45:37,270
the FDIC had service level
requirements that we had to meet.

844
00:45:37,270 --> 00:45:42,360
If we ever had a data failure in our bank
we had to have our systems back up in

845
00:45:42,360 --> 00:45:47,670
operational to where people can withdraw
money within 72 hours, so we had 3 days.

846
00:45:47,670 --> 00:45:49,950
We had to be back online.

847
00:45:49,950 --> 00:45:52,800
If we weren't,
then they would take over the bank.

848
00:45:52,800 --> 00:45:54,430
We'd lose control of the service.

849
00:45:54,430 --> 00:45:58,700
So that was a requirement,
nonnegotiable, we had to meet that.

850
00:45:58,700 --> 00:46:04,410
And so every service that we ever offered,
if it impacted the customer's ability

851
00:46:04,410 --> 00:46:09,920
to be able to withdraw funds, we had to
build in a three day recovery period.

852
00:46:09,920 --> 00:46:13,115
That if anything failed, we had to be
able to recover it within three days.

853
00:46:13,115 --> 00:46:15,135
If we couldn't,
then we couldn't offer that service,

854
00:46:15,135 --> 00:46:16,625
so that was really important.

855
00:46:16,625 --> 00:46:18,815
That impacted a lot of what we did,

856
00:46:18,815 --> 00:46:22,275
so service level management is where we
step in and we identify these things.

857
00:46:22,275 --> 00:46:24,575
So, they're super important, all right?

858
00:46:24,575 --> 00:46:26,015
With service level agreements,

859
00:46:26,015 --> 00:46:30,285
this is determining the agreement,
negotiating the agreement,

860
00:46:30,285 --> 00:46:33,960
getting it in place, monitoring it,
and making sure that we live up to it.

861
00:46:33,960 --> 00:46:34,500
Right?

862
00:46:34,500 --> 00:46:37,870
With a service level requirement, we get
the requirement from the customer, and

863
00:46:37,870 --> 00:46:40,670
if it's negotiable,
we're converting it over to an SLA.

864
00:46:40,670 --> 00:46:43,500
If its not,
then we leave it as that requirement, and

865
00:46:43,500 --> 00:46:45,110
we go through and handle that.

866
00:46:45,110 --> 00:46:48,690
And the activities that ITIL calls out,
there's define,

867
00:46:48,690 --> 00:46:51,990
right, that's when we
figure out what it is.

868
00:46:51,990 --> 00:46:53,930
Document, we write it down.

869
00:46:54,970 --> 00:46:57,620
You'd think you wouldn't have to
put this stuff down, but you do.

870
00:46:57,620 --> 00:46:59,710
How do you know what to live up to?

871
00:46:59,710 --> 00:47:01,770
You hire a new employee,
how do they learn about it?

872
00:47:01,770 --> 00:47:03,120
You got to document.

873
00:47:03,120 --> 00:47:05,130
>> We also talk about agreement.

874
00:47:05,130 --> 00:47:08,560
Ensuring both sides are actually
saying this is what's gonna be done,

875
00:47:08,560 --> 00:47:10,140
that makes sense.

876
00:47:10,140 --> 00:47:11,488
>> Let me add one thing to agree.

877
00:47:11,488 --> 00:47:14,100
Right, so you hit the main part, right.

878
00:47:14,100 --> 00:47:16,080
But there's one extra one that
might show up on the exam.

879
00:47:16,080 --> 00:47:19,240
So you've got to be in agreement
with the customers needs, right.

880
00:47:19,240 --> 00:47:23,830
Whatever SLA you create or whatever
has to agree with their requirements.

881
00:47:23,830 --> 00:47:26,900
But it also has to agree
with your business strategy.

882
00:47:26,900 --> 00:47:29,430
We've used the term alignment a lot.

883
00:47:29,430 --> 00:47:31,610
I don't think we've used
the term agree yet,

884
00:47:31,610 --> 00:47:33,630
so this might be the first
time we've seen that.

885
00:47:33,630 --> 00:47:38,860
ITIL uses that word, agree,
in a lot of points to reference aligning.

886
00:47:38,860 --> 00:47:43,191
Do these SLAAs and SLRs, do they agree
with what our overall strategy is for

887
00:47:43,191 --> 00:47:45,800
our company, our company's goals?

888
00:47:45,800 --> 00:47:48,310
This might not be something
we wanna get involved in,

889
00:47:48,310 --> 00:47:52,400
because it puts undue burden on our
company and doesn't really live up, so

890
00:47:52,400 --> 00:47:55,410
we might wanna pass on that business
if that's the case, all right?

891
00:47:55,410 --> 00:47:58,770
Hopefully we can reach that agreement with
the customer, and that's the main part,

892
00:47:58,770 --> 00:47:59,710
what Ronnie said.

893
00:47:59,710 --> 00:48:02,780
But just be aware of that other one, there
is a time where you fail to agree, and

894
00:48:02,780 --> 00:48:07,420
that's just as important as
when you succeed to agree.

895
00:48:07,420 --> 00:48:08,562
Oh, the next one's the most
common sense one, right?

896
00:48:08,562 --> 00:48:09,729
Monitoring.
>> Yep.

897
00:48:09,729 --> 00:48:12,791
Yeah, monitoring of course is making
sure that all the things that

898
00:48:12,791 --> 00:48:16,959
we agreed to That we're tracking and that
we're maintaining everything that's there.

899
00:48:16,959 --> 00:48:21,240
And then, along with that of course,
naturally follows measuring.

900
00:48:21,240 --> 00:48:25,090
Verifying that it's there, that we
actually have metrics that we put in place

901
00:48:25,090 --> 00:48:28,390
that we know that we're hitting
those benchmarks that we need to.

902
00:48:28,390 --> 00:48:31,230
>> And that seems confusing that
we have monitor and measure,

903
00:48:31,230 --> 00:48:32,280
aren't those the same?

904
00:48:32,280 --> 00:48:34,580
Well, monitoring is just collecting data.

905
00:48:34,580 --> 00:48:37,180
Measuring is actually evaluating the data,
right?

906
00:48:37,180 --> 00:48:40,230
So they kind of work hand in hand,
we usually do them together but

907
00:48:40,230 --> 00:48:41,757
they are separate activities.

908
00:48:41,757 --> 00:48:44,336
Reports, that's where we take the data and

909
00:48:44,336 --> 00:48:48,560
we convert it into a form that our
people can actually interpret.

910
00:48:48,560 --> 00:48:51,730
If we're monitoring things like
server performance reports,

911
00:48:51,730 --> 00:48:55,100
we might have huge
spreadsheets that dictate,

912
00:48:55,100 --> 00:48:59,700
how many users were on the server
every one minute for hours on end?

913
00:48:59,700 --> 00:49:01,860
And how much CPU utilization there was?

914
00:49:01,860 --> 00:49:03,520
And how much RAM utilization?

915
00:49:03,520 --> 00:49:05,860
But at the end of the day,
people don't want to see all of that.

916
00:49:05,860 --> 00:49:09,149
So we might just summarize
it all into an average.

917
00:49:09,149 --> 00:49:11,382
And so here's our report that says hey,

918
00:49:11,382 --> 00:49:14,731
on average we had 300 people
on the site at any given time,

919
00:49:14,731 --> 00:49:19,520
and on average, our server farm was
operating at about 20% utilization.

920
00:49:19,520 --> 00:49:23,460
So those are numbers that people can grasp
a lot easier than a massive spreadsheet.

921
00:49:23,460 --> 00:49:25,284
So the reporting piece is important.

922
00:49:25,284 --> 00:49:30,160
Now, when you agree,
when you sign up for these SLAs or SLRs.

923
00:49:30,160 --> 00:49:32,660
You'll normally also agree
on that reporting plan.

924
00:49:32,660 --> 00:49:34,760
How often do you report
the information back?

925
00:49:34,760 --> 00:49:36,190
And I know, I have had to set these up for

926
00:49:36,190 --> 00:49:38,420
a number of companies to
where it was automated.

927
00:49:38,420 --> 00:49:42,580
So that you could verify the SLAs
were being met by simple reports, and

928
00:49:42,580 --> 00:49:47,750
if they weren't, then you'd kick
into the punitive charges or

929
00:49:47,750 --> 00:49:50,480
whatever it was that you did
when you violated an SLA.

930
00:49:51,850 --> 00:49:55,530
>> Our last activity is
the process of reviewing, too.

931
00:49:55,530 --> 00:49:59,105
We've got to remember that because
time and functionality and

932
00:49:59,105 --> 00:50:02,748
resources also change,
that what could end up happening is that

933
00:50:02,748 --> 00:50:06,726
the service level agreement no longer
meets the needs of the company,

934
00:50:06,726 --> 00:50:09,711
requirements from
the government may also change.

935
00:50:09,711 --> 00:50:13,778
So the last step here is review, which
means that we wanna make sure that we go

936
00:50:13,778 --> 00:50:18,102
over this with the customer, as well as
within our own internal company strategy

937
00:50:18,102 --> 00:50:22,299
to make sure that we're actually meeting
the service level agreement each and

938
00:50:22,299 --> 00:50:26,260
every time, and that we're actually
up to whatever we need to be.

939
00:50:26,260 --> 00:50:26,880
>> Yeah.

940
00:50:26,880 --> 00:50:28,230
And things change.

941
00:50:28,230 --> 00:50:32,130
You might wanna change that agreement,
and it could come from the customer.

942
00:50:32,130 --> 00:50:34,740
It could come from you internally.

943
00:50:34,740 --> 00:50:35,820
It could come from the government.

944
00:50:35,820 --> 00:50:37,650
There's things that can modify that.

945
00:50:37,650 --> 00:50:40,780
So while they're really important,
and we kind of treat them as set and

946
00:50:40,780 --> 00:50:42,220
stone, we may need to modify those.

947
00:50:42,220 --> 00:50:46,220
So you gotta keep that as an open minded
and if you repeatedly fail an SLA,

948
00:50:46,220 --> 00:50:48,070
you need to evaluate why.

949
00:50:48,070 --> 00:50:50,748
So that's important.

950
00:50:50,748 --> 00:50:54,417
The other thing is if you're reviewing
your information, you can do trending, and

951
00:50:54,417 --> 00:50:55,550
that's kind of handy.

952
00:50:55,550 --> 00:50:58,190
I know a great example of that.

953
00:50:58,190 --> 00:51:02,150
We always had an SLA that would define,
how long our backups could take?

954
00:51:02,150 --> 00:51:04,082
And so we would say that at night,

955
00:51:04,082 --> 00:51:08,786
we could do backups in our non-peak time
which was really like midnight to 4 AM.

956
00:51:08,786 --> 00:51:12,470
And so our backups needed to
complete in that four hour window.

957
00:51:12,470 --> 00:51:13,910
So we would do reporting on that, and

958
00:51:13,910 --> 00:51:18,380
I can see that last week, maybe
the backups only took an hour and a half.

959
00:51:18,380 --> 00:51:19,850
Great.
I'm well within the SLA.

960
00:51:19,850 --> 00:51:23,670
I meet that amount of time, but if I look
at the historical data I can go back.

961
00:51:23,670 --> 00:51:28,630
And I can see where maybe it took
an hour and a half two months ago, or

962
00:51:28,630 --> 00:51:31,480
let's say five months ago,
it took an hour and a half.

963
00:51:31,480 --> 00:51:34,750
And then, four months ago,
it took two hours.

964
00:51:34,750 --> 00:51:37,390
And three months ago,
it took two and a half hours.

965
00:51:37,390 --> 00:51:39,750
And two months ago, it took three hours.

966
00:51:39,750 --> 00:51:41,110
It's getting bigger each time.

967
00:51:41,110 --> 00:51:45,757
And if I see that trend, I can follow
that trend out into the future.

968
00:51:45,757 --> 00:51:49,370
And I can say well, that was a month ago,
how about a month from now?

969
00:51:49,370 --> 00:51:51,130
If we follow this trend,
where are we gonna be?

970
00:51:51,130 --> 00:51:54,180
And you can predict when
you're gonna violate the SLA.

971
00:51:55,180 --> 00:51:57,460
That's one of the real
values of that review side,

972
00:51:57,460 --> 00:52:01,820
and the reporting side, is that we can
predict when we're gonna violate the SLA.

973
00:52:01,820 --> 00:52:05,870
And we can take steps now to
prevent it from happening.

974
00:52:05,870 --> 00:52:08,340
Maybe I need to add more back up servers,
add more band width.

975
00:52:08,340 --> 00:52:12,290
Maybe I need to clear out some archive
data to make the backup smaller,

976
00:52:12,290 --> 00:52:15,800
whatever it is,
I need to do to get back in line so

977
00:52:15,800 --> 00:52:19,690
that my trend is not going up,
but back down.

978
00:52:19,690 --> 00:52:23,480
Or I buy time to extend it another year,
until we figure something else out.

979
00:52:23,480 --> 00:52:26,790
So you want to predict the future,
and this is the way you do it.

980
00:52:29,440 --> 00:52:31,840
Well, we've covered quite
a bit in this show and

981
00:52:31,840 --> 00:52:36,250
I think this is probably a good spot for
us to stop and wrap this one up.

982
00:52:36,250 --> 00:52:39,010
So let's just kind of
recap what all we hit.

983
00:52:39,010 --> 00:52:42,500
We kicked off the show just with our
general description of service design.

984
00:52:42,500 --> 00:52:45,760
So what is service design and
what do we hope to achieve?

985
00:52:45,760 --> 00:52:49,740
And then, there is the eight processes,
and we've tackled the first three.

986
00:52:49,740 --> 00:52:54,110
Design coordination, which is all part
of creating that original plan for

987
00:52:54,110 --> 00:52:56,130
how we are going to implement the service.

988
00:52:56,130 --> 00:52:58,320
We did service catalog management.

989
00:52:58,320 --> 00:53:00,980
As we create that catalog that
indexes all of the different

990
00:53:00,980 --> 00:53:04,440
services that we've offered through
the life cycle of the company.

991
00:53:04,440 --> 00:53:07,270
And then lastly,
we talked about service level management.

992
00:53:07,270 --> 00:53:10,380
And the creation of those SLA's and SLR's.

993
00:53:10,380 --> 00:53:16,379
How we create them, monitor them, live up
to them, and take action based on them?

994
00:53:16,379 --> 00:53:22,079
But we still have five more processes.

995
00:53:22,079 --> 00:53:25,275
So make sure you tune in for
part two of service design,

996
00:53:25,275 --> 00:53:27,230
which is gonna be coming up next.

997
00:53:27,230 --> 00:53:28,310
But for right now,

998
00:53:28,310 --> 00:53:32,670
if you have questions on anything that
we have covered, make sure you ask.

999
00:53:32,670 --> 00:53:36,082
Live during the show you
can go to itpro.tv/live.

1000
00:53:36,082 --> 00:53:38,740
You'll see the chat box
right beneath the video.

1001
00:53:38,740 --> 00:53:39,440
Jump on in there.

1002
00:53:39,440 --> 00:53:40,090
Post your questions.

1003
00:53:40,090 --> 00:53:42,470
We monitor and answer during the show.

1004
00:53:42,470 --> 00:53:44,160
And sometimes we ask questions.

1005
00:53:44,160 --> 00:53:44,743
The chat room-

1006
00:53:44,743 --> 00:53:45,410
>> [LAUGH]
>> Helps us.

1007
00:53:45,410 --> 00:53:49,861
So thanks again, David for
our accounting term of the day.

1008
00:53:49,861 --> 00:53:51,710
If you have questions after the show.

1009
00:53:51,710 --> 00:53:55,490
If you're watching this recorded,
then use our Q and A forums.

1010
00:53:55,490 --> 00:53:57,740
At the top of every page
on the ITProTV site,

1011
00:53:57,740 --> 00:53:59,860
you'll see that link that says Q and A.

1012
00:53:59,860 --> 00:54:00,560
Click it.

1013
00:54:00,560 --> 00:54:03,350
It'll take you in to our forums,
you can post your questions there, and

1014
00:54:03,350 --> 00:54:05,210
we monitor and answer after the show.

1015
00:54:05,210 --> 00:54:07,650
We want to make sure you guys get
answers to your questions, so

1016
00:54:07,650 --> 00:54:10,610
you're not scratching your head and
trying to figure out what something means?

1017
00:54:10,610 --> 00:54:11,337
We're a resource.

1018
00:54:11,337 --> 00:54:11,865
Use us.

1019
00:54:11,865 --> 00:54:13,630
That's what we're here for.

1020
00:54:13,630 --> 00:54:15,610
All right,
well I hope you guys enjoyed the show.

1021
00:54:15,610 --> 00:54:18,040
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

1022
00:54:18,040 --> 00:54:18,689
>> I'm Ronnie Wong.

1023
00:54:18,689 --> 00:54:20,248
>> And we will see you next time.

00:54:31,966 --> 00:54:38,242

1

2
00:00:33,086 --> 00:00:35,990
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening.

3
00:00:35,990 --> 00:00:38,090
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:38,090 --> 00:00:41,130
I'm your host, Don Pezet,
back again with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

5
00:00:41,130 --> 00:00:41,870
How's it going, Ronnie?

6
00:00:41,870 --> 00:00:43,080
>> It is going well.

7
00:00:43,080 --> 00:00:46,910
I'm going to take my camera tonight, go to
some old dusty jail, and just turn off all

8
00:00:46,910 --> 00:00:51,370
the lights, and use the infrared light so
I can just walk around and see stuff.

9
00:00:51,370 --> 00:00:53,240
>> Yeah, see stuff, like walls.

10
00:00:53,240 --> 00:00:53,900
>> Walls.

11
00:00:53,900 --> 00:00:55,954
>> Exciting.
[LAUGH] So

12
00:00:55,954 --> 00:00:59,500
we don't have any paranormal
activity tonight.

13
00:00:59,500 --> 00:01:02,086
But we do have more ITIL to jump into.

14
00:01:02,086 --> 00:01:05,160
So that's what we're gonna be doing,
is getting back into ITIL foundation.

15
00:01:05,160 --> 00:01:06,580
We're reaching out and

16
00:01:06,580 --> 00:01:11,490
picking up where we left off on the
service design side of the ITIL framework.

17
00:01:11,490 --> 00:01:14,630
And in the first episode, in part one,

18
00:01:14,630 --> 00:01:18,490
we tackled what service design was and
some of the initial processes.

19
00:01:18,490 --> 00:01:20,110
And so
we're just gonna jump right back in and

20
00:01:20,110 --> 00:01:22,420
pick up with the next process in our list.

21
00:01:22,420 --> 00:01:25,980
And that next process is
availability management.

22
00:01:25,980 --> 00:01:28,380
Now I wanna address one thing
before we dive right into that.

23
00:01:28,380 --> 00:01:30,790
There's something that's
really easy to confuse here.

24
00:01:30,790 --> 00:01:33,970
We're gonna talk about availability, and

25
00:01:33,970 --> 00:01:38,760
later we're gonna talk about continuity,
and those are easy terms to confuse.

26
00:01:38,760 --> 00:01:42,530
So when we talk about availability,
what we're saying is,

27
00:01:42,530 --> 00:01:47,330
what can we do to prevent
failures from happening?

28
00:01:47,330 --> 00:01:51,890
So if something goes wrong and our network
is completely insulated and our users,

29
00:01:51,890 --> 00:01:54,680
our customers never even experience it.

30
00:01:54,680 --> 00:01:57,340
Availability is all about
preventing failure.

31
00:01:58,470 --> 00:02:02,800
Continuity, on the other hand,
the failure has happened.

32
00:02:02,800 --> 00:02:05,270
Our customer is impacted.

33
00:02:05,270 --> 00:02:08,570
What steps do we take to
continue doing business,

34
00:02:08,570 --> 00:02:13,020
to stay operational even
though the failure occurred?

35
00:02:13,020 --> 00:02:14,980
The two go hand in hand, right?

36
00:02:14,980 --> 00:02:17,390
You don't normally just plan for
one and not the other,

37
00:02:17,390 --> 00:02:20,430
because you can never truly
prevent all failures.

38
00:02:20,430 --> 00:02:24,220
So there's no perfect availability
solution that's out there.

39
00:02:24,220 --> 00:02:29,540
So availability is being proactive,
steps we take before a failure.

40
00:02:30,870 --> 00:02:37,020
Continuity is being reactive, steps we
take afterwards to react to a failure.

41
00:02:37,020 --> 00:02:38,490
So they're different ideas.

42
00:02:38,490 --> 00:02:40,380
Make sure you don't
confuse them in your head.

43
00:02:40,380 --> 00:02:42,290
You know, the test questions
are straightforward, but

44
00:02:42,290 --> 00:02:45,930
if you mix up the terms, then you can
choose the wrong answer because of that.

45
00:02:45,930 --> 00:02:49,813
So these are easy to confuse, and
different vendors out there use these

46
00:02:49,813 --> 00:02:52,545
terms almost interchangeably,
and I hate that.

47
00:02:52,545 --> 00:02:56,320
In ITIL they're very specific about that.

48
00:02:56,320 --> 00:02:58,830
>> Availability management, when we begin.

49
00:02:58,830 --> 00:03:03,350
We've talked in another episode
about service and about warranty.

50
00:03:03,350 --> 00:03:06,230
Remember that service is the value
that we're trying to deliver.

51
00:03:06,230 --> 00:03:10,830
Warranty is the fit for use, making
sure that things are actually working.

52
00:03:10,830 --> 00:03:14,910
And availability really falls more
underneath that category of warranty than

53
00:03:14,910 --> 00:03:17,200
it does just about the service itself.

54
00:03:17,200 --> 00:03:19,210
So I want to make sure
we emphasize that too.

55
00:03:19,210 --> 00:03:22,630
>> Yeah, you know, when a customer
approaches us and we decide to offer a new

56
00:03:22,630 --> 00:03:26,640
service for them, or if we create
a service based on market demand,

57
00:03:26,640 --> 00:03:31,050
when our customers come in they have
an expectation of the service working.

58
00:03:31,050 --> 00:03:35,820
If I am a bank and I start to offer
web-based mortgage payments, so

59
00:03:35,820 --> 00:03:39,250
you can log in, check your account, and
pay your mortgage, the customer is going

60
00:03:39,250 --> 00:03:43,310
to expect each month to be able
to log in and pay their mortgage.

61
00:03:43,310 --> 00:03:45,080
It's a basic expectation.

62
00:03:45,080 --> 00:03:48,000
And if they come and
the website is not available, or

63
00:03:48,000 --> 00:03:51,060
they can't log in to their account and
they try and call the help desk and

64
00:03:51,060 --> 00:03:55,125
the help desk is not available, then
they're not getting the functionality.

65
00:03:55,125 --> 00:03:58,450
We created it, and it may have worked
at some point, but it's not working for

66
00:03:58,450 --> 00:03:59,460
them right now.

67
00:03:59,460 --> 00:04:02,550
So our product may not actually be fit for
use.

68
00:04:02,550 --> 00:04:05,041
It may not meet the requirements
of the customer or

69
00:04:05,041 --> 00:04:08,250
it may not just be available
when the customer wants it.

70
00:04:08,250 --> 00:04:12,000
So are there steps that we could
have taken to handle that?

71
00:04:12,000 --> 00:04:15,790
And the answer is yes,
in the design phase.

72
00:04:15,790 --> 00:04:19,890
When we're creating this new service,
when we're designing the plan for how this

73
00:04:19,890 --> 00:04:24,490
service is going to be implemented, we
need to come up with an availability plan.

74
00:04:24,490 --> 00:04:28,128
And it's gonna define exactly what
we're going to try and achieve.

75
00:04:28,128 --> 00:04:33,240
Now you can't really do this
until you have your SLAs.

76
00:04:33,240 --> 00:04:35,772
What service lever are you trying achieve?

77
00:04:35,772 --> 00:04:39,660
What would count as fit for use?

78
00:04:39,660 --> 00:04:43,840
So if,
I think I used a hammer example before,

79
00:04:43,840 --> 00:04:48,250
if our service is gonna be
manufacturing hammers, how many

80
00:04:48,250 --> 00:04:53,120
nails should somebody be able to drive in
with that hammer before the hammer breaks?

81
00:04:53,120 --> 00:04:54,890
What would be an acceptable number?

82
00:04:54,890 --> 00:04:55,711
I have no clue.

83
00:04:55,711 --> 00:04:58,900
Is it 100, is it 1,000, is it 10,000?

84
00:04:58,900 --> 00:05:01,790
I've never broken a hammer, so I imagine
the number is really high, right?

85
00:05:01,790 --> 00:05:06,180
So if we manufactured a hammer that can
only be used 1,000 times, is that fit for

86
00:05:06,180 --> 00:05:09,590
use or are people going to be really angry
when it breaks after 1,000 nails and

87
00:05:09,590 --> 00:05:10,890
they gotta go and buy a new one?

88
00:05:10,890 --> 00:05:14,995
We've got to evaluate that to figure
out whether we are fit for use.

89
00:05:14,995 --> 00:05:16,395
If we know that number,

90
00:05:16,395 --> 00:05:20,705
if we say it's gotta be 10,000 nails, then
we've gotta create an availability plan.

91
00:05:20,705 --> 00:05:23,325
We've got to use materials
that are strong enough to make

92
00:05:23,325 --> 00:05:26,567
that hammer survive those
10,000 hits reliably.

93
00:05:26,567 --> 00:05:29,837
Knowing that you'll have some outliers,
manufacturing flaws and defects.

94
00:05:29,837 --> 00:05:32,077
That's where your express
warranties come in.

95
00:05:33,457 --> 00:05:36,507
But otherwise,
if a product is manufactured properly and

96
00:05:36,507 --> 00:05:39,530
to quality,
it should live up to that availability.

97
00:05:39,530 --> 00:05:43,730
In IT we're normally thinking about
web servers, database servers and

98
00:05:43,730 --> 00:05:44,380
that type of thing.

99
00:05:44,380 --> 00:05:49,460
And the way we maintain availability
is usually through redundancy.

100
00:05:49,460 --> 00:05:52,390
The best way to make a web
server available all the time

101
00:05:52,390 --> 00:05:55,210
is to have a second one or
a third one or a fourth one.

102
00:05:55,210 --> 00:05:58,920
And that way if one fails,
the others are still churning along.

103
00:05:58,920 --> 00:06:02,240
Your end user never even notices,
and you stay available.

104
00:06:03,270 --> 00:06:07,360
Another solution, though, would be
to say I'll buy better web servers.

105
00:06:07,360 --> 00:06:09,442
Instead of buying the cheapest
server that I can buy,

106
00:06:09,442 --> 00:06:11,200
maybe I'll buy a more expensive one.

107
00:06:11,200 --> 00:06:15,057
They'll use better parts,
higher quality equipment, and

108
00:06:15,057 --> 00:06:18,920
that'll ensure a larger MTBF,
mean time between failure.

109
00:06:18,920 --> 00:06:22,086
That we can have that equipment
run longer without fail.

110
00:06:22,086 --> 00:06:24,045
There's different solutions that are here.

111
00:06:24,045 --> 00:06:27,920
And remember, the failure can actually
be from any of a number of sources.

112
00:06:27,920 --> 00:06:30,790
Maybe the failure's actually
caused by a hacking incident.

113
00:06:30,790 --> 00:06:33,650
A hacker breaks into our web server and
starts messing with things and

114
00:06:33,650 --> 00:06:36,130
now our website's defaced and
it's no longer functioning.

115
00:06:36,130 --> 00:06:37,600
Even though the servers are up and

116
00:06:37,600 --> 00:06:40,350
running, our service is
no longer available, so

117
00:06:40,350 --> 00:06:44,540
we need to have security measures in
place to prevent the hacking attack.

118
00:06:44,540 --> 00:06:46,760
That's part of our availability plan.

119
00:06:48,170 --> 00:06:48,760
>> Creating or

120
00:06:48,760 --> 00:06:54,050
maintaining that availability plan means
that we're also currently taking a look at

121
00:06:54,050 --> 00:06:58,510
what we do have that's actually going to
make sure that the availability is there.

122
00:06:58,510 --> 00:07:02,700
We may find out that the servers that
we're running on, for example, are five or

123
00:07:02,700 --> 00:07:06,040
maybe ten years old, and
realize something that in the next year or

124
00:07:06,040 --> 00:07:08,460
two, we've got to retire that server.

125
00:07:08,460 --> 00:07:12,160
So knowing what we're gonna achieve also
need to bring up in the future is part of

126
00:07:12,160 --> 00:07:16,580
that so that our customer doesn't lose
any of the availability that they need.

127
00:07:16,580 --> 00:07:19,980
>> You see this factor in with
capacity planning, right?

128
00:07:19,980 --> 00:07:21,900
I think we talk about capacity next.

129
00:07:21,900 --> 00:07:25,190
But when you build out
your redundant web farm.

130
00:07:25,190 --> 00:07:26,570
So you might say, all right,

131
00:07:26,570 --> 00:07:32,490
I've got enough customers right now to
consume the resources of two web servers.

132
00:07:32,490 --> 00:07:33,860
So I'm gonna bring up three.

133
00:07:33,860 --> 00:07:36,180
I'm gonna bring up three web servers.

134
00:07:36,180 --> 00:07:38,270
That way if one fails, I still have two.

135
00:07:38,270 --> 00:07:40,660
I still have enough to
cover my current user base.

136
00:07:40,660 --> 00:07:44,375
And so we can put that in place, and
that's a highly available solution, great.

137
00:07:44,375 --> 00:07:48,683
But as your company grows, as you get more
customers, hopefully you're successful and

138
00:07:48,683 --> 00:07:49,900
you get more customers.

139
00:07:49,900 --> 00:07:51,180
That's what we all hope for.

140
00:07:51,180 --> 00:07:52,962
As you grow you find out that oh,

141
00:07:52,962 --> 00:07:56,333
now We actually consume
the resources of three web servers.

142
00:07:56,333 --> 00:07:59,170
And so if one fails, my other two are up.

143
00:07:59,170 --> 00:08:02,530
But they can't handle
the load of all of my users.

144
00:08:02,530 --> 00:08:04,090
And so while some users get in and

145
00:08:04,090 --> 00:08:07,850
just have a slow experience,
other users can't even get in.

146
00:08:07,850 --> 00:08:11,190
So now our availability needs
change as our company grows and

147
00:08:11,190 --> 00:08:12,210
we need to add to it.

148
00:08:13,280 --> 00:08:15,800
So we usually add some metrics and
say, all right.

149
00:08:15,800 --> 00:08:17,760
I'm gonna have three servers.

150
00:08:17,760 --> 00:08:23,000
As long as the utilization of all three
servers stays at 50% then I'm fine.

151
00:08:23,000 --> 00:08:26,235
One server could easily take over the job
of another server because they're at

152
00:08:26,235 --> 00:08:27,200
50% utilization.

153
00:08:27,200 --> 00:08:30,830
But if I see my servers getting over that,
now I need to start adding more.

154
00:08:30,830 --> 00:08:34,120
And so we set a metric to grow our
availability requirements over time.

155
00:08:34,120 --> 00:08:35,100
Sometimes that's easy to do.

156
00:08:35,100 --> 00:08:37,110
Sometimes that's very challenging.

157
00:08:37,110 --> 00:08:39,550
You might not be able to have
a simple formula like that.

158
00:08:39,550 --> 00:08:42,630
And in that scenario you have
to set up a series of reviews.

159
00:08:44,260 --> 00:08:45,790
Review, check you availability solutions.

160
00:08:45,790 --> 00:08:48,560
Is it still meeting the needs
of what you set up originally?

161
00:08:48,560 --> 00:08:50,360
And update as necessary.

162
00:08:50,360 --> 00:08:52,089
That's a big part of
availability management.

163
00:08:54,160 --> 00:08:56,730
The other thing is, you may

164
00:08:56,730 --> 00:09:00,560
have built an availability solution when
your company was configured one way.

165
00:09:00,560 --> 00:09:02,290
But over time you have changes.

166
00:09:02,290 --> 00:09:04,730
New services start to get offered.

167
00:09:04,730 --> 00:09:08,670
Equipment, people,
technology start getting repurposed or

168
00:09:08,670 --> 00:09:12,210
split tasks to work on more than
one thing at the same time.

169
00:09:12,210 --> 00:09:17,610
And now some of the extra capacity we
had before that we didn't worry about

170
00:09:17,610 --> 00:09:18,720
has got consumed.

171
00:09:18,720 --> 00:09:22,290
And so anytime a change is being proposed.

172
00:09:22,290 --> 00:09:25,180
When we're in this design phase for
that change.

173
00:09:25,180 --> 00:09:28,040
We have to evaluate the impact
that that's going to create on

174
00:09:28,040 --> 00:09:30,750
any of our availability
solutions in place right now.

175
00:09:30,750 --> 00:09:33,810
So going back and
double checking that with any change.

176
00:09:33,810 --> 00:09:38,370
>> One of the things about
the availability management is

177
00:09:38,370 --> 00:09:43,360
to always try to be proactive about what
is actually going to be the best solution

178
00:09:43,360 --> 00:09:46,560
that we're going to need to
provide to ensure availability.

179
00:09:46,560 --> 00:09:49,820
It's not, remember the reactive side,

180
00:09:49,820 --> 00:09:53,290
it is just saying here are all
the things that we can put in place.

181
00:09:53,290 --> 00:09:55,130
And this is our chance to do that.

182
00:09:55,130 --> 00:09:57,040
So with the design ready to go,

183
00:09:57,040 --> 00:10:00,870
we want to make sure that we're
taking the steps necessary.

184
00:10:00,870 --> 00:10:05,350
>> And if a failure does occur,
that's where continuity kicks in, right?

185
00:10:05,350 --> 00:10:07,690
But that doesn't mean we just
give up on availability either.

186
00:10:07,690 --> 00:10:11,340
If a failure does occur,
it just means you missed something.

187
00:10:11,340 --> 00:10:13,490
You didn't factor something in.

188
00:10:13,490 --> 00:10:16,950
Or maybe you did, and you just couldn't
get the funding to take care of it.

189
00:10:16,950 --> 00:10:18,140
That happens, right?

190
00:10:18,140 --> 00:10:19,650
Sometimes management will look at it and

191
00:10:19,650 --> 00:10:23,980
say you know, I understand that
we can prevent a failure here,

192
00:10:23,980 --> 00:10:28,575
but it doesn't make financial sense
to spend the money to prevent it.

193
00:10:28,575 --> 00:10:32,510
We'd actually lose less money by just
letting the failure happen and fix it.

194
00:10:32,510 --> 00:10:33,940
So that could happen.

195
00:10:33,940 --> 00:10:37,220
And in those situations,
whether you just overlooked it or

196
00:10:37,220 --> 00:10:40,490
whether it was purposefully ignored for
other reasons.

197
00:10:40,490 --> 00:10:44,150
When the failure happens, the availability
team needs to look at that and

198
00:10:44,150 --> 00:10:46,510
say, all right,
let's analyze the service failure.

199
00:10:46,510 --> 00:10:48,940
Let's see what caused this and

200
00:10:48,940 --> 00:10:53,250
now we can find out where there steps
we could have taken to prevent it.

201
00:10:53,250 --> 00:10:56,350
Maybe it is worth it now, now that your
company has seen what happens in an actual

202
00:10:56,350 --> 00:10:59,550
outage may be all of a sudden it is
worth it, that happens all too often.

203
00:10:59,550 --> 00:11:04,280
Or you can look at it and say, why
didn't our availability techniques work?

204
00:11:04,280 --> 00:11:08,740
We thought we had these covered,
here is the failure, what happened, right?

205
00:11:08,740 --> 00:11:10,150
And you can start to analyze it there.

206
00:11:10,150 --> 00:11:13,950
So the availability team during a failure,
they're not the ones responsible for

207
00:11:13,950 --> 00:11:17,380
fixing it or getting us back and running.

208
00:11:17,380 --> 00:11:20,130
They're analyzing to see how
can we prevent that later on.

209
00:11:20,130 --> 00:11:22,250
It's always proactive actions.

210
00:11:22,250 --> 00:11:24,200
Availability is always
looking to the future.

211
00:11:26,040 --> 00:11:30,720
So we're gonna talk about
continuity a little bit later.

212
00:11:30,720 --> 00:11:32,260
Which is not looking to the future.

213
00:11:32,260 --> 00:11:33,140
It's looking to the now.

214
00:11:33,140 --> 00:11:37,070
And I kind of wanted to cover that next
because they're so closely related.

215
00:11:37,070 --> 00:11:41,010
But I'm following the order in
the service design manual, and

216
00:11:41,010 --> 00:11:43,900
the next one ITIL hits
is capacity management.

217
00:11:43,900 --> 00:11:46,506
So, we're going to talk about
capacity management now, and

218
00:11:46,506 --> 00:11:48,520
then we'll jump back to continuity.

219
00:11:48,520 --> 00:11:51,620
But as far as availability,
it sounds pretty simple, right?

220
00:11:51,620 --> 00:11:54,620
But it is actually one of the more
challenging processes that we have to go

221
00:11:54,620 --> 00:11:58,280
through, because you're trying to
anticipate failures that out there and

222
00:11:58,280 --> 00:12:00,000
cover your bases and

223
00:12:00,000 --> 00:12:04,600
every little bit of availability you
introduce has a cost associated with it.

224
00:12:04,600 --> 00:12:06,750
So there's a financial
aspect that has to occur.

225
00:12:06,750 --> 00:12:10,220
You have to do a cost-to-benefit ratio.

226
00:12:10,220 --> 00:12:12,960
What does it cost to
create this availability?

227
00:12:12,960 --> 00:12:15,430
And what's my benefit for doing that?

228
00:12:15,430 --> 00:12:20,280
And so we'll talk about business
impact analyses later, or BIAs, and

229
00:12:20,280 --> 00:12:22,190
that's a great way to be
able to find that out.

230
00:12:22,190 --> 00:12:25,390
But I'll tie that into continuity
a little bit later and we'll see that.

231
00:12:25,390 --> 00:12:29,050
But a lot of companies like amazon.com,
right?

232
00:12:29,050 --> 00:12:31,940
They have a web-based online store.

233
00:12:31,940 --> 00:12:33,550
They have no physical stores.

234
00:12:33,550 --> 00:12:38,450
If their website goes offline,
they lose over a million dollars an hour.

235
00:12:38,450 --> 00:12:41,860
So if I were to tell them, hey,
we could put this redundancy in here and

236
00:12:41,860 --> 00:12:44,260
it'll cost you $500,000.

237
00:12:44,260 --> 00:12:47,345
That might sound like a lot of money but
to them they say, it's a no brainer,

238
00:12:47,345 --> 00:12:50,890
cuz if we had the outage it would cost
us a million dollars an hour, we'll make

239
00:12:50,890 --> 00:12:55,800
that up in half an hour of an outage,
right, by avoiding the outage altogether.

240
00:12:55,800 --> 00:12:57,380
Companies need to look at it that way.

241
00:12:57,380 --> 00:12:59,820
There's other ones you hear about it

242
00:12:59,820 --> 00:13:03,300
where the manufacturer knows about
a flaw in the car and they say well,

00:13:03,300 --> 00:13:07,820
it will cost us this amount
of money to do a recall, or

244
00:13:07,820 --> 00:13:11,160
we could just let a few people by and
we'll settle it out of court.

245
00:13:11,160 --> 00:13:14,080
And the settlements will cost us
this amount, and that's cheaper.

246
00:13:14,080 --> 00:13:14,800
So, we'll just go that route.

247
00:13:14,800 --> 00:13:16,520
Right?
There have been several movies and

248
00:13:16,520 --> 00:13:17,900
documentaries and stuff on this.

249
00:13:17,900 --> 00:13:18,970
It's a true thing.

250
00:13:18,970 --> 00:13:21,940
We do that cost to benefit
analysis to find out.

251
00:13:21,940 --> 00:13:26,130
What those guys don't factor in is the
public relations side which has its own

252
00:13:26,130 --> 00:13:28,440
cost, it's just not money.

253
00:13:28,440 --> 00:13:29,280
Well, it ends up being money.

254
00:13:29,280 --> 00:13:31,179
>> Reputation.
>> If your customers leave you, yeah.

255
00:13:31,179 --> 00:13:33,195
>> So that all factors in.

256
00:13:33,195 --> 00:13:37,127
So that's pretty much it for availability
management, it's pretty straight forward.

257
00:13:37,127 --> 00:13:42,505
All right,
our next process is capacity management.

258
00:13:42,505 --> 00:13:46,165
And we talked a little bit about capacity
in an earlier segment just as it was

259
00:13:46,165 --> 00:13:52,703
related to kind of our strategies,
but here it's all part of planning.

260
00:13:52,703 --> 00:13:56,569
As we're doing our service design,
as we're creating the service,

261
00:13:56,569 --> 00:14:00,320
we have to figure out what levels
of capacity we're gonna provide.

262
00:14:00,320 --> 00:14:05,630
If we're providing an online
mortgage payment website.

00:14:05,630 --> 00:14:09,012
How many customers do we expect

00:14:09,012 --> 00:14:12,110
That's gonna influence the amount of
equipment and resources that we need, and

00:14:12,110 --> 00:14:13,430
