I participated in
the supporting services and

494
00:26:26,710 --> 00:26:30,800
from the supporting side, every thing
I worked on was important to me.

495
00:26:30,800 --> 00:26:33,970
All the web servers I touched were
important, all the data base servers,

496
00:26:33,970 --> 00:26:36,310
all of that stuff to me was important.

497
00:26:36,310 --> 00:26:42,390
But to the core services they may not
be so we have identify what part, what

498
00:26:42,390 --> 00:26:47,010
are our supporting or ancillary services
are actually critical to the core.

499
00:26:47,010 --> 00:26:53,915
And the best way to find that is to bring
an outsider, to bring in a consultant,

500
00:26:53,915 --> 00:26:59,090
a auditor, to come in and perform what's
called a business impact analysis.

501
00:26:59,090 --> 00:27:01,930
Now if you have a risk management team,
they'll often do the BIA for you,

502
00:27:01,930 --> 00:27:04,410
a business impact analysis.

503
00:27:04,410 --> 00:27:07,416
But if you don't, you just bring
in somebody from the outside.

504
00:27:07,416 --> 00:27:10,860
In the banking industry we
usually brought in KPMG or

505
00:27:10,860 --> 00:27:13,850
somebody like that to come and
evaluate our environment.

506
00:27:13,850 --> 00:27:17,820
And what they did is they would basically
catalog all your systems, all of your

507
00:27:17,820 --> 00:27:22,430
servers, all of the software that you ran,
and they would break it down and

508
00:27:22,430 --> 00:27:26,780
say alright if this server failed,
what systems would stop working?

509
00:27:26,780 --> 00:27:28,150
What processes would stop working?

510
00:27:29,180 --> 00:27:32,790
Maybe there's a server that failed and
no processes stopped working.

511
00:27:32,790 --> 00:27:34,840
In that case, it's a non-critical server,
you don't worry about it.

512
00:27:34,840 --> 00:27:38,930
But there might be another one that failed
and it caused the website to go offline.

513
00:27:38,930 --> 00:27:42,280
All right, but if the website is offline,
we might still be able to handle

514
00:27:42,280 --> 00:27:47,160
withdrawals and issue mortgages so you
might still be able to do other things.

515
00:27:47,160 --> 00:27:51,220
So they'll identify what are the critical
systems, the systems that you really

516
00:27:51,220 --> 00:27:55,640
need to be online to be making money and
the systems that

517
00:27:55,640 --> 00:27:58,770
don't need to be online because they don't
impact your bottom line, you making money.

518
00:27:59,810 --> 00:28:04,210
Of the ones that are critical, they say
okay if this server were to go off line

519
00:28:04,210 --> 00:28:07,110
here's how much money
you would lose per hour.

520
00:28:07,110 --> 00:28:09,520
This is the business impact.

521
00:28:09,520 --> 00:28:12,650
If that server were to go off
line here's the dollar signs,

522
00:28:12,650 --> 00:28:13,780
here's how much it;s going to cost you.

523
00:28:14,990 --> 00:28:17,550
And based on that,
you'll learn two things.

524
00:28:17,550 --> 00:28:20,270
One, you learn which
servers are truly critical.

525
00:28:20,270 --> 00:28:24,250
These are the ones that you need to
have the most effort put in to make them

526
00:28:24,250 --> 00:28:25,850
highly available.

527
00:28:25,850 --> 00:28:28,960
You want them to avoid a failure in
the first place because their critical.

528
00:28:30,020 --> 00:28:36,850
And if they do fail, you wanna have a lock
tight continuity plan, a backup, a plan B

529
00:28:36,850 --> 00:28:41,260
so that you can still resume business
in the event your availability failed.

530
00:28:41,260 --> 00:28:43,310
And you identify the non-critical servers,
and

531
00:28:43,310 --> 00:28:45,550
these guys maybe I don't
worry about availability.

532
00:28:45,550 --> 00:28:47,070
So if they fail, it's bad, but

533
00:28:47,070 --> 00:28:51,180
it's not that big of a deal, we can always
fix it and bring it back up online.

534
00:28:51,180 --> 00:28:54,200
And then maybe we don't worry about
a plan B on this one, because, again,

535
00:28:54,200 --> 00:28:56,760
if it fails,
then we just restore from backup or

536
00:28:56,760 --> 00:28:58,760
something simple like that and
just deal with it.

537
00:28:58,760 --> 00:29:00,360
It's nothing critical, right?

538
00:29:00,360 --> 00:29:03,870
So that's the first thing that this tells
us is which servers we need to be planning

539
00:29:03,870 --> 00:29:05,660
for, for our systems.

540
00:29:05,660 --> 00:29:08,560
And then secondly, the dollar signs.

541
00:29:08,560 --> 00:29:10,960
That helps us to gauge how much we spend.

542
00:29:12,350 --> 00:29:14,920
If a service fails and

543
00:29:14,920 --> 00:29:19,230
it's gonna cost us twenty dollars an hour
that's probably not something we're gonna

544
00:29:19,230 --> 00:29:22,620
take a lot of action on to get corrected
because it's just not a lot of money.

545
00:29:22,620 --> 00:29:26,320
But if a service fails and it costs
us twenty thousand dollars an hour

546
00:29:26,320 --> 00:29:30,330
it's worth it for us to spend a few
grand to build in some extra redundancy.

547
00:29:30,330 --> 00:29:32,270
Or if it's gonna cost us
a million dollars now, or

548
00:29:32,270 --> 00:29:35,560
it makes us first to spend hundreds
of thousands of dollars to make that

549
00:29:35,560 --> 00:29:38,920
available and
avoid the failure in the first place.

550
00:29:38,920 --> 00:29:43,450
So, the BIA, the business impact
analysis that's what steers us

551
00:29:43,450 --> 00:29:45,870
to where we should focus where we
should be making things available.

552
00:29:47,140 --> 00:29:50,600
The BIAs will normally focus
on existing services, and

553
00:29:50,600 --> 00:29:55,130
so every time you introduce a new service,
you kind of have to reevaluate it.

554
00:29:55,130 --> 00:29:57,000
How's this impact or
what are the impacts of this one?

555
00:29:57,000 --> 00:30:01,450
So BIAs are things that you'll perform
on a regular basis and it's tough for

556
00:30:01,450 --> 00:30:05,160
us to perform them internally, especially
as IT guys cuz we don't necessarily

557
00:30:05,160 --> 00:30:10,120
understand the true core service
that our company provides.

558
00:30:10,120 --> 00:30:12,180
All right, so that's a BIA.

559
00:30:12,180 --> 00:30:17,880
And based on the information from
there we'll create usually two things,

560
00:30:17,880 --> 00:30:21,510
a business continuity plan and
a business resumption plan.

561
00:30:22,800 --> 00:30:26,460
Now the BRP and the BCP.

562
00:30:26,460 --> 00:30:30,570
A lot of people get these confused but
there is a difference between them.

563
00:30:30,570 --> 00:30:34,630
The business continuity plan
says if there's a failure

564
00:30:34,630 --> 00:30:38,450
what steps do we need to take
just to keep doing business?

565
00:30:40,200 --> 00:30:43,690
That means that we may
still have the failure.

566
00:30:43,690 --> 00:30:47,610
We may not be at full capacity but
at least we could still do business.

567
00:30:48,640 --> 00:30:53,240
Maybe I have a call center that has 500
sales reps in it that are answering

568
00:30:53,240 --> 00:30:57,390
phones or support reps or whatever
answering phones and talking to customers.

569
00:30:57,390 --> 00:31:00,770
500, and I say all right,
if something happens and

570
00:31:00,770 --> 00:31:04,210
all those phones go dead in that
data center, in that call center,

571
00:31:04,210 --> 00:31:08,610
I might have another call center
somewhere else with a 100 reps and

572
00:31:08,610 --> 00:31:12,660
if the main call center fails
I've still got my other one.

573
00:31:12,660 --> 00:31:17,720
But it's only got a hundred reps so
I'm at a much lower capacity but

574
00:31:17,720 --> 00:31:18,680
I can still do business.

575
00:31:18,680 --> 00:31:20,010
I'm continuing, right?

576
00:31:20,010 --> 00:31:24,560
So a BCP is like a band-aid,
what can we stick on this problem

577
00:31:24,560 --> 00:31:29,075
just to get us by until we can really
fix it and get back to full test?

578
00:31:29,075 --> 00:31:33,570
If you're lucky your BCP might
actually maintain full capacity but

579
00:31:33,570 --> 00:31:36,990
normally it results in
a degraded performance at least.

580
00:31:36,990 --> 00:31:40,600
You fail back the servers in another
location like might be a little older or

581
00:31:40,600 --> 00:31:43,660
whatever, so you may see a decrease.

582
00:31:43,660 --> 00:31:48,640
Some people plan for this very, very
well like the New York Stock Exchange.

583
00:31:48,640 --> 00:31:52,112
Their disaster recovery site it's actually
the same equipment as in production so

584
00:31:52,112 --> 00:31:55,250
when they fail over you don't even
don't even see a performance degrade.

585
00:31:55,250 --> 00:31:59,500
So their BCP, it's not just a band-aid,
it keeps them at full capacity.

586
00:31:59,500 --> 00:32:01,060
It's really awesome.

587
00:32:01,060 --> 00:32:04,980
But if you're a small or medium size
company, that comes at a price and

588
00:32:04,980 --> 00:32:05,870
you may not be able to do that.

589
00:32:05,870 --> 00:32:11,200
So the BCP we draft first, and that's
just to keep us going during the failure.

590
00:32:12,900 --> 00:32:15,570
The BRP, the Business Resumption Plan.

591
00:32:15,570 --> 00:32:18,830
That's saying, okay we've got the failure.

592
00:32:18,830 --> 00:32:22,104
How do we fix it to get back to 100%?

593
00:32:22,104 --> 00:32:24,680
How do we resume business as normal?

594
00:32:24,680 --> 00:32:30,110
How do we get back into that to where
it's like the failure never happened?

595
00:32:30,110 --> 00:32:32,270
And that can be a more protracted event.

596
00:32:32,270 --> 00:32:34,460
That might take longer than we needed.

597
00:32:34,460 --> 00:32:37,670
So I mentioned earlier the FDIC
had given us that three day limit.

598
00:32:37,670 --> 00:32:41,410
That was just to be able to limp along,
to handle withdrawals.

599
00:32:41,410 --> 00:32:44,050
That we could take two weeks, if we wanted

600
00:32:44,050 --> 00:32:47,935
to bring other aspects of our business
back in line., it'd be costing us money.

601
00:32:47,935 --> 00:32:49,265
We wouldn't want that, right?

602
00:32:49,265 --> 00:32:53,775
But we could have taken longer,
so your BRP is typically longer

603
00:32:53,775 --> 00:32:56,735
in time frame than your BCP
cuz you're getting everything,

604
00:32:56,735 --> 00:33:01,172
even your noncritical systems
getting them back up in operation.

605
00:33:01,172 --> 00:33:05,752
>> With these in hand, we also want
to take a look at the management of

606
00:33:05,752 --> 00:33:10,622
the impact that's gonna happen if
things do change, as well as make

607
00:33:10,622 --> 00:33:14,682
sure that we put in place the measures
that will help increase the availability.

608
00:33:15,872 --> 00:33:18,112
By taking all this
information that we have,

609
00:33:18,112 --> 00:33:22,640
were now putting it into a plan that says,
here's what we need to do to now ensure

610
00:33:22,640 --> 00:33:27,000
that the continuity is gonna continue,
whether it's at a less state or if we can

611
00:33:27,000 --> 00:33:28,690
actually do New York Stock Exchange-
>> [LAUGH]

612
00:33:28,690 --> 00:33:31,450
>> Have complete parity, that state.

613
00:33:31,450 --> 00:33:35,650
But this is where we begin is we
wanna manage our entire design

614
00:33:35,650 --> 00:33:37,850
to make sure that we handle it that way.

615
00:33:37,850 --> 00:33:41,760
>> And if you're implementing a change,
that change is gonna impact this.

616
00:33:41,760 --> 00:33:45,440
We may have to introduce new measures
to provide that availability.

617
00:33:45,440 --> 00:33:48,220
We might, not be impacting us at all.

618
00:33:48,220 --> 00:33:51,610
So we've gotta evaluate that, and
keep that documentation up to date.

619
00:33:51,610 --> 00:33:55,820
All of these things, the BCP,
the BRP, they contain tons of

620
00:33:55,820 --> 00:33:59,030
data instructions that say,
here's how you get back in business.

621
00:33:59,030 --> 00:34:02,550
So those instructions change as your
systems change, as you upgrade servers,

622
00:34:02,550 --> 00:34:03,820
as you replace equipment.

623
00:34:03,820 --> 00:34:07,340
Maybe you had all Cisco routers one year,
and

624
00:34:07,340 --> 00:34:09,480
then two years,
later you switched to all Juniper routers.

625
00:34:10,800 --> 00:34:12,370
The routers are performing
the same function,

626
00:34:12,370 --> 00:34:14,670
maybe they're at the same IP addresses and
so on.

627
00:34:14,670 --> 00:34:16,570
But during a disaster,

628
00:34:16,570 --> 00:34:21,020
you might have in your BRP some steps that
you should be putting in static routes,

629
00:34:21,020 --> 00:34:24,090
and the commands are different on
Cisco than they are on Juniper.

630
00:34:24,090 --> 00:34:26,300
So we need to update that
to reflect those changes.

631
00:34:26,300 --> 00:34:28,900
It is really important that
we keep those up to date and

632
00:34:28,900 --> 00:34:32,220
that we put in any additional
measures that are necessary.

633
00:34:32,220 --> 00:34:36,350
We may find though, that there are times
where, it doesn't make sense for

634
00:34:36,350 --> 00:34:37,630
us to put the measures in for ourselves.

635
00:34:37,630 --> 00:34:40,500
They are too expensive or
we may not have the capability,

636
00:34:40,500 --> 00:34:42,980
in those scenario you got to
reach outside the company.

637
00:34:42,980 --> 00:34:47,360
And when you reach out side, what you are
gonna be doing is entering into contracts

638
00:34:47,360 --> 00:34:50,160
with other organizations
to help offset this.

639
00:34:50,160 --> 00:34:52,660
The most common form is simply insurance.

640
00:34:53,720 --> 00:34:57,660
Insurance says, we are not gonna dump
a ton of money into preventing this.

641
00:34:57,660 --> 00:35:03,290
So if it happens, we want somebody
else to absorb the cost of a failure.

642
00:35:03,290 --> 00:35:06,650
So I know,
I'm gonna be losing $20,000 an hour.

643
00:35:06,650 --> 00:35:10,051
So I go and buy an insurance policy
that says, if a failure does happen,

644
00:35:10,051 --> 00:35:12,051
they'll insure me for $100,00.

645
00:35:12,051 --> 00:35:14,613
But I give you five hours,
that'll buy me five hours of time,

646
00:35:14,613 --> 00:35:18,490
where I won't lose that money cuz I
get an insurance payment instead.

647
00:35:18,490 --> 00:35:21,350
Other options though, maybe you
want to have a remote data center,

648
00:35:21,350 --> 00:35:23,710
a disaster recovery center,
somewhere else.

649
00:35:23,710 --> 00:35:27,670
But you don't want to build a building,
do redundant power supplies, generators,

650
00:35:27,670 --> 00:35:32,520
all of that stuff, it's expensive and
it requires a lot of maintenance, so

651
00:35:32,520 --> 00:35:35,670
you might contract out
with a hosting provider.

652
00:35:35,670 --> 00:35:41,130
Somebody who will provide you racks inside
of their data center that's already

653
00:35:41,130 --> 00:35:43,450
highly redundant and all of that.

654
00:35:43,450 --> 00:35:45,850
And you just throw your
servers in there and go or

655
00:35:45,850 --> 00:35:48,510
maybe they're not even physical servers,
maybe they're virtual servers.

656
00:35:48,510 --> 00:35:53,150
We use Amazon web services or Windows
Azure or somebody to host virtual machines

657
00:35:53,150 --> 00:35:56,980
that mirror our production environment,
and we can flip over to when we want.

658
00:35:56,980 --> 00:36:00,450
The cool thing about the contracts,
a lot of times you can negotiate them, so

659
00:36:00,450 --> 00:36:03,130
that you're only paying for
the servers when they're used.

660
00:36:03,130 --> 00:36:06,100
That's how Windows Azure and
Amazon web services work.

661
00:36:06,100 --> 00:36:09,190
The physical data centers, they normally
have to charge you no matter what cuz

662
00:36:09,190 --> 00:36:11,950
you've got the service in there,
the consuming power and so on.

663
00:36:11,950 --> 00:36:16,190
But with Azure and Amazon,
you can shut all those servers off.

664
00:36:16,190 --> 00:36:18,870
And then when you have a failure you can
just bring them up, it takes a moment, and

665
00:36:18,870 --> 00:36:20,010
you're back in business.

666
00:36:20,010 --> 00:36:24,040
So you contact the other people
to get that functionality.

667
00:36:24,040 --> 00:36:28,760
In today's technologies, in today's world,
even a small company can

668
00:36:28,760 --> 00:36:32,605
afford a good bit of redundancy that
would have been a dream years ago.

669
00:36:32,605 --> 00:36:35,365
Now, it's pretty easy to achieve.

670
00:36:35,365 --> 00:36:40,360
So that in a nut shell is the IT
service continuity management.

671
00:36:40,360 --> 00:36:45,695
It's a lot of planning,
it does boil down to budget.

672
00:36:45,695 --> 00:36:49,625
The anecdote, I always give is
I use to be a field consultant.

673
00:36:49,625 --> 00:36:53,700
I'd go out to various companies and
help them with their design and plans.

674
00:36:53,700 --> 00:36:56,184
And there was this question,
I always loved to ask it,

675
00:36:56,184 --> 00:36:57,696
cuz I always got the same answer.

676
00:36:57,696 --> 00:37:00,915
And I thought it was funny,
is if you went to a CIO or

677
00:37:00,915 --> 00:37:04,446
any executive within the company,
and you said okay,

678
00:37:04,446 --> 00:37:09,237
this is the service that you offer, and
how available do you want it to be?

679
00:37:09,237 --> 00:37:10,130
And they would say, what do you mean?

680
00:37:10,130 --> 00:37:13,440
And I would say well,
if a customer comes to your site.

681
00:37:13,440 --> 00:37:15,670
We want to guarantee to get to it.

682
00:37:15,670 --> 00:37:20,420
What percentage of down time or how much
down time do you think is acceptable?

683
00:37:20,420 --> 00:37:21,580
They would say well, none.

684
00:37:21,580 --> 00:37:23,828
I want it to be available all the time.

685
00:37:23,828 --> 00:37:26,034
I would say, okay,
we can certainly do that,

686
00:37:26,034 --> 00:37:29,420
we can create a design where
you would have zero down time.

687
00:37:29,420 --> 00:37:31,176
What does your budget look like?

688
00:37:31,176 --> 00:37:33,090
Cuz this is gonna cost
millions of dollars,

689
00:37:34,470 --> 00:37:36,440
you don't even have to
work out the math on it.

690
00:37:36,440 --> 00:37:40,060
If you want a zero downtime environment,
it's gonna cost millions of dollars.

691
00:37:40,060 --> 00:37:41,200
I can guarantee you.

692
00:37:41,200 --> 00:37:46,020
So then they look at it and they go,
oh okay, well now, we're thinking money.

693
00:37:46,020 --> 00:37:49,980
It really comes down to how much are you
willing to spend to create availability?

694
00:37:49,980 --> 00:37:52,740
Finding that balancing point and
then you go and

695
00:37:52,740 --> 00:37:57,850
design from there, and that financial side
as an IT guy, we don't normally know it.

696
00:37:57,850 --> 00:38:01,130
I don't know,
if we can't sell mortgages right now,

697
00:38:02,190 --> 00:38:05,910
I have no idea how many mortgages we sell
in an hour or a day or a month, right?

698
00:38:05,910 --> 00:38:08,120
So that's where we have
to rely on other people.

699
00:38:08,120 --> 00:38:11,290
Other people in the organization to put
this data together and then we act on it.

700
00:38:11,290 --> 00:38:13,510
And they say, okay, it makes sense for

701
00:38:13,510 --> 00:38:18,680
us to spend about $200,000 to create
a highly available environment.

702
00:38:18,680 --> 00:38:21,986
How much availability can you give us for
that $200,000?

703
00:38:21,986 --> 00:38:27,430
And we can say, okay we can keep it
down to about eight minutes per year.

704
00:38:27,430 --> 00:38:31,980
With this model in place, this solution we
keep down to about eight minutes per year.

705
00:38:31,980 --> 00:38:33,690
If it's a failure here in our center,

706
00:38:33,690 --> 00:38:35,290
we can just flip over to
other servers instantly.

707
00:38:35,290 --> 00:38:36,330
No down time.

708
00:38:36,330 --> 00:38:38,180
If it's a big failure like
the whole data center.

709
00:38:38,180 --> 00:38:40,400
It would take us about eight
minutes to jump to the other one.

710
00:38:40,400 --> 00:38:42,750
And we can do that for $200,000.

711
00:38:42,750 --> 00:38:45,520
That's acceptable,
we achieve it, and we move on.

712
00:38:45,520 --> 00:38:47,560
And each year we just reevaluate that.

713
00:38:47,560 --> 00:38:49,370
Does it make sense to
keep spending that money?

714
00:38:49,370 --> 00:38:52,610
Does it make sense to increase it or

01:03:01,060 --> 01:03:05,160
We've gotta come up with a design,
originally, in that service design phase

1164
01:03:05,160 --> 01:03:08,760
and then, we continually revisit it,
reinforcing it in our environment.

1165
01:03:08,760 --> 01:03:13,240
So, that's pretty much it for the ITSCM,

1166
01:03:13,240 --> 01:03:17,610
our information security management
in general, quite a bit in there.

1167
01:03:17,610 --> 01:03:19,230
A lot of stuff.

1168
01:03:19,230 --> 01:03:24,393
You'll find that the service availability,
the IT service continuity management,

1169
01:03:24,393 --> 01:03:28,991
ITSCM, and information security
management, those three, they really do

1170
01:03:28,991 --> 01:03:33,750
overlap quite a bit, so a lot of companies
just combine that into one big thing.

1171
01:03:33,750 --> 01:03:37,700
ITIL defines them out separately
because you might have different teams

1172
01:03:37,700 --> 01:03:39,583
of employees operating each one.

1173
01:03:39,583 --> 01:03:43,833
So they give you the ability to have it
broken out or you can merge it together.

1174
01:03:43,833 --> 01:03:46,293
It's very easy to do.

1175
01:03:46,293 --> 01:03:50,040
All right, well Ronnie,
that brings us to our very last process.

1176
01:03:50,040 --> 01:03:54,580
I know, this is one of the bigger of
the service books that we get into,

1177
01:03:54,580 --> 01:03:56,320
cuz this one has eight processes.

1178
01:03:56,320 --> 01:04:00,240
But the last process is supplier
management, and you won't likely see this

1179
01:04:00,240 --> 01:04:02,717
one on the exam, but
I did want to cover it for completeness.

1180
01:04:02,717 --> 01:04:06,480
Because you're gonna deal with suppliers,
it happens.

1181
01:04:06,480 --> 01:04:09,990
Here at ITProTV,
we've got a ton of IT talent, our staff,

1182
01:04:09,990 --> 01:04:14,594
pretty much everybody here, is at least
mid level certified for IT stuff.

1183
01:04:14,594 --> 01:04:16,578
The IT stuff.

1184
01:04:16,578 --> 01:04:17,377
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm gonna make that

1185
01:04:17,377 --> 01:04:18,270
certification next year.

1186
01:04:18,270 --> 01:04:19,960
The IT stuff cert.

1187
01:04:19,960 --> 01:04:21,970
So when we wanna offer something new,

1188
01:04:21,970 --> 01:04:24,910
often times we've got the in
house talent to do it.

1189
01:04:24,910 --> 01:04:28,500
But we don't have anybody in here
that can build a server, right?

1190
01:04:28,500 --> 01:04:31,600
We don't have a manufacturing plant or
anything to generate our equipment.

1191
01:04:31,600 --> 01:04:34,050
So we've gotta buy that from somewhere.

1192
01:04:34,050 --> 01:04:38,850
And we don't have giant redundant
generators outside of our building,

1193
01:04:38,850 --> 01:04:41,400
and five different ISPs
run into our building.

1194
01:04:41,400 --> 01:04:42,850
We don't have stuff like that.

1195
01:04:42,850 --> 01:04:46,080
So we rely on other people to do that for
us.

1196
01:04:46,080 --> 01:04:48,480
So that's very, very common, even for

1197
01:04:48,480 --> 01:04:51,080
tech companies that you're not
gonna create everything internally.

1198
01:04:51,080 --> 01:04:53,950
So when you deal with the supplier,

1199
01:04:53,950 --> 01:04:57,920
we've got to make sure that's all handled
in a healthy and responsible manner.

1200
01:04:59,700 --> 01:05:01,830
>> When it comes down to suppliers,

1201
01:05:01,830 --> 01:05:04,900
we of course need to make sure
that the supplier that's we're

1202
01:05:04,900 --> 01:05:10,420
gonna be purchasing from is also going
to be providing the value that we need.

1203
01:05:10,420 --> 01:05:14,220
Same time, we also need to ensure
that the item that we choose or

1204
01:05:14,220 --> 01:05:16,900
whatever the product
that we choose from them

1205
01:05:16,900 --> 01:05:21,310
is going to help us to also meet
our own customer needs as well.

1206
01:05:21,310 --> 01:05:25,790
So it does come down to an unusual
balancing act, in which we have to pick

1207
01:05:25,790 --> 01:05:29,440
the right supplier who can provide for
us the right service.

1208
01:05:29,440 --> 01:05:31,450
And of course, even at the right cost, so

1209
01:05:31,450 --> 01:05:34,690
there's a lot of elements that go
into this in the managing side.

1210
01:05:34,690 --> 01:05:37,310
>> Yeah, you might have
a supplier that originally was

1211
01:05:37,310 --> 01:05:38,990
perfectly in alignment with you.

1212
01:05:38,990 --> 01:05:41,900
You wanted high quality
equipment that was reliable, and

1213
01:05:41,900 --> 01:05:44,590
they were making high quality
equipment that was reliable.

1214
01:05:44,590 --> 01:05:48,770
And as time goes on maybe, they started
cutting corners to increase their

1215
01:05:48,770 --> 01:05:52,330
profit margin, so they started
creating lower quality equipment.

1216
01:05:52,330 --> 01:05:56,610
Well now, they've gotten out of alignment
with what your strategy is, and

1217
01:05:56,610 --> 01:06:00,050
so that might not be the appropriate
supplier for you anymore.

1218
01:06:00,050 --> 01:06:03,260
You may need to switch or you may need
to just communicate with them and

1219
01:06:03,260 --> 01:06:07,030
say look, if you want me to keep doing
business with you here's what I need.

1220
01:06:07,030 --> 01:06:08,890
Can you do that?

1221
01:06:08,890 --> 01:06:11,030
And they may come back into alignment.

1222
01:06:11,030 --> 01:06:13,240
But we need to keep an eye on that.

1223
01:06:13,240 --> 01:06:16,510
Just because you started with a particular
vendor doesn't mean you need to stick with

1224
01:06:16,510 --> 01:06:17,200
them forever.

1225
01:06:17,200 --> 01:06:19,145
You got to keep your options opened,

1226
01:06:19,145 --> 01:06:22,426
because you are not doing business
to support that supplier.

1227
01:06:22,426 --> 01:06:26,994
You are doing business to support your
companies' strategies which is ultimately

1228
01:06:26,994 --> 01:06:29,250
servicing your customers.

1229
01:06:29,250 --> 01:06:32,340
So that's who we would care about,
not necessarily the supplier.

1230
01:06:32,340 --> 01:06:33,820
It doesn't mean to disregard the supplier.

1231
01:06:33,820 --> 01:06:36,180
You need to have a healthy
relationship with them.

1232
01:06:36,180 --> 01:06:39,760
So you need to ensure that things like,
your bills are paid on time.

1233
01:06:39,760 --> 01:06:43,360
Because what supplier is gonna wanna
help you, if you pay your bills late?

1234
01:06:43,360 --> 01:06:45,770
That kinda thing is really frustrating.

1235
01:06:45,770 --> 01:06:50,509
So we've gotta make sure that when we
enter into a contract with these vendors,

1236
01:06:50,509 --> 01:06:54,839
that we're getting value, but
that it's also aligned with our goals.

1237
01:06:54,839 --> 01:06:56,688
That everybody's kind of
got their ducks in a row,

1238
01:06:56,688 --> 01:06:58,280
they're all moving in the same direction.

1239
01:07:00,310 --> 01:07:02,760
Now, whenever we enter into a contract,

1240
01:07:02,760 --> 01:07:05,740
you set expectations as a statement
of work in that contract.

1241
01:07:05,740 --> 01:07:07,590
What you expect from that vendor?

1242
01:07:07,590 --> 01:07:10,250
We need to make sure
that they perform to it.

1243
01:07:10,250 --> 01:07:14,350
So during our design stage we're figuring
out what suppliers we're gonna need

1244
01:07:14,350 --> 01:07:18,500
to interact with and we're creating this
methodology for interacting with them.

1245
01:07:18,500 --> 01:07:20,820
How we monitor that performance?

1246
01:07:20,820 --> 01:07:26,440
A great example would be a company that I
worked for, where we had all Dell servers.

1247
01:07:26,440 --> 01:07:32,760
So we had several hundred just Dell
servers, and we had a conversation

1248
01:07:32,760 --> 01:07:37,100
with them, and we said, we're looking to
build out a disaster recovery center.

1249
01:07:37,100 --> 01:07:39,730
But we have several hundred servers, and

1250
01:07:39,730 --> 01:07:43,140
we don't want to just buy
several hundred more over there.

1251
01:07:43,140 --> 01:07:47,310
It's a big expense to have for servers
that hopefully we never have to use.

1252
01:07:47,310 --> 01:07:50,936
And so we had bought enough from Dell
that they were ready to take care of us.

1253
01:07:50,936 --> 01:07:52,920
And they said, here's what we can do.

1254
01:07:52,920 --> 01:07:56,440
Because you guys have bought hundreds of
servers, and you've been our customer for

1255
01:07:56,440 --> 01:07:57,640
a long time.

1256
01:07:57,640 --> 01:07:59,210
Let's do this.

1257
01:07:59,210 --> 01:08:01,850
Buy physical servers that
match your critical systems.

1258
01:08:01,850 --> 01:08:04,390
So out of our,
I think we had about 270 servers.

1259
01:08:04,390 --> 01:08:09,300
And out of that, they were really about 80
to 85 that were truly critical services.

1260
01:08:09,300 --> 01:08:11,230
And say, go ahead and buy those.

1261
01:08:11,230 --> 01:08:16,150
And then, for the rest of them we will
sign an agreement with you that says,

1262
01:08:16,150 --> 01:08:21,620
if a disaster strikes we will do next day,
shipping on that equipment to

1263
01:08:21,620 --> 01:08:27,760
get it delivered to your facility
the very next day, as quickly as we can.

1264
01:08:27,760 --> 01:08:31,340
Your critical service will be up
right away, but the other ones,

1265
01:08:31,340 --> 01:08:34,020
you just need to make sure you have your
back ups and we'll get the servers to you.

1266
01:08:34,020 --> 01:08:36,890
You can restore your back ups and
you'll be back up in business.

1267
01:08:36,890 --> 01:08:38,240
And it's gonna be a disaster.

1268
01:08:38,240 --> 01:08:41,220
It might affect other people,
other people are gonna be ordering, but

1269
01:08:41,220 --> 01:08:42,460
we will honor yours first.

1270
01:08:42,460 --> 01:08:44,190
That's what this contract states.

1271
01:08:44,190 --> 01:08:49,250
So we purchased a lot from them, and
they took care of us because of that.

1272
01:08:49,250 --> 01:08:52,100
We didn't have to buy those servers,
and just have them sitting there for

1273
01:08:52,100 --> 01:08:56,050
months on end for
a disaster that likely will never come.

1274
01:08:56,050 --> 01:08:58,030
But in the event the disaster did hit,
we had it.

1275
01:08:58,030 --> 01:09:01,360
Now, how do we know that
they're gonna perform to that?

1276
01:09:02,470 --> 01:09:05,310
What if the disaster happens, and we go
and we say, all right send us the servers.

1277
01:09:05,310 --> 01:09:07,400
And they go,
oh actually they're on back-order.

1278
01:09:07,400 --> 01:09:10,550
Well, next day them to you
as we get them in six weeks.

1279
01:09:11,850 --> 01:09:13,840
And how do you know that
that's not gonna happen?

1280
01:09:13,840 --> 01:09:18,690
So you've gotta have that relationship,
but you've also gotta have penalties

1281
01:09:18,690 --> 01:09:24,780
drafted in that agreement that says,
if you don't, here's what's gonna happen.

1282
01:09:24,780 --> 01:09:27,220
You got to refund,

1283
01:09:27,220 --> 01:09:30,810
you got to have some kind of clause
in there to handle that, because

1284
01:09:30,810 --> 01:09:34,340
sometimes companies don't live up to what
they promised unless it is in a contract.

1285
01:09:35,950 --> 01:09:39,310
>> Maintaining the relationship with
the supplier will also depend on

1286
01:09:39,310 --> 01:09:42,060
how closely your aligned
with that supplier.

1287
01:09:42,060 --> 01:09:46,080
You may end up having what we call
strategic partners that you'll actually

1288
01:09:46,080 --> 01:09:50,740
team up with a lot more often than
somebody you'd call a commodity,

1289
01:09:50,740 --> 01:09:53,790
a type of supplier who
just provides you pieces,

1290
01:09:53,790 --> 01:09:56,170
but that you could get
the other piece somewhere else.

1291
01:09:56,170 --> 01:09:58,310
So depending on how you
see that relationship,

1292
01:09:58,310 --> 01:10:00,345
whether you're depending
on them heavily or

1293
01:10:00,345 --> 01:10:03,611
whether you're just kind of dependent
on them because they're cheap,

1294
01:10:03,611 --> 01:10:07,212
you're gonna see that your relationship's
gonna be different with each one.

1295
01:10:07,212 --> 01:10:10,331
>> Yeah, so at this phase,
when we're doing service design,

1296
01:10:10,331 --> 01:10:14,850
what we're really worried about here
is just general contract management.

1297
01:10:14,850 --> 01:10:17,200
How we're going to manage the contracts?

1298
01:10:17,200 --> 01:10:20,420
So we need to find that way for how we're
going to be monitoring these people,

1299
01:10:20,420 --> 01:10:23,130
interacting with these people,
entering into contracts?

1300
01:10:23,130 --> 01:10:24,510
Once the contract is in place,

1301
01:10:24,510 --> 01:10:28,820
how we insure that we're living up to our
part and they're living up to their part?

1302
01:10:28,820 --> 01:10:31,890
And more importantly,
when the contract is done,

1303
01:10:32,890 --> 01:10:35,540
how we verify that it is done and
terminated?

1304
01:10:35,540 --> 01:10:38,740
Because you don't want to end up
into a situation where you think

1305
01:10:38,740 --> 01:10:43,180
the contract is over and
they think it isn't or vice versa.

1306
01:10:43,180 --> 01:10:48,430
And work continues to happen or billing
continues to happen when it shouldn't.

1307
01:10:48,430 --> 01:10:53,040
I think we've probably all had that at
some point where you cancel an account and

1308
01:10:53,040 --> 01:10:55,066
then you still get billed-
>> Another bill, yup.

1309
01:10:55,066 --> 01:10:55,810
>> After the cancellation.

1310
01:10:55,810 --> 01:10:57,000
Right?
It happens and

1311
01:10:57,000 --> 01:11:00,640
that's exactly what's going on
is you've got a contract that

1312
01:11:00,640 --> 01:11:03,230
one side believes is terminated,
the other side doesn't.

1313
01:11:03,230 --> 01:11:05,460
And usually very easy to resolve that,

1314
01:11:05,460 --> 01:11:07,660
people don't normally
give you grief over it.

1315
01:11:07,660 --> 01:11:10,900
But you have to be monitoring
to ensure that hasn't happened,

1316
01:11:10,900 --> 01:11:11,950
that people understand.

1317
01:11:11,950 --> 01:11:15,400
So that's all part of general contract
management, and you probably,

1318
01:11:15,400 --> 01:11:18,700
in your organization,
already have a legal team or

1319
01:11:18,700 --> 01:11:21,730
someone who specifically handles
the contract management piece.

1320
01:11:21,730 --> 01:11:24,240
So with ITIL we don't
necessarily replace that,

1321
01:11:24,240 --> 01:11:27,510
we integrate,
we get them in to our design process.

1322
01:11:27,510 --> 01:11:29,583
And we say okay,
what do we need to do here?

1323
01:11:29,583 --> 01:11:32,390
As part of this new service we're
going to enter in to a few contracts.

1324
01:11:32,390 --> 01:11:33,950
So what do we need to plan for?

1325
01:11:33,950 --> 01:11:37,529
And that contract management team
or- There's a few different names it

1326
01:11:37,529 --> 01:11:38,280
might have.

1327
01:11:38,280 --> 01:11:39,570
Procurement team.

1328
01:11:39,570 --> 01:11:42,325
Procurement management is
another popular name for it.

1329
01:11:42,325 --> 01:11:43,600
That they will give you the advice.

1330
01:11:43,600 --> 01:11:48,381
They'll give you the recommendation of
how your company handles those contracts.

1331
01:11:48,381 --> 01:11:52,395
Now no one of these processes
is terribly effective by itself.

1332
01:11:52,395 --> 01:11:57,505
So all eight of these processes that we
just covered are really what makes up

1333
01:11:57,505 --> 01:11:59,065
service design.

1334
01:11:59,065 --> 01:12:02,815
All of this really just
boils down to good planning.

1335
01:12:02,815 --> 01:12:06,725
We plan for what's gonna to happen in the
future, as we roll out this service and

1336
01:12:06,725 --> 01:12:09,735
we plan for how we're going to manage
the service while it's running,

1337
01:12:09,735 --> 01:12:11,595
and we'll be successful.

1338
01:12:11,595 --> 01:12:15,030
Or we've at least increased our
odds of becoming successful.

1339
01:12:15,030 --> 01:12:16,170
Always remember that.

1340
01:12:16,170 --> 01:12:18,980
If your service is junk then it's not
going to be the most successful no matter

1341
01:12:18,980 --> 01:12:20,320
how well you plan.

1342
01:12:20,320 --> 01:12:21,980
But if it's a good service and

1343
01:12:21,980 --> 01:12:27,070
you put proper planning behind it, then
your odds of success are gonna be higher.

1344
01:12:27,070 --> 01:12:27,710
>> Yeah.

1345
01:12:27,710 --> 01:12:31,740
The nice thing about following these
service design processes that we've talked

1346
01:12:31,740 --> 01:12:36,000
about is it also ensures that you've
covered all the major areas that you need,

1347
01:12:36,000 --> 01:12:37,910
and that you didn't leave anything out.

1348
01:12:37,910 --> 01:12:41,840
So, even if you go, well, I think I can
do most of it, that's perfectly fine.

1349
01:12:41,840 --> 01:12:44,580
You can leave out certain pieces
that are already taken care of.

1350
01:12:44,580 --> 01:12:48,270
But overall, make sure you follow
all the processes, and that way

1351
01:12:48,270 --> 01:12:52,030
you're not sitting there after the design
going, I didn't even consider that.

1352
01:12:52,030 --> 01:12:56,960
So it's a very great part, a good part,
of what will help build your IT service.

1353
01:12:58,662 --> 01:13:02,920
>> All right, well that pretty much
boils it all down for service designs.

1354
01:13:02,920 --> 01:13:04,700
We're gonna wrap that one up here.

1355
01:13:04,700 --> 01:13:06,840
You know,
we still have several other areas to get.

1356
01:13:06,840 --> 01:13:11,468
I think we've got service transition next,
which is once we've done our design,

1357
01:13:11,468 --> 01:13:15,169
it's time to get the service actually
ready and get it produced and

1358
01:13:15,169 --> 01:13:17,236
ready to move over into production.

1359
01:13:17,236 --> 01:13:20,057
So that's kind of our next
stage that we move into.

1360
01:13:20,057 --> 01:13:22,820
But for now, this is a pretty
good spot to wrap up our show.

1361
01:13:22,820 --> 01:13:26,779
So let me remind you guys,
if you have questions on anything that we

1362
01:13:26,779 --> 01:13:30,967
talked about, live during the show,
you can go to itpro.tv/live.

1363
01:13:30,967 --> 01:13:33,660
And you'll see a chat box
right beneath the video.

1364
01:13:33,660 --> 01:13:34,640
Post your questions there.

1365
01:13:34,640 --> 01:13:36,870
We monitor and answer during the show.

1366
01:13:36,870 --> 01:13:38,030
If you go there and we're not live,

1367
01:13:38,030 --> 01:13:40,910
if it's showing reruns,
well, use our Q&A forum.

1368
01:13:40,910 --> 01:13:43,850
At the top of every page you'll
see a link that says Q&A and

1369
01:13:43,850 --> 01:13:46,110
you can jump in there and
post your questions.

1370
01:13:46,110 --> 01:13:48,290
We monitor and answer after the show.

1371
01:13:48,290 --> 01:13:52,382
So one way or another we'll get you the
answers to the questions that you have.

1372
01:13:52,382 --> 01:13:54,500
All right,
well I hope you guys enjoyed the show.

1373
01:13:54,500 --> 01:13:56,850
Signing off for ITProTV I'm Don Pezet.

1374
01:13:56,850 --> 01:13:59,250
