1142
01:00:05,270 --> 01:00:07,370
But if you're declined,
this is the end of your journey.

1143
01:00:07,370 --> 01:00:09,450
Step three you don't even
go to the other steps.

1144
01:00:09,450 --> 01:00:11,410
That's it, it's over.

1145
01:00:11,410 --> 01:00:16,160
So many organizations implement
another option, which is deferred.

1146
01:00:16,160 --> 01:00:18,300
And what you want to call it is up to you.

1147
01:00:18,300 --> 01:00:20,340
But deferred just simply means.

1148
01:00:20,340 --> 01:00:24,420
We either need more information, that
a pretty common one, or we need to adjust

1149
01:00:24,420 --> 01:00:27,720
that schedule, or whatever component it is
that we need to make some modifications.

1150
01:00:27,720 --> 01:00:30,250
And so
typically it would be like a notes column.

1151
01:00:30,250 --> 01:00:31,750
If it's deferred, here's why.

1152
01:00:31,750 --> 01:00:33,340
Or if it's declined, here's why.

1153
01:00:33,340 --> 01:00:35,910
But authorized,
that's what we care about, right?

1154
01:00:35,910 --> 01:00:39,320
That's where we're saying all right,
this change is going to be approved and

1155
01:00:39,320 --> 01:00:40,990
ready to move forward.

1156
01:00:40,990 --> 01:00:45,390
And once it's ready, Now we go into
the fourth step which is prioritize,

1157
01:00:45,390 --> 01:00:48,970
there is likely other changes
that are pending in the system.

1158
01:00:48,970 --> 01:00:52,502
And so we need to prioritize
this change against the other.

1159
01:00:52,502 --> 01:00:58,050
If there's resource conflicts, which
changes get access to the resources first,

1160
01:00:58,050 --> 01:01:01,362
and usually this is handdled through
some kind of classification system.

1161
01:01:01,362 --> 01:01:03,950
So you'll have a high priority changes and

1162
01:01:03,950 --> 01:01:06,800
low priority changes and
critical and so on.

1163
01:01:06,800 --> 01:01:09,600
And so when you fill out
the RFC you might suggest that.

1164
01:01:09,600 --> 01:01:12,810
This is a high-priority change.

1165
01:01:12,810 --> 01:01:16,100
We need to get this done because we're
patching, maybe it's a critical,

1166
01:01:16,100 --> 01:01:20,280
this is a security flaw, it's critical
we fix this as soon as possible.

1167
01:01:20,280 --> 01:01:23,610
Well, The people that review
this back in evaluation,

1168
01:01:23,610 --> 01:01:26,470
they may choose to change that priority.

1169
01:01:26,470 --> 01:01:28,020
And that's their discretion,

1170
01:01:28,020 --> 01:01:30,770
they can do that because the change
itself isn't being modified.

1171
01:01:30,770 --> 01:01:32,100
Just the priority.

1172
01:01:32,100 --> 01:01:37,040
And so now we're prioritizing that, and
making sure that the really critical stuff

1173
01:01:37,040 --> 01:01:41,260
gets the resources first, and then the
less critical changes can be moved off.

1174
01:01:42,260 --> 01:01:44,888
>> Because changes are always
happening within our organization,

1175
01:01:44,888 --> 01:01:48,690
we may also need to do what we
call planning the change out.

1176
01:01:48,690 --> 01:01:52,420
That normally requires us to be
able to coordinate the resources

1177
01:01:52,420 --> 01:01:56,410
that are available, to actually know
what we're actually working on.

1178
01:01:56,410 --> 01:01:59,810
But then to make sure that we
also schedule everything so

1179
01:01:59,810 --> 01:02:03,610
that we know when it's happening and
what's going on and everything.

1180
01:02:03,610 --> 01:02:06,294
So that our organization is not
overburdened on one particular day as

1181
01:02:06,294 --> 01:02:07,227
the change is going on.

1182
01:02:07,227 --> 01:02:11,378
>> It's basically like a miniature
project at that point.

1183
01:02:11,378 --> 01:02:13,700
So you kind of engage with
your products management team.

1184
01:02:13,700 --> 01:02:16,090
Say here's this change that we're
going to go ahead and implement.

1185
01:02:16,090 --> 01:02:17,560
People don't normally designate it.

1186
01:02:17,560 --> 01:02:18,510
It's like a full project.

1187
01:02:18,510 --> 01:02:20,340
But that's kind of like how it's treated.

1188
01:02:20,340 --> 01:02:22,110
Once that's done we're ready to test,
right.

1189
01:02:22,110 --> 01:02:27,510
I know that whoever submitted
this RFC did some basic testing.

1190
01:02:27,510 --> 01:02:29,400
But now we really need to test it again.

1191
01:02:29,400 --> 01:02:32,110
All right, we need to take this change and
test it out,

1192
01:02:32,110 --> 01:02:36,200
and you can't do that in production,
and so most environments, or

1193
01:02:36,200 --> 01:02:38,950
most organizations,
will have several environments.

1194
01:02:38,950 --> 01:02:42,890
And it depends, right,
you can have many, many different ones,

1195
01:02:42,890 --> 01:02:48,380
a lot of people will at a minimum have
a production and a test environment.

1196
01:02:48,380 --> 01:02:51,360
And that test environment may
be a mirror of production.

1197
01:02:51,360 --> 01:02:54,970
So they are basically the same
environments, but your customers are on

1198
01:02:54,970 --> 01:02:58,940
the production environment, and
no one is on the testing environment.

1199
01:02:58,940 --> 01:03:01,890
So you can make the change in tests and
see how it goes.

1200
01:03:01,890 --> 01:03:05,010
Maybe it works great and
we're ready to roll it in production.

1201
01:03:05,010 --> 01:03:08,350
Maybe it doesn't work great,
and now we stop.

1202
01:03:08,350 --> 01:03:11,740
Now, You may just have two environments,
you may have many, many,

1203
01:03:11,740 --> 01:03:12,730
many environments.

1204
01:03:12,730 --> 01:03:15,060
It is not uncommon to have
five separate environments.

1205
01:03:15,060 --> 01:03:21,750
As an example,
I'll use the last company I worked in.

1206
01:03:21,750 --> 01:03:26,090
We had five different environments
there where we had a sandbox.

1207
01:03:26,090 --> 01:03:29,090
And a sandbox environment
it contained our software.

1208
01:03:29,090 --> 01:03:31,840
The main line of business applications for
our company.

1209
01:03:31,840 --> 01:03:34,920
And the developers were allowed
to use it to experiment with.

1210
01:03:34,920 --> 01:03:35,700
They could connect in.

1211
01:03:35,700 --> 01:03:37,580
They could do whatever
they wanted in sandbox.

1212
01:03:37,580 --> 01:03:38,520
We didn't care.

1213
01:03:38,520 --> 01:03:42,640
And every night at midnight the sandbox
environment was destroyed and rebuilt.

1214
01:03:42,640 --> 01:03:46,130
And so it always went to back to
new each day, as we went forward.

1215
01:03:46,130 --> 01:03:47,230
And they did experimentation there.

1216
01:03:48,250 --> 01:03:49,610
That was Sandbox.

1217
01:03:49,610 --> 01:03:53,520
Then there was the development
environment, or the dev environment.

1218
01:03:53,520 --> 01:03:57,470
And once they had experimented, and
come up with some kind of idea they liked,

1219
01:03:57,470 --> 01:04:00,800
the actual development for
it happened in the dev environment.

1220
01:04:00,800 --> 01:04:04,445
And the dev environment had
a lot of our software, but

1221
01:04:04,445 --> 01:04:07,043
not necessarily live customer data.

1222
01:04:07,043 --> 01:04:08,238
You're in development, so

1223
01:04:08,238 --> 01:04:11,042
you don't necessarily have all
the security protocols in place.

1224
01:04:11,042 --> 01:04:15,924
So you don't want copies of your live data
in there, you could accidentally leak it

1225
01:04:15,924 --> 01:04:19,969
So the dev environment was our
software but packed full of fake data,

1226
01:04:19,969 --> 01:04:24,600
fake accounts and users and just fake
information for the development cycle.

1227
01:04:26,520 --> 01:04:30,350
After development, when a developer had
completed what they were working on,

1228
01:04:30,350 --> 01:04:35,430
the next environment was the QA
environment, the quality assurance.

1229
01:04:35,430 --> 01:04:37,130
Some people call it quality control.

1230
01:04:37,130 --> 01:04:38,800
There's different names for it.

1231
01:04:38,800 --> 01:04:42,783
But it would then go in to the QA
environment where people would review it.

1232
01:04:42,783 --> 01:04:46,114
They would take what the developer did,
throw it on the QA environment and

1233
01:04:46,114 --> 01:04:46,770
evaluate it.

1234
01:04:46,770 --> 01:04:48,500
And if they found bugs, flaws,

1235
01:04:48,500 --> 01:04:52,120
anything that didn't meet our policies,
it would go back to dev.

1236
01:04:52,120 --> 01:04:56,280
But if it passed there,
the next environment was staging.

1237
01:04:56,280 --> 01:05:01,410
Now our staging environment
was an exact mirror

1238
01:05:01,410 --> 01:05:04,900
of the last environment,
which was our production environment.

1239
01:05:04,900 --> 01:05:06,360
Every night at midnight,

1240
01:05:06,360 --> 01:05:09,970
our production environment was
cloned to the staging environment.

1241
01:05:09,970 --> 01:05:13,860
And that way, when we had a change
that was ready to roll out,

1242
01:05:13,860 --> 01:05:18,250
we could deploy it in staging and
just do a final check.

1243
01:05:18,250 --> 01:05:19,590
And here's where it was a mirror.

1244
01:05:19,590 --> 01:05:22,680
It had our actual customer data,
our actual environment.

1245
01:05:22,680 --> 01:05:27,090
It was server for server, the exact
same hardware, the exact same version.

1246
01:05:27,090 --> 01:05:29,270
Everything was exact as production.

1247
01:05:29,270 --> 01:05:30,350
So we could deploy the change,

1248
01:05:30,350 --> 01:05:33,580
and if something went wrong,
it didn't affect production.

1249
01:05:33,580 --> 01:05:36,540
So a lot of what we talked about earlier,
as far as validating the change,

1250
01:05:36,540 --> 01:05:39,280
could actually happen before
we've even touched production.

1251
01:05:39,280 --> 01:05:41,950
And then once everything was green there,

1252
01:05:41,950 --> 01:05:47,610
once we tested out okay, then we
repeated the deployment in production.

1253
01:05:47,610 --> 01:05:48,610
Five separate environments.

1254
01:05:48,610 --> 01:05:52,874
That's a lot of equipment and a lot to
maintain, but if you want a secure and

1255
01:05:52,874 --> 01:05:55,533
stable environment, then you do it, right?

1256
01:05:55,533 --> 01:05:58,330
I mean, there's no argument against it.

1257
01:05:58,330 --> 01:06:02,950
The sandbox, the dev, the QA environments,
they were all virtual machines.

1258
01:06:02,950 --> 01:06:04,120
That wasn't a big deal.

1259
01:06:04,120 --> 01:06:05,530
It wasn't until you got to staging and

1260
01:06:05,530 --> 01:06:07,480
production that it became
physical machines.

1261
01:06:07,480 --> 01:06:12,030
But even then, a lot of them are VMs on
top of those, so it really wasn't that

1262
01:06:12,030 --> 01:06:14,180
bad to set up this kind of environment,
and that's very common.

1263
01:06:14,180 --> 01:06:17,580
So when we talk about that test here,

1264
01:06:17,580 --> 01:06:20,470
after the ROC has already been deployed,
that's what we're talking about.

1265
01:06:20,470 --> 01:06:23,150
Running it through that staging
type environment to make sure

1266
01:06:23,150 --> 01:06:24,310
that it's not gonna affect production.

1267
01:06:25,710 --> 01:06:29,150
>> Our seventh process here
is gonna be implementation.

1268
01:06:29,150 --> 01:06:33,310
This is us really just doing
the work that we say we're gonna do.

1269
01:06:33,310 --> 01:06:36,550
Making sure that the change happens
according to all the process and

1270
01:06:36,550 --> 01:06:39,910
the steps that we actually said
we're going to make sure that we do.

1271
01:06:39,910 --> 01:06:43,950
And once we get it in, then we're
beginning to monitor it to make sure that

1272
01:06:43,950 --> 01:06:46,700
we carried out all the steps,
but it's working.

1273
01:06:46,700 --> 01:06:52,230
>> And now implement is just
actually putting it in production.

1274
01:06:52,230 --> 01:06:56,350
So any events that you had planned to
affect production, if you were gonna take

1275
01:06:56,350 --> 01:07:00,540
your system down for maintenance while you
did this change, that's what happens here.

1276
01:07:00,540 --> 01:07:03,990
And once it's done,
your next step is to document.

1277
01:07:03,990 --> 01:07:06,690
You document how it went,
document the change.

1278
01:07:06,690 --> 01:07:09,190
Now document also goes a step further.

1279
01:07:09,190 --> 01:07:12,510
You have business continuity plans,
business resumption plans,

1280
01:07:12,510 --> 01:07:15,560
all this other documentation that
centers around your product.

1281
01:07:15,560 --> 01:07:16,970
It all needs to be updated,

1282
01:07:16,970 --> 01:07:20,630
updated to reflect this change
as part of your new baseline.

1283
01:07:20,630 --> 01:07:24,932
A baseline is really just kind of
a captured configuration that says here's

1284
01:07:24,932 --> 01:07:27,158
how my system is configured right now.

1285
01:07:27,158 --> 01:07:29,440
Now that I've put the change in,
that baseline changes.

1286
01:07:29,440 --> 01:07:32,940
So we take this new baseline,
this new set of documentation.

1287
01:07:32,940 --> 01:07:34,780
It's normally just a couple
little modifications we have to

1288
01:07:34,780 --> 01:07:35,540
make to tweak that.

1289
01:07:35,540 --> 01:07:39,120
But that's a part of that eighth step,
which leads us to the end.

1290
01:07:39,120 --> 01:07:41,300
>> Yeah, last step is review.

1291
01:07:41,300 --> 01:07:44,770
This is when, if we've submitted this
change to someone and they've authorized

1292
01:07:44,770 --> 01:07:49,270
it, they now take the entire process
of the change that we've submitted.

1293
01:07:49,270 --> 01:07:52,419
They go through and
look at everything that we've done, and

1294
01:07:52,419 --> 01:07:56,428
they review it, to be able to learn from
it, to be able to actually go, okay,

1295
01:07:56,428 --> 01:07:57,809
it didn't go all smooth.

1296
01:07:57,809 --> 01:07:59,548
What can we do to make it better?

1297
01:07:59,548 --> 01:08:01,956
And then just to make
sure it's documented and

1298
01:08:01,956 --> 01:08:04,681
that everything is actually
the way we need it to be.

1299
01:08:04,681 --> 01:08:07,636
>> Now I think you can start to see
where if you're a small company,

1300
01:08:07,636 --> 01:08:09,410
this looks like a lot of bureaucracy.

1301
01:08:09,410 --> 01:08:12,785
This looks like a lot
of steps to go through.

1302
01:08:12,785 --> 01:08:16,460
And so a lot of companies that are small,
small development teams or

1303
01:08:16,460 --> 01:08:19,570
whatever, will just forgo this process,
and say, you know what?

1304
01:08:19,570 --> 01:08:22,271
Screw it, I'm just gonna make changes in
production, and if something goes wrong I

1305
01:08:22,271 --> 01:08:24,533
can just tell the other guys,
they're right here in the room with me.

1306
01:08:24,533 --> 01:08:27,595
You can do that if you've got
a small customer base and

1307
01:08:27,595 --> 01:08:32,010
you're not too terribly worried
about your user experience, right?

1308
01:08:32,010 --> 01:08:35,760
So companies that brand a product as
beta and release it to the public?

1309
01:08:35,760 --> 01:08:39,630
Those are companies that are probably
not enforcing good change management.

1310
01:08:39,630 --> 01:08:43,150
They're letting their customers
do the testing for them.

1311
01:08:43,150 --> 01:08:45,700
But that's not what most companies want.

1312
01:08:45,700 --> 01:08:48,696
If you want to scale, if you want to
grow to be a large organization or

1313
01:08:48,696 --> 01:08:50,799
if you already are,
if you're an enterprise or

1314
01:08:50,799 --> 01:08:54,130
a multinational organization,
you can't afford to do things like that.

1315
01:08:55,860 --> 01:08:59,117
Outages that your customers experience,
that's high-visibility stuff.

1316
01:08:59,117 --> 01:09:03,010
It affects your public image,
and so we can't have that.

1317
01:09:03,010 --> 01:09:07,200
So when we come up with a methodology
like this, the steps that we go through,

1318
01:09:07,200 --> 01:09:11,720
whatever your company decides is the right
amount of steps for your change system,

1319
01:09:11,720 --> 01:09:17,080
it's super important that it be enforced,
that no one be allowed to

1320
01:09:17,080 --> 01:09:22,200
bypass the change system because
really it negates the whole thing.

1321
01:09:22,200 --> 01:09:24,970
If you have one person that's allowed
to make changes in the production

1322
01:09:24,970 --> 01:09:28,870
environment, then you might as well not
even have the change system at all, right?

1323
01:09:28,870 --> 01:09:31,100
Because you're over here evaluating and

1324
01:09:31,100 --> 01:09:34,900
approving changes, but you don't even know
what the actual production environment

1325
01:09:34,900 --> 01:09:38,200
looks like anymore because this other
person's able to make direct changes.

1326
01:09:38,200 --> 01:09:39,366
So you can't have that.

1327
01:09:39,366 --> 01:09:42,176
You've gotta maintain those separate
systems and you've gotta control it, and

1328
01:09:42,176 --> 01:09:44,090
that requires a lot of monitoring.

1329
01:09:44,090 --> 01:09:48,740
Now the way we control is typically
through the use of something Ronnie

1330
01:09:48,740 --> 01:09:51,450
mentioned earlier which is
a change advisory board.

1331
01:09:51,450 --> 01:09:53,770
And there's a lot we need
to talk about with that and

1332
01:09:53,770 --> 01:09:57,360
I know we're short on time on this
segment, so let's stop at that thought.

1333
01:09:57,360 --> 01:10:01,220
We'll kind of put a pin in it or
whatever and take a break.

1334
01:10:01,220 --> 01:10:04,840
And when we get back, we'll talk about
that change advisory board, what it is,

1335
01:10:04,840 --> 01:10:05,990
how it works and

1336
01:10:05,990 --> 01:10:09,340
ways that you can implement it in
your environment to control change.

1337
01:10:09,340 --> 01:10:10,065
So stay tuned.

1338
01:10:10,065 --> 01:10:11,491
We'll be back in just a moment.

1339
01:10:11,491 --> 01:10:18,991
[MUSIC]

1340
01:10:18,991 --> 01:10:20,830
All right, welcome back everybody.

1341
01:10:20,830 --> 01:10:26,050
So we left off talking about change
management and how it has to be enforced.

1342
01:10:26,050 --> 01:10:31,000
And the way we do that is through
having a person or a group of people

1343
01:10:31,000 --> 01:10:34,380
who are the gatekeeper, who are actually
approving or declining the changes.

1344
01:10:34,380 --> 01:10:39,244
And that most commonly takes
the form of what's called a change

1345
01:10:39,244 --> 01:10:41,366
advisory board, or a CAB.

1346
01:10:41,366 --> 01:10:44,580
Now on the ITool exam,
you'll see it referred to as a CAB,

1347
01:10:44,580 --> 01:10:49,190
change advisory board, but there's other
names that you may see this fall under.

1348
01:10:49,190 --> 01:10:51,240
So some people don't call
it a change advisory board.

1349
01:10:51,240 --> 01:10:56,210
They might call it a change advisory
committee or a change control board, CCB.

1350
01:10:56,210 --> 01:10:58,020
I know I've worked in
environments like that.

1351
01:10:58,020 --> 01:10:59,350
The name doesn't really matter.

1352
01:10:59,350 --> 01:11:01,580
It's what they do that's important, right?

1353
01:11:01,580 --> 01:11:06,370
What it is is a group of people who
have the authority to approve or

1354
01:11:06,370 --> 01:11:07,810
decline the changes.

1355
01:11:07,810 --> 01:11:12,500
Now that act of approving a change,
that requires a good bit of knowledge.

1356
01:11:12,500 --> 01:11:15,460
And it's likely that the only
person who has that level of

1357
01:11:15,460 --> 01:11:18,480
knowledge is the person recommending
the change in the first place, and

1358
01:11:18,480 --> 01:11:21,180
they shouldn't get a vote cause they're
the ones recommending the change.

1359
01:11:21,180 --> 01:11:25,930
So the change advisory board is normally
made up of a cross-section of your

1360
01:11:25,930 --> 01:11:30,910
company, people from different
parts of the organization that

1361
01:11:30,910 --> 01:11:34,890
individually might not have all the
knowledge needed to approve or decline.

1362
01:11:34,890 --> 01:11:40,440
But combined, they come together
like Voltron and then they've

1363
01:11:40,440 --> 01:11:45,260
got that power to be able to make the
approval or decline and move from there.

1364
01:11:45,260 --> 01:11:49,840
So the change advisory board is
not normally just one person.

1365
01:11:49,840 --> 01:11:51,251
It can be, in a small company.

1366
01:11:51,251 --> 01:11:55,671
But normally you're gonna have several
people, even people that are outside of

1367
01:11:55,671 --> 01:11:59,246
the IT department, because you
need people from outside of the IT

1368
01:11:59,246 --> 01:12:03,536
department because they'll understand
the impact that's not technical but

1369
01:12:03,536 --> 01:12:07,458
maybe the impact on the regular users or
employees within the company.

1370
01:12:07,458 --> 01:12:08,570
>> Yeah.

1371
01:12:08,570 --> 01:12:12,125
In the ITIL guide that
you take a look at here.

1372
01:12:12,125 --> 01:12:17,984
They talk about it being a cross
representation of users and

1373
01:12:17,984 --> 01:12:20,400
customers at times.

1374
01:12:20,400 --> 01:12:24,550
So that you do see where the change
is going to impact not only them, but

1375
01:12:24,550 --> 01:12:27,850
also the other side of it, people
that are going to be implementing and

1376
01:12:27,850 --> 01:12:29,490
people that have technical
knowledge behind it.

1377
01:12:29,490 --> 01:12:33,150
So it is a nice cross section,
that is what i was trying to get to.

1378
01:12:33,150 --> 01:12:37,591
>> And these are your stake holders, and
stake holder we use it in ITIL the term

1379
01:12:37,591 --> 01:12:41,610
but it is really from project management
>> If the people have a vested

1380
01:12:41,610 --> 01:12:44,680
interest in the success of the company,
right?

1381
01:12:44,680 --> 01:12:48,150
The people who are moving our company
forward, and know that strategy,

1382
01:12:48,150 --> 01:12:51,650
so that they can evaluate these changes,
and determine whether they're in line

1383
01:12:51,650 --> 01:12:54,990
with the strategy,
whether they align with our company goals.

1384
01:12:54,990 --> 01:12:58,970
So, that is going to require
a good group of people.

1385
01:12:58,970 --> 01:13:02,686
And it might be five or six people,
you don't want it to be too large,

1386
01:13:02,686 --> 01:13:04,910
because that's going to slow
down the change process.

1387
01:13:04,910 --> 01:13:07,550
But you don't want to be too
small that you exclude certain

1388
01:13:07,550 --> 01:13:10,450
parts of your organization that
might have valuable feedback.

1389
01:13:10,450 --> 01:13:14,890
So, we have this committee, and what a lot
of organizations will do is say it is

1390
01:13:14,890 --> 01:13:16,850
hard to get that group of people together.

1391
01:13:16,850 --> 01:13:20,400
So, maybe once a week we
have a change meeting.

1392
01:13:20,400 --> 01:13:24,010
And so every Thursday,
we have a change advisory meeting and

1393
01:13:24,010 --> 01:13:27,240
it will be Thursday mornings,
build up whatever changes you have and

1394
01:13:27,240 --> 01:13:29,160
submit them on Thursdays, all right.

1395
01:13:29,160 --> 01:13:32,300
So if I come up with some new change,
I have got to wait until Thursday.

1396
01:13:32,300 --> 01:13:33,730
I can fill out the form today.

1397
01:13:33,730 --> 01:13:37,540
That’s fine and submit it, but
they won't meet until Thursday and

1398
01:13:37,540 --> 01:13:40,830
they'll make the decision and
depending on how your structure is,

1399
01:13:40,830 --> 01:13:43,890
you may or
may not want the submitter to be there.

1400
01:13:43,890 --> 01:13:47,020
I worked at one company where when
you filled out a change ticket,

1401
01:13:47,020 --> 01:13:51,040
you had to be there at the change
advisory meeting so you could provide and

1402
01:13:51,040 --> 01:13:54,060
additional answers to
questions that they had.

1403
01:13:54,060 --> 01:13:57,440
I've worked at other companies, though,
where they were far more strict.

1404
01:13:57,440 --> 01:13:59,940
And your RFC needed to be complete.

1405
01:13:59,940 --> 01:14:02,150
It needed to contain all the information.

1406
01:14:02,150 --> 01:14:05,070
And so when it went to the cab,
you weren't there.

1407
01:14:05,070 --> 01:14:07,910
And they approved or declined it
based on the information they had.

1408
01:14:07,910 --> 01:14:10,850
And if it didn't have enough information,
they would just defer it, send it right

1409
01:14:10,850 --> 01:14:14,580
back to you, and say resubmit next
week with this additional information.

1410
01:14:14,580 --> 01:14:19,090
Now that was a little disheartening,
because if there was something missing,

1411
01:14:19,090 --> 01:14:22,230
you had to wait another week to submit it.

1412
01:14:22,230 --> 01:14:26,080
And this is where people start to get
a little fidgety, and they say well, this

1413
01:14:26,080 --> 01:14:30,300
sounds like bureaucracy, this sounds like
it's going to slow my company down, right?

1414
01:14:30,300 --> 01:14:34,620
We want to be Agile, that's the big
buzz word everybody's excited about now.

1415
01:14:34,620 --> 01:14:39,460
Agile is different people have
different opinions on how Agile works,

1416
01:14:39,460 --> 01:14:42,440
when it's implemented right,
it allows you to make

1417
01:14:42,440 --> 01:14:46,510
minor changes without going
through a change approval process.

1418
01:14:46,510 --> 01:14:48,880
But they're minor changes,
they're not significant and

1419
01:14:48,880 --> 01:14:53,320
you agree to that in a stand up meeting
from what you can kind of expedite.

1420
01:14:53,320 --> 01:14:57,500
But critical changes still go
through the CAD, even under Agile.

1421
01:14:57,500 --> 01:15:00,270
What happens is a lot of
people implement Agile wrong.

1422
01:15:00,270 --> 01:15:02,970
And they say,
we can get rid of the CAD, and

1423
01:15:02,970 --> 01:15:04,450
just move all of our
changes through Agile.

1424
01:15:04,450 --> 01:15:06,300
So we have a quick standup
meeting every morning.

1425
01:15:06,300 --> 01:15:08,070
We say, here's the changes
I'm going to make today.

1426
01:15:08,070 --> 01:15:10,650
And everybody says well,
I guess that sounds okay, you know?

1427
01:15:10,650 --> 01:15:11,970
And you move forward.

1428
01:15:11,970 --> 01:15:15,160
And so Agile becomes a substitute for
proper planning.

1429
01:15:15,160 --> 01:15:18,310
When it's improperly deployed,
Agile can be really, really bad.

1430
01:15:18,310 --> 01:15:21,600
When it's deployed right,
it can actually be really useful.

1431
01:15:21,600 --> 01:15:23,940
It can take pressure off of your cab, and

1432
01:15:23,940 --> 01:15:27,110
it can make it where your company's able
to support itself much more quickly.

1433
01:15:27,110 --> 01:15:31,470
So If you're combining agile methodologies
with ITIL just be aware of that,

1434
01:15:31,470 --> 01:15:37,500
you've got to make sure that you set a
line between what has to go to the cab and

1435
01:15:37,500 --> 01:15:38,830
what doesn't.

1436
01:15:38,830 --> 01:15:41,220
But all the things that go to the cab,
these need to be reviewed.

1437
01:15:41,220 --> 01:15:43,990
These are changes to our product,
our production environment and

1438
01:15:43,990 --> 01:15:46,580
so we need to ensure that they're safe and
that

1439
01:15:46,580 --> 01:15:50,790
all of the proper planning went into it
before we approve it and roll it forward.

1440
01:15:50,790 --> 01:15:56,700
>> Sometimes changes happen or they need
to occur more immediately but the cab only

1441
01:15:56,700 --> 01:16:00,950
meets on every Thursday, or every other
Thursday if the company's really small.

1442
01:16:00,950 --> 01:16:06,530
So in the meantime, if we still want
to be able to still submit our changes,

1443
01:16:06,530 --> 01:16:09,840
we may actually end up be doing
it in an even smaller group.

1444
01:16:09,840 --> 01:16:15,370
Which IT calls that as being an emergency
change advisory board instead.

1445
01:16:15,370 --> 01:16:17,500
Yeah, the eCab, the emergency.

1446
01:16:17,500 --> 01:16:21,220
They're there because
sometimes you can't wait.

1447
01:16:21,220 --> 01:16:23,890
And the number one example of this
is going to be a security patch.

1448
01:16:23,890 --> 01:16:24,410
Right?

1449
01:16:24,410 --> 01:16:26,830
A new exploit is released in the wild,

1450
01:16:26,830 --> 01:16:30,790
or hopefully one of your testers
finds a potential exploit.

1451
01:16:30,790 --> 01:16:32,630
And so, they work up a patch for it, and

1452
01:16:32,630 --> 01:16:36,000
you need to patch that
as quickly as possible.

1453
01:16:36,000 --> 01:16:40,240
Well, if your CAB is made up of people
from all throughout the company,

1454
01:16:40,240 --> 01:16:43,020
if it's eight people and
they meet every Thursday,

1455
01:16:43,020 --> 01:16:47,190
you may not be able to get all eight of
them together for an emergency meeting.

1456
01:16:47,190 --> 01:16:52,310
So you create an emergency CAB so
when there is a security exploit or

1457
01:16:52,310 --> 01:16:55,880
some kind of high critical update
that needs to be pushed through,

1458
01:16:55,880 --> 01:17:01,800
you can convene this smaller advisory
board that may be really small.

1459
01:17:01,800 --> 01:17:05,050
It may just be the CIO,
the Chief Information Officer, right.

1460
01:17:05,050 --> 01:17:08,790
But, it'll be a smaller group, that you
can pull together at a moment's notice,

1461
01:17:08,790 --> 01:17:11,670
that may not meet formally in
a meeting room or whatever.

1462
01:17:11,670 --> 01:17:14,250
They might be by phone,
you do a three way conference call, or

1463
01:17:14,250 --> 01:17:16,700
something to get these people together.

1464
01:17:16,700 --> 01:17:20,850
Remotely and approve that change so
you can make a rapid response.

1465
01:17:20,850 --> 01:17:25,280
But notice even though it's an emergency,
we still go through the cab.

1466
01:17:25,280 --> 01:17:27,058
There's still an approval process.

1467
01:17:27,058 --> 01:17:31,343
The e-cab, what they're going to do,
is they're going to determine,

1468
01:17:31,343 --> 01:17:34,495
is this actually an emergency,
or can it wait?

1469
01:17:34,495 --> 01:17:37,840
Because sometimes IT guys and
security professionals,

1470
01:17:37,840 --> 01:17:41,890
we get a little ahead of ourselves,
a little extra excitement.

1471
01:17:41,890 --> 01:17:43,730
And so,
it might be something that can wait.

1472
01:17:43,730 --> 01:17:47,412
And so, we make that determination
inside of the ECAB and

1473
01:17:47,412 --> 01:17:53,580
then if it is an emergency, if it truly is
critical then they're going to approve it.

1474
01:17:53,580 --> 01:17:54,500
It's critical, right?

1475
01:17:54,500 --> 01:17:56,100
It is rare that you decline it.

1476
01:17:56,100 --> 01:17:58,150
So they're going to approve it but

1477
01:17:58,150 --> 01:18:00,830
they'll double check to make sure
that the information is correct.

1478
01:18:00,830 --> 01:18:01,400
Right?

1479
01:18:01,400 --> 01:18:03,230
Have we done any testing yet?

1480
01:18:03,230 --> 01:18:04,040
We know this is critical.

1481
01:18:04,040 --> 01:18:07,530
We know we need to roll it out but
we still need to test it because

1482
01:18:07,530 --> 01:18:11,670
even though it's critical if it breaks out
product or changes the user experience.

1483
01:18:11,670 --> 01:18:12,840
We need to be able communicate that.

1484
01:18:12,840 --> 01:18:15,580
We need to have contingency
plans that it plays to.

1485
01:18:15,580 --> 01:18:18,280
So you still have to do planning.

1486
01:18:18,280 --> 01:18:20,580
Microsoft rolls out security updates.

1487
01:18:20,580 --> 01:18:25,330
Critical security updates on the first
Thursday or second Tuesday of the month?

1488
01:18:25,330 --> 01:18:26,270
>> Shoot.
>> I always mix that one up.

1489
01:18:26,270 --> 01:18:28,700
It's either the first Tuesday or
the second Tuesday of every month.

1490
01:18:28,700 --> 01:18:30,830
So they roll these out monthly.

1491
01:18:30,830 --> 01:18:33,740
Well if there's a critical one
they'll rush out right away,

1492
01:18:33,740 --> 01:18:35,660
so you might get it in
the middle of the month, but

1493
01:18:35,660 --> 01:18:38,970
even Microsoft says don't deploy
this right into production,

1494
01:18:38,970 --> 01:18:42,545
you need to deploy it as soon as you can,
but test it on your systems.

1495
01:18:42,545 --> 01:18:44,805
Make sure it doesn't break your software.

1496
01:18:44,805 --> 01:18:47,925
If it breaks your software you've got to
reach out to the software development

1497
01:18:47,925 --> 01:18:49,475
team, and find out what you
need to do to patch that.

1498
01:18:49,475 --> 01:18:53,375
So just because it's critical
doesn't mean rush head long into it.

1499
01:18:53,375 --> 01:18:54,915
>> [LAUGH]
>> You've still got to do

1500
01:18:54,915 --> 01:18:57,515
your due diligence to get that approved.

1501
01:18:57,515 --> 01:19:00,215
>> James says it's the second Tuesday
of every month from our system.

1502
01:19:00,215 --> 01:19:01,345
>> Thank you chat room.

1503
01:19:01,345 --> 01:19:02,070
Awesome.

1504
01:19:02,070 --> 01:19:04,560
Now, in most of the environments
I've worked in,

1505
01:19:04,560 --> 01:19:09,660
the ECAB really wasn't a separate
advisory board, it was just

1506
01:19:09,660 --> 01:19:14,690
a selection of the people in the main CAB,
so everybody in the ECAB was in the CAB,

1507
01:19:14,690 --> 01:19:19,250
in the full change advisory board and
you just had particular people.

1508
01:19:19,250 --> 01:19:21,540
One company I worked for,
we actually had designated members.

1509
01:19:21,540 --> 01:19:25,260
There were eight people in the cab, and
there were three of them that were on

1510
01:19:25,260 --> 01:19:29,180
the emergency cab, and so if there was
ever an emergency, those were the three

1511
01:19:29,180 --> 01:19:32,970
people that we contacted to get approval
for the change to move it through.

1512
01:19:32,970 --> 01:19:35,130
There was another company I worked for

1513
01:19:35,130 --> 01:19:38,950
though that didn't nail down
to a particular person.

1514
01:19:38,950 --> 01:19:41,770
They said the CAB has eight people.

1515
01:19:41,770 --> 01:19:47,280
If there's an emergency, you can just get
approval from five of them, a majority.

1516
01:19:47,280 --> 01:19:50,050
If you can get approval from five
of them go ahead and roll forward.

1517
01:19:50,050 --> 01:19:52,970
And that left us where if there were
three people that we just couldn't reach

1518
01:19:52,970 --> 01:19:53,550
by phone.

1519
01:19:53,550 --> 01:19:56,418
That it was okay,
we could move without their approval.

1520
01:19:56,418 --> 01:20:00,226
So your e-cab may not be a separate
entity all together, but

1521
01:20:00,226 --> 01:20:03,150
simply a division of the existing cab.

1522
01:20:03,150 --> 01:20:06,360
It's up to the amount of risk that
your company is willing to tolerate.

1523
01:20:06,360 --> 01:20:09,977
What you don't wanna end up with
is having an emergency change and

1524
01:20:09,977 --> 01:20:13,260
not being able to reach out
to the necessary people.

1525
01:20:13,260 --> 01:20:16,670
So the people that are on the e-cab
need to have cell phones.

1526
01:20:16,670 --> 01:20:21,652
They need to be prepared to
answer that phone at any time.

1527
01:20:21,652 --> 01:20:25,160
Especially if you've got service
level agreements that you gotta meet.

1528
01:20:25,160 --> 01:20:31,310
Now if you don't have SLA's, if you're
a company like, I work for a bank, where

1529
01:20:31,310 --> 01:20:35,120
there really wasn't any business that we
conducted overnight or on the weekends.

1530
01:20:35,120 --> 01:20:37,900
And so in those cases the e-cab
might not be available at night,

1531
01:20:37,900 --> 01:20:41,130
they might not be available on the weekend
cuz we're not really doing business then.

1532
01:20:41,130 --> 01:20:45,290
So this may be a 24/7 type requirement or

1533
01:20:45,290 --> 01:20:48,949
it might be something much less,
it does boil down to your organization.

1534
01:20:50,592 --> 01:20:56,150
All right, now that kind of leads
us into the three types of RFC's.

1535
01:20:56,150 --> 01:21:00,060
When you submit a request for change,
we'll normally categorize them.

1536
01:21:00,060 --> 01:21:02,820
And there's are all sorts of categories
that you can create that are unique to

1537
01:21:02,820 --> 01:21:03,800
your business.

1538
01:21:03,800 --> 01:21:06,810
But there are three main categories
that ITIL recommends for everyone.

1539
01:21:08,040 --> 01:21:10,610
And these are the categories
that are gonna determine

1540
01:21:10,610 --> 01:21:14,730
where this RFC needs to go or if the RFC
even needs to happen in the first place.

1541
01:21:14,730 --> 01:21:17,680
So these are three categories of changes.

1542
01:21:19,060 --> 01:21:22,770
>> The first category of change that we
have is just the regular standard change.

1543
01:21:22,770 --> 01:21:26,060
This type of change is
a preauthorized change

1544
01:21:26,060 --> 01:21:29,900
that really happens just about every day,
or weekly.

1545
01:21:29,900 --> 01:21:33,890
In other words, it's routine work
that's being done for organizations.

1546
01:21:33,890 --> 01:21:41,080
So we think about maybe just a change in
backups, or maybe something like that?

1547
01:21:41,080 --> 01:21:42,475
>> Well, backups are sensitive, right?

1548
01:21:42,475 --> 01:21:44,990
>> Yeah. Right. >> That's kinda like
holy ground, you don't mess with that.

1549
01:21:44,990 --> 01:21:49,920
This would be just an ongoing activity, so
something like you hire a new employee.

1550
01:21:49,920 --> 01:21:51,590
So we just hired a new employee.

1551
01:21:51,590 --> 01:21:53,360
They need a user account, don't they?

1552
01:21:53,360 --> 01:21:57,920
So I've gotta go into our, let's say we
have the Windows active directory, and

1553
01:21:57,920 --> 01:21:59,470
create a user account.

1554
01:21:59,470 --> 01:22:00,500
Well that's a change.

1555
01:22:00,500 --> 01:22:02,260
I just changed the directory.

1556
01:22:02,260 --> 01:22:04,030
But it's such a minor change.

1557
01:22:04,030 --> 01:22:05,540
It's adding a user.

1558
01:22:05,540 --> 01:22:08,560
What damage could I do adding a user?

1559
01:22:08,560 --> 01:22:11,150
Well I could accidentally give them
more permissions than they should have.

1560
01:22:11,150 --> 01:22:13,090
There are mistakes that can be made.

1561
01:22:13,090 --> 01:22:17,805
But it's not gonna bring my system down
and so those are preauthorized changes.

1562
01:22:17,805 --> 01:22:23,420
Where as we create our service
transition model we say,

1563
01:22:23,420 --> 01:22:27,500
all right creating a user account,
resetting your account's password.

1564
01:22:27,500 --> 01:22:32,030
If somebody's last name changes,
modifying that, those are minor changes,

1565
01:22:32,030 --> 01:22:36,550
they're preauthorized, you don't need to
submit a request for a change, right?

1566
01:22:36,550 --> 01:22:38,120
You don't even have to
fill out the paperwork.

1567
01:22:38,120 --> 01:22:41,450
You're allowed to just go in and
make that change.

1568
01:22:41,450 --> 01:22:44,190
Don't involve the cab,
don't even fill out the RFC.

1569
01:22:44,190 --> 01:22:48,110
You might have other paperwork that you
fill out, but it's just minor, right?

1570
01:22:48,110 --> 01:22:54,580
So ongoing regular operations like that,
adding a new computer to the network.

1571
01:22:54,580 --> 01:22:57,720
That's a change to the network,
but you got lots of computers,

1572
01:22:57,720 --> 01:22:59,620
that's just a routine thing.

1573
01:22:59,620 --> 01:23:01,720
Adding a new server on the other hand.

1574
01:23:01,720 --> 01:23:03,250
That's a different story, right?

1575
01:23:03,250 --> 01:23:07,880
So, we have to draw that line, and that
line is different for different companies,

1576
01:23:07,880 --> 01:23:09,880
so you've got to figure
out where the line is for

1577
01:23:09,880 --> 01:23:14,030
you of what get categorized
best as a standard change.

1578
01:23:16,065 --> 01:23:17,885
The next one we have is
an emergency change.

1579
01:23:18,885 --> 01:23:23,385
An emergency change is special because
it doesn't involve the cab either.

1580
01:23:23,385 --> 01:23:25,945
It involves the e-cab, the emergency cab.

1581
01:23:25,945 --> 01:23:29,952
So what are changes that
are critical enough

1582
01:23:29,952 --> 01:23:34,422
that we can't wait until
the cab is convening?

1583
01:23:34,422 --> 01:23:39,132
So we need to draw that line as part
of our service transition model.

1584
01:23:39,132 --> 01:23:41,060
Our service policy.

1585
01:23:41,060 --> 01:23:43,780
To tell employees so that they can
tell the difference themselves, and

1586
01:23:43,780 --> 01:23:46,730
they can say, this counts as critical,
I need to go to the e-cab,

1587
01:23:46,730 --> 01:23:50,060
I need to get this moving fast,
I can't wait until Thursday.

1588
01:23:50,060 --> 01:23:52,070
So it's just defining what that is.

1589
01:23:52,070 --> 01:23:55,900
And when it is critical like this,
it'll be the e-cab that receives it, and

1590
01:23:55,900 --> 01:24:00,290
authorizes it, or
changes the category to something else.

1591
01:24:00,290 --> 01:24:01,600
>> Last one is a normal change.

1592
01:24:01,600 --> 01:24:04,158
This is when we do submit
our changes to the cab and

1593
01:24:04,158 --> 01:24:07,570
they will either authorize it or
they will decline it.

1594
01:24:07,570 --> 01:24:11,930
So anything else that's not
categorized by that standard change or

1595
01:24:11,930 --> 01:24:12,950
the emergency change,

1596
01:24:12,950 --> 01:24:17,870
is just gonna be a regular submission, cab
will meet every Thursday, every Tuesday,

1597
01:24:17,870 --> 01:24:21,610
whatever day it may be to decide whether
or not that change is gonna be done.

1598
01:24:21,610 --> 01:24:23,800
>> Yeah.
So, these are easy to confuse.

1599
01:24:23,800 --> 01:24:26,390
I know for me, on the exam,
I had a hard time with this.

1600
01:24:26,390 --> 01:24:30,070
Because standard and normal, to me
>> Sound the same.

1601
01:24:30,070 --> 01:24:31,120
>> It means the same thing, right?

1602
01:24:31,120 --> 01:24:34,270
But, when we talk about our tickets,
just standard changes,

1603
01:24:34,270 --> 01:24:37,060
that's routine stuff,
doesn't go through the CAB.

1604
01:24:37,060 --> 01:24:39,630
Normal, that's a change, right?

1605
01:24:39,630 --> 01:24:41,280
Normal goes through the CAB.

1606
01:24:41,280 --> 01:24:44,980
So, standard changes don't
got to the cab and e-cab.

1607
01:24:44,980 --> 01:24:46,200
I mean emergency.

1608
01:24:46,200 --> 01:24:47,410
Those go to the e-cab.

1609
01:24:47,410 --> 01:24:49,560
So, those two are special.

1610
01:24:49,560 --> 01:24:54,550
Everything else is just a normal change,
or some people just call that a change.

1611
01:24:54,550 --> 01:24:57,373
So a normal change that runs
through the change advisory board.

1612
01:24:57,373 --> 01:24:59,901
But the key take away here is,
well first the categories,

1613
01:24:59,901 --> 01:25:01,930
you need to know those for the exam.

1614
01:25:01,930 --> 01:25:07,230
But the other thing is making
sure you define ahead of time

1615
01:25:07,230 --> 01:25:09,730
what these boundaries are,
so that your employees know.

1616
01:25:09,730 --> 01:25:13,610
Everyone in your IT department,
every single person that could

1617
01:25:13,610 --> 01:25:18,190
potentially change your production
environment needs to know the differences.

1618
01:25:18,190 --> 01:25:20,820
If they're able to make changes in
your dev environment, or staging, or

1619
01:25:20,820 --> 01:25:23,130
whatever, that's not a big deal, right?

1620
01:25:23,130 --> 01:25:25,470
But anybody who can make a change
in the production environment,

1621
01:25:25,470 --> 01:25:28,794
anybody who has the permissions,
the user account access,

1622
01:25:28,794 --> 01:25:32,460
the physical building access to
get to your production servers.

1623
01:25:32,460 --> 01:25:36,715
Any employee who has that type of access,
needs to know by heart,

1624
01:25:36,715 --> 01:25:40,160
memorized in their mind, the difference
between those three categories.

1625
01:25:40,160 --> 01:25:40,850
Right.

1626
01:25:40,850 --> 01:25:43,720
When they're allowed to make
a change without approval,

1627
01:25:43,720 --> 01:25:48,275
when they have to seek approval and when
that approval can come from the emergency

1628
01:25:48,275 --> 01:25:51,000
cab instead of the regular cab, right?

1629
01:25:51,000 --> 01:25:54,990
That way they know when they're about to
make a change who they need to go to, and

1630
01:25:54,990 --> 01:25:57,460
if they violate that, right?

1631
01:25:57,460 --> 01:26:00,160
If they decide that they're gonna apply
some updates to a server and they say,

1632
01:26:00,160 --> 01:26:03,560
well that's just standard stuff,
I'm just applying an update, right?

1633
01:26:03,560 --> 01:26:07,190
They need to know they've broken the rules
and that you can then take action on that.

1634
01:26:07,190 --> 01:26:11,480
But if you haven't set that forth in
a written policy then they don't know.

1635
01:26:11,480 --> 01:26:14,308
And that's where you really have
a challenge bringing on new employees.

1636
01:26:14,308 --> 01:26:18,890
When you on-board a new IT worker
they need to understand that

1637
01:26:18,890 --> 01:26:21,900
it might be different here than
it was at their last company.

1638
01:26:21,900 --> 01:26:25,520
At their last company maybe they did
just blanket push out updates to their

1639
01:26:25,520 --> 01:26:27,920
workstations, and
not worry about it, right?

1640
01:26:27,920 --> 01:26:30,400
Maybe all of their applications
were web based applications, so

1641
01:26:30,400 --> 01:26:32,420
they didn't really care about
updates to the operating system.

1642
01:26:33,570 --> 01:26:38,590
But in your environment, your applications
might be dedicated apps that run right on

1643
01:26:38,590 --> 01:26:42,860
the workstation, and when that operating
system update goes out, it breaks the app.

1644
01:26:42,860 --> 01:26:46,341
So they need to know that your
company is structured differently, and

1645
01:26:46,341 --> 01:26:47,703
where do you draw the line.

1646
01:26:47,703 --> 01:26:49,472
Now the exam's not gonna
ask you to draw that line,

1647
01:26:49,472 --> 01:26:50,720
cuz they don't know your company.

1648
01:26:50,720 --> 01:26:54,540
But they are gonna ask you to
understand those categories.

1649
01:26:54,540 --> 01:26:57,910
So we spent a lot of time
on change management,

1650
01:26:57,910 --> 01:26:59,670
but that's because it is so critical.

1651
01:26:59,670 --> 01:27:05,130
And you guys start to see where it helps
to create a more stable IT environment.

1652
01:27:05,130 --> 01:27:07,330
Because unauthorized
changes aren't going in and

1653
01:27:07,330 --> 01:27:11,230
the changes that do go in have
been thoroughly tested, right?

1654
01:27:11,230 --> 01:27:13,710
That's gonna result in stability.

1655
01:27:13,710 --> 01:27:18,490
So if you're a CIO, if you're a Chief
Information Officer or an IT manager.

1656
01:27:18,490 --> 01:27:20,440
You love this, this is great.

1657
01:27:20,440 --> 01:27:25,420
You hate it when at 10:00 PM you get
a phone call cuz something's wrong at

1658
01:27:25,420 --> 01:27:29,370
the office, and you find one of your guys
was messing around on the servers, right?

1659
01:27:29,370 --> 01:27:31,170
Not messing around, but

1660
01:27:31,170 --> 01:27:34,910
just making changes without testing them
thoroughly and now you've got a problem.

1661
01:27:34,910 --> 01:27:38,870
So for management this is great and
for your customer

1662
01:27:38,870 --> 01:27:43,110
it's great cuz it makes sure that these
changes don't affect their experience too.

1663
01:27:43,110 --> 01:27:47,000
So any medium,
large enterprise organization

1664
01:27:47,000 --> 01:27:49,900
is going to have an established change
management plan, and if they don't,

1665
01:27:49,900 --> 01:27:51,760
they're doing themselves a disservice.

1666
01:27:52,940 --> 01:27:55,550
Small companies might
choose to forego this.

1667
01:27:55,550 --> 01:27:58,140
And they can do that cuz
communication is a lot easier.

1668
01:27:58,140 --> 01:27:59,890
But eventually, they'll need it.

1669
01:27:59,890 --> 01:28:02,420
So when companies start looking at ITIL,

1670
01:28:02,420 --> 01:28:06,860
the change management piece is usually
one of the first things they deploy.

1671
01:28:06,860 --> 01:28:12,940
So there are many people out there that if
you poll them and ask them what is ITIL.

1672
01:28:12,940 --> 01:28:16,530
Some of them will even answer, oh yeah
it's change management, we love it.

1673
01:28:16,530 --> 01:28:20,230
Not realizing there's a whole heck a lot
more to service management than this.

1674
01:28:20,230 --> 01:28:23,790
This is probably one of
the most critical pieces.

1675
01:28:23,790 --> 01:28:28,380
All right well Ronnie, I think we've
covered change pretty exhaustively.

1676
01:28:28,380 --> 01:28:32,530
We didn't dive very deep into
configuration though, which very similar.

1677
01:28:32,530 --> 01:28:34,810
So, we'll see that in an upcoming episode,
but

1678
01:28:34,810 --> 01:28:36,730
we're pretty much out of time for
this one.

1679
01:28:36,730 --> 01:28:38,615
So we'll wrap it up here.

1680
01:28:38,615 --> 01:28:40,395
Definitely stay tuned,
we're gonna do a part two,

1681
01:28:40,395 --> 01:28:43,455
where we'll jump into configuration and
a few of the other things, right?

1682
01:28:43,455 --> 01:28:45,775
We've got all sorts of stuff left over,
right?

1683
01:28:45,775 --> 01:28:47,105
Let's quick review that.

1684
01:28:47,105 --> 01:28:50,605
We've got configuration management,
service validation and testing,

1685
01:28:50,605 --> 01:28:54,300
change evaluation, and
knowledge management.

1686
01:28:54,300 --> 01:28:57,450
Handful of other processes to tackle,
those will all be in part two so

1687
01:28:57,450 --> 01:28:58,270
make sure you check that out.

1688
01:28:59,300 --> 01:29:00,020
In the mean time,

1689
01:29:00,020 --> 01:29:04,210
if you have questions on anything that
we talked about, feel free to ask.

1690
01:29:04,210 --> 01:29:07,083
Live during the show you
can go to itpro.tv/live,

1691
01:29:07,083 --> 01:29:09,511
you'll see the chat box beneath the video.

1692
01:29:09,511 --> 01:29:12,994
Post your questions there we monitor and
answer during the show.

1693
01:29:12,994 --> 01:29:16,610
If you have questions after the show,
use our Q&A forums.

1694
01:29:16,610 --> 01:29:20,360
Live, not live, but
when we're not live we are in reruns,

1695
01:29:20,360 --> 01:29:23,870
you can click the Q&A link
on all of our webpages.

1696
01:29:23,870 --> 01:29:26,950
It'll take you to the Q&A forum and
you can post your questions there.

1697
01:29:26,950 --> 01:29:28,590
We monitor and answer after the show.

1698
01:29:28,590 --> 01:29:31,640
Want to make sure you guys have
the information you need so

1699
01:29:31,640 --> 01:29:33,010
that all of this can click.

1700
01:29:33,010 --> 01:29:34,788
It is a lot of data and some of it's new.

1701
01:29:34,788 --> 01:29:38,490
So, we wanna make sure you have an easy
way of moving in and understanding it.

1702
01:29:38,490 --> 01:29:41,080
Answering your questions is one
of the best ways we can do that.

1703
01:29:41,080 --> 01:29:42,920
So, take advantage of that,
it's there for you.

1704
01:29:44,020 --> 01:29:46,050
All right,
well I hope you enjoyed today's show.

1705
01:29:46,050 --> 01:29:48,080
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

1706
01:29:48,080 --> 01:29:49,130
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

1707
01:29:49,130 --> 01:29:51,034
>> And we'll see you next time.

1708

4

All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening.

5
00:00:36,434 --> 00:00:39,051
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:39,051 --> 00:00:42,310
I'm your host Don Pezet back
once again with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:42,310 --> 00:00:43,030
How's it going, Ronnie?

8
00:00:43,030 --> 00:00:44,950
>> It is going well, today is Friday.

9
00:00:44,950 --> 00:00:49,660
I have listened to my fill of the dulcet
tones of Alannis Morrisette, and

10
00:00:49,660 --> 00:00:50,520
I'm ready for a change.

11
00:00:50,520 --> 00:00:51,735
>> All right.

12
00:00:51,735 --> 00:00:53,174
[LAUGH]
>> So

13
00:00:53,174 --> 00:00:54,515
I'm joking on the Alannis Morrisette.

14
00:00:54,515 --> 00:00:57,305
>> I don't know if that's good or bad.

15
00:00:57,305 --> 00:00:58,885
Well, speaking of change, right?

16
00:00:58,885 --> 00:01:02,175
So we are jumping right back
into ITIL foundations and

17
00:01:02,175 --> 00:01:05,455
particularly back into
service integration.

18
00:01:05,455 --> 00:01:07,335
And if you've been following along,

19
00:01:07,335 --> 00:01:10,945
we've already done one episode on
service integration but it's such a big

20
00:01:10,945 --> 00:01:14,685
topic because of change management,
that we only got through half of it.

21
00:01:14,685 --> 00:01:18,564
So we're picking up with the second
part today and we've got a handful of

22
00:01:18,564 --> 00:01:22,138
processes to cover that we just
didn't get to in the original one.

23
00:01:22,138 --> 00:01:27,800
Now the first episode covered what service
integration was, that overall process.

24
00:01:27,800 --> 00:01:30,850
And we talked a little bit about
drafting our service policy.

25
00:01:30,850 --> 00:01:32,480
And we talk about changed management,

26
00:01:32,480 --> 00:01:36,020
big amount of content there
on changed management.

27
00:01:36,020 --> 00:01:38,155
>> Now Don you've kind of
switched up terms on us so

28
00:01:38,155 --> 00:01:41,270
remember in ITIL we call
it service transition.

29
00:01:41,270 --> 00:01:42,170
>> Oh shoot.

30
00:01:42,170 --> 00:01:45,600
>> You're calling it service integration,
[CROSSTALK] [LAUGH]

31
00:01:45,600 --> 00:01:48,440
>> Sorry yeah, terminology is important

32
00:01:48,440 --> 00:01:49,230
>> Service transition.

33
00:01:49,230 --> 00:01:52,550
>> So service transition and
we're really talking about

34
00:01:52,550 --> 00:01:56,530
introducing some kind of functionality
into our production environment and

35
00:01:56,530 --> 00:01:57,470
integration is part of that.

36
00:01:57,470 --> 00:01:58,140
>> It is.

37
00:01:58,140 --> 00:01:59,740
>> But it's not the right term.

38
00:01:59,740 --> 00:02:04,310
So service transition, that's what
we're diving back into and we're gonna

39
00:02:04,310 --> 00:02:08,410
pick back up with some of the other
processes that are equally important.

40
00:02:08,410 --> 00:02:12,580
The change management piece, that
applies to every company out there, but

41
00:02:12,580 --> 00:02:16,530
some of these other ones may or may not,
you may move in these directions,

42
00:02:16,530 --> 00:02:18,440
you may not, and so
we'll just kind of tackle them.

43
00:02:18,440 --> 00:02:21,220
There's a few extras that aren't on
the exam, but I want to cover anyway

44
00:02:21,220 --> 00:02:25,800
to make sure we have good
completeness of the covered material.

45
00:02:25,800 --> 00:02:27,370
So let's go ahead and dive into that.

46
00:02:27,370 --> 00:02:31,830
The first process that we're going
to tackle today is service asset and

47
00:02:31,830 --> 00:02:33,170
configuration management.

48
00:02:34,230 --> 00:02:35,941
Now what are we talking about here?

49
00:02:35,941 --> 00:02:39,538
Before we dive into it too deeply I wanna
make sure that we understand exactly

50
00:02:39,538 --> 00:02:40,390
what an asset is.

51
00:02:41,650 --> 00:02:45,200
So this is asset management as
well as configuration management.

52
00:02:45,200 --> 00:02:48,890
So how we handle these
two different things.

53
00:02:48,890 --> 00:02:52,490
And on the asset side, an asset is really

54
00:02:52,490 --> 00:02:57,450
anything we need to deliver the service,
to get this service put in place.

55
00:02:57,450 --> 00:02:59,960
And these are things that
are really non negotiable.

56
00:02:59,960 --> 00:03:03,240
We need these assets if we
want to get something done.

57
00:03:03,240 --> 00:03:06,050
And for the most part,
asset management is easy.

58
00:03:06,050 --> 00:03:10,350
You list in the design, in service
design what you need, and then by

59
00:03:10,350 --> 00:03:14,990
the time you get to service transition
you just get the resources you need.

60
00:03:14,990 --> 00:03:18,060
So that part is really,
really straightforward.

61
00:03:18,060 --> 00:03:22,150
>> Yeah, the acquisition side of things,
it really is just about buying them or

62
00:03:22,150 --> 00:03:24,830
making sure that you can get
a hold of them to be able

63
00:03:24,830 --> 00:03:26,680
to put into the production.

64
00:03:26,680 --> 00:03:30,610
When we start to take a look here
at managing those assets, we're

65
00:03:30,610 --> 00:03:35,360
actually trying to make sure that we have
the right number of the items on hand.

66
00:03:35,360 --> 00:03:38,280
We're trying to make sure
that if we buy software

67
00:03:38,280 --> 00:03:41,630
we're getting the right software that
will give us the service that we need.

68
00:03:41,630 --> 00:03:42,900
And if it's something like servers,

69
00:03:42,900 --> 00:03:46,220
we wanna make sure that there's powerful
enough to do everything that we want.

70
00:03:46,220 --> 00:03:50,220
So just even simple things like that
are some of the things that we're

71
00:03:50,220 --> 00:03:52,610
trying to make sure that we do
as we move into production.

72
00:03:52,610 --> 00:03:54,910
It can even include somebody's
expert advice if we need,

73
00:03:54,910 --> 00:03:56,980
to bring them on hand as a contractor.

74
00:03:56,980 --> 00:03:59,900
>> Yeah, it might not be a tangible asset,

75
00:03:59,900 --> 00:04:03,290
like a server, it might be something
somebody's got in their brain.

76
00:04:03,290 --> 00:04:07,718
And in that scenario it's not so
much that any web developer would do,

77
00:04:07,718 --> 00:04:10,760
it's that there's this particular
web developer has something in

78
00:04:10,760 --> 00:04:15,240
their head that you need as part of this
service, so it can be very specific.

79
00:04:15,240 --> 00:04:20,685
Now with assets like that a lot of times
you either have them or you don't.

80
00:04:20,685 --> 00:04:25,625
There's no real configuration involved,
but there are some assets where

81
00:04:25,625 --> 00:04:29,967
there is a configuration and
software is a great example of that.

82
00:04:29,967 --> 00:04:33,957
When you deploy software, that software
has a certain set of features,

83
00:04:33,957 --> 00:04:38,607
a certain set of functionality, and
we might change that as a part of

84
00:04:38,607 --> 00:04:42,700
locating bugs, security patches,
adding new features, or whatever.

85
00:04:42,700 --> 00:04:44,900
That is considered a configuration change.

86
00:04:44,900 --> 00:04:48,530
And if you have a server,
like a physical server,

87
00:04:48,530 --> 00:04:51,970
we might want to add memory to it or
change the hard drive configuration.

88
00:04:51,970 --> 00:04:53,710
That's a configuration change.

89
00:04:53,710 --> 00:04:59,060
These are assets that we don't just have,
but we're also able to modify and

90
00:04:59,060 --> 00:05:03,480
modifying one of those
assets can positively or

91
00:05:03,480 --> 00:05:05,770
negatively impact the actual
service delivery.

92
00:05:05,770 --> 00:05:08,320
So, we've gotta be careful about that and

93
00:05:08,320 --> 00:05:11,190
we've gotta implement something
very similar to change management.

94
00:05:11,190 --> 00:05:14,000
Change management is
when we change any aspect

95
00:05:14,000 --> 00:05:16,590
of what we are doing usually focused
around our triple constraints.

96
00:05:16,590 --> 00:05:19,960
Our costs, our schedule,
and our requirements.

97
00:05:19,960 --> 00:05:24,730
Configuration management almost
always centers around requirements.

98
00:05:24,730 --> 00:05:28,875
When we move this service into production
it's supposed to be matching up,

99
00:05:28,875 --> 00:05:33,540
aligning with our business strategy, and
meeting the requirements that were set for

100
00:05:33,540 --> 00:05:35,047
it back in service design.

101
00:05:35,047 --> 00:05:39,980
That's defined in our SDP, but
if we need to make some kind of a change,
