make sure that we can do it, we check that

1007
00:54:08,100 --> 00:54:11,790
it's actually working and then finally
we implement everything that we can.

1008
00:54:11,790 --> 00:54:13,880
So what was this process called?

1009
00:54:13,880 --> 00:54:18,820
>> ITEL calls this the PDCA model and
it's just how you implement everything.

1010
00:54:18,820 --> 00:54:22,360
Plan, do, check, act.

1011
00:54:22,360 --> 00:54:23,970
Every time you do something
in your environment,

1012
00:54:23,970 --> 00:54:26,630
every time you handle a change, you plan,

1013
00:54:26,630 --> 00:54:29,500
make sure you understand
what you are doing.

1014
00:54:29,500 --> 00:54:30,860
You do, you make the change.

1015
00:54:31,920 --> 00:54:34,047
Check, you verify
the change went as planned.

1016
00:54:34,047 --> 00:54:35,847
And then you act, and your act,

1017
00:54:35,847 --> 00:54:40,053
that action is either going to be
corrected if the change didn't work out,

1018
00:54:40,053 --> 00:54:43,823
or it's just going to be a fading
documentation if it did work out.

1019
00:54:43,823 --> 00:54:46,871
Plan, do, check, act.

1020
00:54:46,871 --> 00:54:48,755
Those are the four steps.

1021
00:54:48,755 --> 00:54:52,815
That's something that needs to be
ingrained in your operations team.

1022
00:54:52,815 --> 00:54:56,865
Everybody in the operations team needs to
understand those steps because sometimes

1023
00:54:56,865 --> 00:55:00,795
they'll just jump right into a do
check and they skip that plan and

1024
00:55:00,795 --> 00:55:02,185
they skip that act part.

1025
00:55:02,185 --> 00:55:05,980
You know, they just kind of do things and
just start putting it in and

1026
00:55:05,980 --> 00:55:08,140
you see this with people troubleshooting.

1027
00:55:08,140 --> 00:55:09,290
So there's a problem.

1028
00:55:09,290 --> 00:55:11,390
So they go in and
they make five changes to try and fix it.

1029
00:55:11,390 --> 00:55:12,620
And they fix it.

1030
00:55:12,620 --> 00:55:15,600
Great, Which of the five changes fixed it?

1031
00:55:15,600 --> 00:55:17,772
We don't know because they
didn't go through and

1032
00:55:17,772 --> 00:55:20,190
they didn't make one change, and check.

1033
00:55:20,190 --> 00:55:22,000
They made five changes and checked, and so

1034
00:55:22,000 --> 00:55:24,950
now we don't know which one was the one
that actually solved the problem.

1035
00:55:24,950 --> 00:55:28,790
So we gotta be really careful with that,
and it's plan, do, check, act.

1036
00:55:28,790 --> 00:55:30,680
It's right in the ITIL guides.

1037
00:55:30,680 --> 00:55:31,670
That's their recommended amount.

1038
00:55:33,400 --> 00:55:35,610
All right, so with change evaluation.

1039
00:55:35,610 --> 00:55:37,650
I doubt we taught anything
new right there, right?

1040
00:55:37,650 --> 00:55:39,220
It's pretty common sense,

1041
00:55:39,220 --> 00:55:42,800
but it's documented anyway because that
means it can be part of our policy.

1042
00:55:42,800 --> 00:55:45,660
And as you on board employees,
if it isn't common to somebody,

1043
00:55:45,660 --> 00:55:47,250
if you've just hired somebody
right out of college,

1044
00:55:47,250 --> 00:55:50,020
they might not have that experience yet,
they might not know.

1045
00:55:50,020 --> 00:55:53,540
If they're coming from a small company,
where they can just jump in and

1046
00:55:53,540 --> 00:55:56,610
make changes well,
they need to know that in your company,

1047
00:55:56,610 --> 00:56:00,320
in this larger organization,
that's not safe and will not be tolerated.

1048
00:56:00,320 --> 00:56:02,870
It's right here in our policy,
this is what we do.

1049
00:56:02,870 --> 00:56:06,250
Do not deviate from this at all.

1050
00:56:06,250 --> 00:56:10,530
Our last process goes right in line with
that, which is knowledge management.

1051
00:56:10,530 --> 00:56:15,030
Knowledge management is how we process
all of the information that we get.

1052
00:56:15,030 --> 00:56:19,090
And what it really centers around is,
storing that information.

1053
00:56:19,090 --> 00:56:22,160
We keep talking about changes,
and request for change.

1054
00:56:22,160 --> 00:56:24,030
Those tickets that we fill out.

1055
00:56:24,030 --> 00:56:25,610
What do we do when those tickets,
when the change is done?

1056
00:56:25,610 --> 00:56:26,670
Do we throw it away?

1057
00:56:26,670 --> 00:56:27,820
No, we keep those.

1058
00:56:27,820 --> 00:56:31,170
You keep the change ticket, so
you can see what happened in the past.

1059
00:56:31,170 --> 00:56:33,880
And you can use that for
all sorts of things in the future.

1060
00:56:33,880 --> 00:56:37,150
You can use it to avoid mistakes
on other activities, or

1061
00:56:37,150 --> 00:56:39,530
other service roll outs
before they happen.

1062
00:56:39,530 --> 00:56:40,480
If a problem occurs,

1063
00:56:40,480 --> 00:56:43,070
you can use the change tickets to be
able to trouble shoot it, and find it.

1064
00:56:43,070 --> 00:56:44,270
But not just the change ticket.

1065
00:56:44,270 --> 00:56:47,470
The SDP, our service design package,
and all of that.

1066
00:56:47,470 --> 00:56:49,980
Any other metric data
that we've collected.

1067
00:56:49,980 --> 00:56:53,150
All of this information,
they needs to go somewhere.

1068
00:56:53,150 --> 00:56:55,415
And that's what the knowledge
management process is all about.

1069
00:56:55,415 --> 00:56:58,260
>> Yeah.
When a small company.

1070
00:56:58,260 --> 00:57:00,330
You may just put everything
into a single folder.

1071
00:57:00,330 --> 00:57:01,787
[INAUDIBLE] When there's a problem,

1072
00:57:01,787 --> 00:57:04,720
let's just look in that folder
to find all the information.

1073
00:57:04,720 --> 00:57:09,520
But as your company, and
your organization grows, very easy for

1074
00:57:09,520 --> 00:57:12,200
a piece of data to become missing.

1075
00:57:12,200 --> 00:57:15,160
Don, I can't tell you how many times I've
just wrote something down on a corner of

1076
00:57:15,160 --> 00:57:18,416
a piece of paper, and
then I stack all those papers up.

1077
00:57:18,416 --> 00:57:19,830
>> [LAUGH]
>> And I go, I know I wrote it down.

1078
00:57:21,280 --> 00:57:23,030
But as your company grows bigger,
and more, and

1079
00:57:23,030 --> 00:57:25,990
more people start making changes,
and start doing thing.

1080
00:57:25,990 --> 00:57:29,780
It becomes much more essential, that
we can keep it somewhere that we could

1081
00:57:29,780 --> 00:57:34,150
access the information easily, and
that the information really helps us.

1082
00:57:34,150 --> 00:57:37,485
So that, we're not having to reinvent the
wheel every time a new change comes along.

1083
00:57:37,485 --> 00:57:38,740
>> Yeah.

1084
00:57:38,740 --> 00:57:41,590
Now, hopefully we have an SKMS.

1085
00:57:41,590 --> 00:57:44,340
That service knowledge management system,
and that's where we put our data.

1086
00:57:44,340 --> 00:57:47,980
So that, anybody can go in, and search the
data, and find the information they want.

1087
00:57:47,980 --> 00:57:50,410
And so,
it facilitates good decision making.

1088
00:57:50,410 --> 00:57:52,720
When you need to make a decision,
you've got hard data.

1089
00:57:52,720 --> 00:57:53,470
You can go on reference.

1090
00:57:53,470 --> 00:57:56,610
You're not just trying to guess,
or estimate, or whatever.

1091
00:57:56,610 --> 00:57:58,940
You've got actual hard data,
you can go and get.

1092
00:57:58,940 --> 00:58:00,810
So, we need to have that.

1093
00:58:00,810 --> 00:58:05,150
Now, the problem is when we collect this
data it's not always useable in it's

1094
00:58:05,150 --> 00:58:06,572
original form.

1095
00:58:06,572 --> 00:58:10,965
So ITIL, basically specify four
different forms the data can be in.

1096
00:58:10,965 --> 00:58:14,409
And there is data itself,
there's information,

1097
00:58:14,409 --> 00:58:18,140
there's knowledge, and there's wisdom.

1098
00:58:18,140 --> 00:58:20,490
Now, to a lot of people
those sound the same.

1099
00:58:20,490 --> 00:58:22,000
Data, information, knowledge, wisdom.

1100
00:58:22,000 --> 00:58:24,010
It’s like four words that
all mean the same thing.

1101
00:58:24,010 --> 00:58:27,650
But it is actually different state,
that your information is in.

1102
00:58:27,650 --> 00:58:33,230
That first state, it is just data, that
is the raw data, what we've collected.

1103
00:58:33,230 --> 00:58:37,050
So, we mentioned our matrix,
or utility, and warranty.

1104
00:58:37,050 --> 00:58:39,870
We collect that raw data,
that is the survey data from our users,

1105
00:58:39,870 --> 00:58:41,890
how happy were they with
the navigation experience.

1106
00:58:41,890 --> 00:58:46,990
We get that raw information back,
and that's all it is, just raw.

1107
00:58:46,990 --> 00:58:50,620
It's there, and it's up to us to
figure out what to do with it.

1108
00:58:50,620 --> 00:58:53,175
The data's not necessarily
usable in its current format.

1109
00:58:53,175 --> 00:58:55,373
Now, when we're dealing with data,

1110
00:58:55,373 --> 00:58:58,685
the only concern that we
really have is accuracy.

1111
00:58:58,685 --> 00:59:02,375
Making sure that data truly reflects,
whatever its supposed to reflect.

1112
00:59:02,375 --> 00:59:05,915
Because if its a flaw in the data,
whenever we work with it,

1113
00:59:05,915 --> 00:59:08,185
our decisions will be flawed.

1114
00:59:08,185 --> 00:59:12,515
So, this is raw data only processed for

1115
00:59:12,515 --> 00:59:13,146
accuracy
>> Yep.

1116
00:59:13,146 --> 00:59:15,255
The next step is information.

1117
00:59:16,285 --> 00:59:19,050
Think about information
as taking that raw data.

1118
00:59:19,050 --> 00:59:22,620
And put it into the context
of what we need it to be in.

1119
00:59:22,620 --> 00:59:25,460
The reason why we need the context
is because not all that data

1120
00:59:25,460 --> 00:59:27,750
applies to every single situation.

1121
00:59:27,750 --> 00:59:30,630
So that way, if we're taking a look at it,
and trying to figure out what we're

1122
00:59:30,630 --> 00:59:34,380
supposed to do next on some type of
process that we're having to correct.

1123
00:59:34,380 --> 00:59:38,060
It helps us to have that context that we
need, so that we make the proper decision.

1124
00:59:38,060 --> 00:59:40,630
And go wait a minute, even though
that looks like it applies to me.

1125
00:59:40,630 --> 00:59:43,100
It doesn't really apply in this situation.

1126
00:59:43,100 --> 00:59:44,247
And that way I don't actually consider it.

1127
00:59:44,247 --> 00:59:47,903
And then I don't make wrong
decision based off of that either.

1128
00:59:47,903 --> 00:59:50,386
>> And what it really boils down to,

1129
00:59:50,386 --> 00:59:54,743
is the raw data is usually too
much data for us to deal with.

1130
00:59:54,743 --> 00:59:57,746
It's got a lot of stuff in there that
doesn't apply to the decision that we

1131
00:59:57,746 --> 00:59:58,980
are trying to make.

1132
00:59:58,980 --> 01:00:02,095
So, when we convert that
data into information,

1133
01:00:02,095 --> 01:00:06,110
where we're parsing it down to
just the pieces that we need.

1134
01:00:06,110 --> 01:00:09,060
And that can be a very complex process,
that we do.

1135
01:00:09,060 --> 01:00:10,860
As we convert it into information.

1136
01:00:10,860 --> 01:00:13,640
We apply a structure,
we aggregate data from different sources,

1137
01:00:13,640 --> 01:00:14,950
we do all that crazy stuff.

1138
01:00:14,950 --> 01:00:16,040
Or it can be very simple.

1139
01:00:16,040 --> 01:00:18,410
Let's use my navigation example.

1140
01:00:18,410 --> 01:00:23,785
We set a metric that said we wanna
score an average evaluation number of

1141
01:00:23,785 --> 01:00:28,480
seven on a scale of one to ten, from our
users if they were happy with navigation.

1142
01:00:28,480 --> 01:00:31,280
Well, the data are the raw surveys.

1143
01:00:31,280 --> 01:00:33,850
So let's say, I get 5,000 surveys back.

1144
01:00:33,850 --> 01:00:38,100
Well, if I take all 5,000 of them,
how useful is that information to me?

1145
01:00:38,100 --> 01:00:39,620
It's not terribly useful.

1146
01:00:39,620 --> 01:00:42,680
But if I average their
navigation rating together.

1147
01:00:42,680 --> 01:00:45,450
I average all those numbers,
now I can get one number, the average.

1148
01:00:45,450 --> 01:00:47,420
That's what I really wanted.

1149
01:00:47,420 --> 01:00:51,570
Now, I just took data, and
converted it into information.

1150
01:00:51,570 --> 01:00:56,470
My metric was I needed to score a seven,
the average of my surveys was a 6.5.

1151
01:00:56,470 --> 01:00:58,640
Now, I can work with that.

1152
01:00:58,640 --> 01:01:01,210
So, that's the difference between data,
and information.

1153
01:01:01,210 --> 01:01:02,530
We get it as data.

1154
01:01:02,530 --> 01:01:04,800
We convert it into information.

1155
01:01:04,800 --> 01:01:05,720
>> Yeah.

1156
01:01:05,720 --> 01:01:10,560
As hard as it is sometimes to distinguish
between the data, and the information.

1157
01:01:10,560 --> 01:01:12,860
Don, I think the next step
was actually even harder.

1158
01:01:12,860 --> 01:01:20,680
It's to take the information, and then to
convert it into what ITIL calls knowledge.

1159
01:01:20,680 --> 01:01:23,603
So, Don, you're gonna have to help me here
cuz apparently, I don't have enough of it.

1160
01:01:23,603 --> 01:01:24,320
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

1161
01:01:24,320 --> 01:01:25,331
>> [LAUGH]
>> So,

1162
01:01:25,331 --> 01:01:28,736
knowledge is simply what you
do with the information.

1163
01:01:28,736 --> 01:01:29,555
>> Yeah.
>> So now,

1164
01:01:29,555 --> 01:01:33,212
I know that my customers
averaged a 6.5 on navigation.

1165
01:01:33,212 --> 01:01:36,940
Great, I've got that,
what does that mean to me?

1166
01:01:36,940 --> 01:01:38,870
Well, we turn it into knowledge.

1167
01:01:38,870 --> 01:01:42,440
And knowledge is just gonna be things
that like ideas, insight, values,

1168
01:01:42,440 --> 01:01:44,780
whatever, these kind of conceptual things.

1169
01:01:44,780 --> 01:01:49,510
So, I look at that, and I see 6.5,
when I compare that to my metric,

1170
01:01:49,510 --> 01:01:54,840
my PKI,or my KPI, sorry,
key performance indicator.

1171
01:01:54,840 --> 01:01:58,150
When I compare those,
I can say I missed mark.

1172
01:01:58,150 --> 01:02:00,790
The 6.5, that was the information.

1173
01:02:00,790 --> 01:02:05,090
Comparing it to that indicator,
that becomes my knowledge.

1174
01:02:05,090 --> 01:02:07,790
I now know, that I didn't meet my mark.

1175
01:02:07,790 --> 01:02:11,950
And I know, that I need to get my
score up at least half a point, so

1176
01:02:11,950 --> 01:02:12,690
I can get to seven.

1177
01:02:12,690 --> 01:02:15,910
I'd like to get beyond that, but
I need to come up at least half a point.

1178
01:02:15,910 --> 01:02:19,672
So, we didn't achieve what we set out to
achieve, so we're gonna need to do more.

1179
01:02:19,672 --> 01:02:22,090
We're gonna need to come
up with some more ideas.

1180
01:02:22,090 --> 01:02:22,890
How can we improve this?

1181
01:02:22,890 --> 01:02:27,230
How can we get up more than that seven,
that we're shooting for?

1182
01:02:27,230 --> 01:02:30,960
That's when we take our information,
and we turn it into knowledge.

1183
01:02:30,960 --> 01:02:35,310
Now, we know information,
we know data about our system, and

1184
01:02:35,310 --> 01:02:37,140
we need to take action on it.

1185
01:02:37,140 --> 01:02:39,440
So, that's a key piece.

1186
01:02:39,440 --> 01:02:44,630
Data, and information by themselves
are nice, but they don't benefit us yet.

1187
01:02:44,630 --> 01:02:47,480
We've got them, it's what we do with that,
that makes the difference.

1188
01:02:47,480 --> 01:02:49,180
And that's when it becomes knowledge.

1189
01:02:49,180 --> 01:02:52,805
We're taking action, and
hopefully, going at it.

1190
01:02:52,805 --> 01:02:56,160
Now, we do have to be careful because
when we get into this knowledge part,

1191
01:02:56,160 --> 01:02:59,060
we're really interpreting
the information we get.

1192
01:02:59,060 --> 01:03:03,475
And it can be manipulated if
the,data is incorrect, or

1193
01:03:03,475 --> 01:03:06,025
whoever converted it into information.

1194
01:03:06,025 --> 01:03:10,745
If they made mistakes in doing the
averaging, or maybe they didn't exclude

1195
01:03:10,745 --> 01:03:14,620
outliers, or they did include outliers, or
they didn't go to enough decimal points.

1196
01:03:14,620 --> 01:03:17,650
The information that we get may not
be accurate even though the data

1197
01:03:17,650 --> 01:03:18,970
underneath it was.

1198
01:03:18,970 --> 01:03:21,500
And so, when we go to create knowledge,

1199
01:03:21,500 --> 01:03:24,780
it's possible that we're basing our
information on something that's incorrect.

1200
01:03:24,780 --> 01:03:29,030
And you see this,
in the medical industry all the time.

1201
01:03:29,030 --> 01:03:35,119
Where they'll come out one year, and
they'll say, [INAUDIBLE] spinach.

1202
01:03:35,119 --> 01:03:37,900
>> [LAUGH]
>> This is a great example.

1203
01:03:37,900 --> 01:03:42,470
In the 1970s, in the United States there
were huge advertising campaigns about how

1204
01:03:42,470 --> 01:03:44,430
awesome spinach was for your health.

1205
01:03:44,430 --> 01:03:46,910
And they were saying boy,
spinach is great.

1206
01:03:46,910 --> 01:03:47,650
Everybody should do this.

1207
01:03:47,650 --> 01:03:49,520
And it had all of these
scientific studies,

1208
01:03:49,520 --> 01:03:52,480
that showed that spinach
was a great source of iron.

1209
01:03:52,480 --> 01:03:54,280
And it really just helped your body.

1210
01:03:55,360 --> 01:03:57,500
Well, then in the late 80s
they came out and they said,

1211
01:03:57,500 --> 01:04:00,165
well actually let's back
off that a little bit.

1212
01:04:00,165 --> 01:04:03,810
>> [LAUGH]
>> Spinach is good, but it's so high in

1213
01:04:03,810 --> 01:04:06,630
iron that if you have any bone damage-
>> [LAUGH]

1214
01:04:06,630 --> 01:04:08,160
>> It actually slows your bones

1215
01:04:08,160 --> 01:04:08,915
down healing.

1216
01:04:08,915 --> 01:04:10,516
>> [LAUGH]
>> And so, if have like a broken bone,

1217
01:04:10,516 --> 01:04:11,833
spinach is a terrible thing to eat.

1218
01:04:11,833 --> 01:04:13,416
So, they just didn't know.

1219
01:04:13,416 --> 01:04:14,792
They didn't have the information.

1220
01:04:14,792 --> 01:04:19,534
So, they had collected some data that
didn't include things like monitoring bone

1221
01:04:19,534 --> 01:04:20,084
health.

1222
01:04:20,084 --> 01:04:23,030
It just monitored other metrics.

1223
01:04:23,030 --> 01:04:26,760
And then the information they gleaned from
it was based on that limited data and

1224
01:04:26,760 --> 01:04:30,616
then they made knowledge that
didn't include certain things.

1225
01:04:30,616 --> 01:04:34,080
Now that does that mean they're bad people
and the scientist should be punished and

1226
01:04:34,080 --> 01:04:35,350
exiled or whatever?

1227
01:04:35,350 --> 01:04:38,840
No, it just means that we always need to
understand the limitation of our data.

1228
01:04:38,840 --> 01:04:42,800
There could be other sources of data
that we didn't take into account.

1229
01:04:42,800 --> 01:04:48,340
And when we convert information into
knowledge, it just has to be done with as

1230
01:04:48,340 --> 01:04:53,680
much information as we can get ahold of,
without paralyzing our decision-making.

1231
01:04:53,680 --> 01:04:56,790
There are some people who will
continually wait and wait and wait for

1232
01:04:56,790 --> 01:04:58,220
more information to roll in.

1233
01:04:58,220 --> 01:05:01,450
There comes a time where you have to make
a decision and you say, you know what,

1234
01:05:01,450 --> 01:05:06,090
this is the best decision I can make
today with the information that I have.

1235
01:05:06,090 --> 01:05:08,100
And so we document that.

1236
01:05:08,100 --> 01:05:12,060
That becomes part of our records
how we reached that decision.

1237
01:05:12,060 --> 01:05:16,580
And then that leads us to the last one,
which is wisdom.

1238
01:05:16,580 --> 01:05:20,060
Now wisdom really is like knowledge.

1239
01:05:20,060 --> 01:05:23,200
The difference is wisdom is right.

1240
01:05:23,200 --> 01:05:29,800
When you make a correct,
well-informed decision, that's wisdom.

1241
01:05:29,800 --> 01:05:33,710
When you make an incorrect decision,
that's still just knowledge.

1242
01:05:33,710 --> 01:05:36,670
We had knowledge, and
to the best of our knowledge,

1243
01:05:36,670 --> 01:05:39,960
what we were doing was right and
it turned out not to be right.

1244
01:05:39,960 --> 01:05:43,240
>> Don, I remembered this phrase that just
popped in my head as you were saying that.

1245
01:05:43,240 --> 01:05:44,620
A little bit of knowledge.

1246
01:05:44,620 --> 01:05:47,720
People actually say I have
just enough to be dangerous.

1247
01:05:47,720 --> 01:05:49,350
And that's what can happen.

1248
01:05:49,350 --> 01:05:53,070
Wisdom gives us enough
knowledge to know that

1249
01:05:53,070 --> 01:05:56,310
we can take the information that we're
given and make a bad decision, or we

1250
01:05:56,310 --> 01:05:59,760
can take the information that we're given
and make the correct decision as well.

1251
01:05:59,760 --> 01:06:02,650
So being able to distinguish
that is pretty much a part of

1252
01:06:02,650 --> 01:06:05,070
what we need to be able to have on hand.

1253
01:06:05,070 --> 01:06:10,890
In ITIL, they do call it an acronym here,
that DI, if I can do it,

1254
01:06:10,890 --> 01:06:16,390
DIKW as well as part of
this process that we have.

1255
01:06:16,390 --> 01:06:20,740
>> Yeah, so DIKW, that's just our data,
information, knowledge, wisdom.

1256
01:06:20,740 --> 01:06:24,510
So when we have an SKMS,
this is kind of the purpose of the SKMS.

1257
01:06:24,510 --> 01:06:26,960
We get our raw data,
we throw it in the SKMS.

1258
01:06:26,960 --> 01:06:31,170
Then we create reports, which
are converting our data into information.

1259
01:06:31,170 --> 01:06:34,550
And then based on those reports,
we evaluate our services.

1260
01:06:34,550 --> 01:06:36,670
And we make decisions as
far as where to go on that.

1261
01:06:36,670 --> 01:06:37,850
Now it's knowledge.

1262
01:06:37,850 --> 01:06:41,880
And if we have the right data, and it's
presented in the right information, and we

1263
01:06:41,880 --> 01:06:47,850
make the right knowledge decisions, we've
now created wisdom and we move forward.

1264
01:06:47,850 --> 01:06:49,060
Now that's pretty common sense.

1265
01:06:49,060 --> 01:06:50,640
A lot of us don't even think
about these four phases.

1266
01:06:50,640 --> 01:06:52,750
It's not like you're going
to tag your data this way.

1267
01:06:52,750 --> 01:06:53,820
But just be aware that that's there.

1268
01:06:53,820 --> 01:06:58,020
It is a concept inside of ITIL, and
we're going to see it more when we get to

1269
01:06:58,020 --> 01:07:01,240
the CSI section,
the continual service improvement,

1270
01:07:01,240 --> 01:07:04,570
because you're collecting a lot of data
there about your service and you're trying

1271
01:07:04,570 --> 01:07:08,420
to find ways to make it better, and you're
going to move through all four stages.

1272
01:07:08,420 --> 01:07:10,390
So it's definitely heavier over there, but

1273
01:07:10,390 --> 01:07:13,480
this is one that really spans
all of the service groups.

1274
01:07:13,480 --> 01:07:17,300
So it's not just limited right
here to service transition, but

1275
01:07:17,300 --> 01:07:21,980
they put it in service transition
because that's where we see it the most.

1276
01:07:21,980 --> 01:07:25,235
When you're deploying a new service or
updating the existing service,

1277
01:07:25,235 --> 01:07:28,445
you're going to be harvesting
a lot of information.

1278
01:07:28,445 --> 01:07:31,735
You're going to be working with that
quite a bit to make the right decisions.

1279
01:07:31,735 --> 01:07:33,125
So that's why it gets thrown in here.

1280
01:07:34,385 --> 01:07:36,702
But again, common sense, so
it's not really on the exam, but

1281
01:07:36,702 --> 01:07:38,165
it's something we need to be aware of.

1282
01:07:39,935 --> 01:07:42,665
All right, so with that process,
that wraps it up.

1283
01:07:42,665 --> 01:07:44,425
That is it for service transition.

1284
01:07:44,425 --> 01:07:47,970
I know we went into two episodes on this
one cuz it was quite a bit of material.

1285
01:07:47,970 --> 01:07:53,270
But at this stage in the game,
now our information is in production.

1286
01:07:53,270 --> 01:07:56,470
Our new service has launched,
our modified service has launched.

1287
01:07:56,470 --> 01:07:57,030
What do we do?

1288
01:07:57,030 --> 01:07:58,330
We kick back and take a break.

1289
01:07:58,330 --> 01:07:59,470
Go on vacation.

1290
01:07:59,470 --> 01:08:01,370
Well, we still have two
more groups to get to.

1291
01:08:01,370 --> 01:08:03,100
We've got service operations.

1292
01:08:03,100 --> 01:08:06,120
So somebody's gotta make this service
continue to run now that it's been

1293
01:08:06,120 --> 01:08:07,090
deployed.

1294
01:08:07,090 --> 01:08:09,650
And then we'll talk about continual
service improvement towards the end of

1295
01:08:09,650 --> 01:08:10,560
this series.

1296
01:08:10,560 --> 01:08:12,120
So definitely stay tuned for that.

1297
01:08:12,120 --> 01:08:17,380
We've got more episodes coming as we
round off the rest of the ITIL books.

1298
01:08:18,390 --> 01:08:21,070
But for now, this is a pretty
good spot to wrap up the show.

1299
01:08:21,070 --> 01:08:22,920
So let me remind you guys,

1300
01:08:22,920 --> 01:08:27,360
if you have questions on any of the things
that we've talked about, feel free to ask.

1301
01:08:27,360 --> 01:08:28,100
Live during the show,

1302
01:08:28,100 --> 01:08:32,770
you can go to ITPro.TV/live,
you'll see the chat box beneath the video.

1303
01:08:32,770 --> 01:08:34,100
Type in your questions.

1304
01:08:34,100 --> 01:08:35,510
We monitor and answer during the show.

1305
01:08:35,510 --> 01:08:38,470
If you have questions after the show,
make use of our Q&A forums.

1306
01:08:38,470 --> 01:08:42,840
At the top of every page on ITProTV
you'll see a link that says Q&A.

1307
01:08:42,840 --> 01:08:44,950
Click on it and
it'll take you into our forums.

1308
01:08:44,950 --> 01:08:48,840
Post your questions there and
we monitor and answer after the show.

1309
01:08:48,840 --> 01:08:50,930
All right, well,
I hope you guys enjoyed today’s show.

1310
01:08:50,930 --> 01:08:52,860
Signing off for ITProTV I’m Don Pezet.

1311
01:08:52,860 --> 01:08:53,900
>> And I’m Ronnie Wong.

1312
01:08:53,900 --> 01:08:55,554
>> And we'll see you next time.

1313
01:08:55,554 --> 01:09:05,554
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Service Operation
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:15,340 --> 00:00:22,750
[SOUND]

3
00:00:22,750 --> 00:00:32,750
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,750 --> 00:00:36,645
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening and

5
00:00:36,645 --> 00:00:38,731
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:38,731 --> 00:00:40,161
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

7
00:00:40,161 --> 00:00:41,741
Back again with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:41,741 --> 00:00:42,670
How's it going Ronnie?

9
00:00:42,670 --> 00:00:43,620
>> It is going well.

10
00:00:43,620 --> 00:00:46,950
It's a beautiful morning
here in sunny Florida.

11
00:00:46,950 --> 00:00:51,250
And we do welcome everybody to our
show as we go into ITIL Foundations.

12
00:00:51,250 --> 00:00:52,620
Another exciting episode.

13
00:00:52,620 --> 00:00:53,460
>> That's right.

14
00:00:53,460 --> 00:00:57,546
We're starting to approach the end of our
service life cycle as we move into these

15
00:00:57,546 --> 00:00:58,460
last few topics.

16
00:00:58,460 --> 00:01:02,580
And the topic we're gonna be
hitting today is service operation.

17
00:01:02,580 --> 00:01:07,110
Now all the other areas that we've hit,
things like service strategy,

18
00:01:07,110 --> 00:01:10,030
service design, service-
>> Transition.

19
00:01:10,030 --> 00:01:10,869
>> Transition [LAUGH].

20
00:01:10,869 --> 00:01:12,328
I just always want to say integration.

21
00:01:12,328 --> 00:01:14,080
>> [LAUGH]
>> Service transition.

22
00:01:14,080 --> 00:01:17,960
All of those were kind of the lead up,
and process of,

23
00:01:17,960 --> 00:01:22,030
getting a new service or a changed
service pushed and into our organization.

24
00:01:22,030 --> 00:01:23,660
Here we switch gears, and

25
00:01:23,660 --> 00:01:28,810
now we're taking a look at actually
using that new service, right?

26
00:01:28,810 --> 00:01:31,330
So you've created this service,
you're providing it to your customer or

27
00:01:31,330 --> 00:01:34,170
you're providing it to your end users,
whoever it is that you're providing it to.

28
00:01:34,170 --> 00:01:36,560
How do we keep it running?

29
00:01:36,560 --> 00:01:39,268
And that's what service
operation is all about.

30
00:01:39,268 --> 00:01:44,180
Remember that ITIL itself is really
based around this concept of IT service

31
00:01:44,180 --> 00:01:49,220
management, and the biggest part of
that is typically operations, right?

32
00:01:49,220 --> 00:01:50,690
Just running with the service.

33
00:01:50,690 --> 00:01:54,310
Hopefully you don't spend
ten years designing and

34
00:01:54,310 --> 00:01:57,930
coming up with a deployment strategy for
a service that you then only use for

35
00:01:57,930 --> 00:01:59,960
a few days, but
that's not impossible, right?

36
00:01:59,960 --> 00:02:00,760
Just look at NASA.

37
00:02:00,760 --> 00:02:03,800
Every time they launch a rocket into
space, there are years and years and

38
00:02:03,800 --> 00:02:08,350
years of effort that go into that, but
then all, as far as operation's concerned,

39
00:02:08,350 --> 00:02:10,350
execute within a small period of time.

40
00:02:10,350 --> 00:02:12,110
But most companies aren't
structured that way, right?

41
00:02:12,110 --> 00:02:15,800
Most of us, we come up with an idea for
a service, like ITProTV.

42
00:02:15,800 --> 00:02:18,440
We wanted to provide video based training,
right?

43
00:02:18,440 --> 00:02:20,700
So coming up with that idea,
our initial designs,

44
00:02:20,700 --> 00:02:23,690
that initial push,
it took some time, right.

45
00:02:23,690 --> 00:02:25,430
But it didn't take a ton of time.

46
00:02:25,430 --> 00:02:28,980
And now we've spent well over two
years creating the actual content,

47
00:02:28,980 --> 00:02:31,040
the actual operations of this company.

48
00:02:31,040 --> 00:02:35,310
So that's a little more common for
most organizations.

49
00:02:35,310 --> 00:02:37,980
>> In service operations,
what we're really trying to do

50
00:02:37,980 --> 00:02:40,870
is not just get the product developed and
just delivered.

51
00:02:40,870 --> 00:02:42,590
But we want it delivered with stability.

52
00:02:42,590 --> 00:02:47,420
In other words, the ability for
you to have that stability that you want,

53
00:02:47,420 --> 00:02:51,160
which is to be able to go to it day after
day and know that it's gonna be there.

54
00:02:51,160 --> 00:02:53,100
But also with consistency.

55
00:02:53,100 --> 00:02:57,550
We want not only our shows to be
consistently better quality and

56
00:02:57,550 --> 00:02:58,860
higher performance here, but

57
00:02:58,860 --> 00:03:02,650
to make sure that we deliver the same
experience each and every time too.

58
00:03:02,650 --> 00:03:06,990
And service operation is really
focused in around that idea.

59
00:03:06,990 --> 00:03:11,210
I'm not just going okay, I got you
the service, you want it to perform now?

60
00:03:11,210 --> 00:03:13,770
It's actually about making it
do it over and over again.

61
00:03:13,770 --> 00:03:16,390
And that's what we want to provide
here in service operations.

62
00:03:16,390 --> 00:03:19,561
>> Yeah, and what we'll find is there's
a real challenge here because service

63
00:03:19,561 --> 00:03:21,630
operations is all about a balancing act,
right.

64
00:03:21,630 --> 00:03:25,532
Where balancing that stability that we
need, right, our customers are paying for

65
00:03:25,532 --> 00:03:26,100
a product.

66
00:03:26,100 --> 00:03:29,060
We want to make sure that we can
deliver that product at all times.

67
00:03:29,060 --> 00:03:35,220
But, we have to offer that stability
while still allowing for change, right?

68
00:03:35,220 --> 00:03:37,170
You could say, all right,
we created a perfect,

69
00:03:37,170 --> 00:03:39,580
stable product just like it is right now.

70
00:03:39,580 --> 00:03:40,570
Don't mess with it, right?

71
00:03:40,570 --> 00:03:41,160
What's the saying?

72
00:03:41,160 --> 00:03:43,240
If it's not broke, don't fix it, right?

73
00:03:43,240 --> 00:03:47,140
So that kind of mentality is easy
to fall into, to say we've got it.

74
00:03:47,140 --> 00:03:48,140
This is perfect.

75
00:03:48,140 --> 00:03:49,900
Don't touch it.

76
00:03:49,900 --> 00:03:53,640
But if you do that, the marketplace
continues to evolve, your customers

77
00:03:53,640 --> 00:03:58,540
continue to evolve, and your perfect,
stable product may now be outdated.

78
00:03:58,540 --> 00:04:01,820
So you've got to allow for change,
for modifications to occur.

79
00:04:01,820 --> 00:04:05,184
And if you remember back in the change
management episodes, I said,

80
00:04:05,184 --> 00:04:06,580
every change brings risks.

81
00:04:06,580 --> 00:04:08,220
There's no way around that.

82
00:04:08,220 --> 00:04:11,370
So, with service operation,
we have to be able to decide

83
00:04:12,410 --> 00:04:15,800
when that risk is appropriate or
when we need to be able to move forward.

84
00:04:15,800 --> 00:04:17,690
We should not be change averse.

85
00:04:17,690 --> 00:04:18,820
That's a bad thing.

86
00:04:18,820 --> 00:04:22,640
But we do need to be controlled
about the changes that we allow.

87
00:04:22,640 --> 00:04:27,520
And service operations is that point where
we decide, oh you want to change that?

88
00:04:27,520 --> 00:04:29,510
You need to go through change management,
right?

89
00:04:29,510 --> 00:04:30,460
Shift people over there.

90
00:04:30,460 --> 00:04:33,390
Otherwise we're just gonna keep this
running the way that it is, but

91
00:04:33,390 --> 00:04:37,730
we've got that input or interface to
be able to jump into change management.

92
00:04:37,730 --> 00:04:38,420
>> Yeah.

93
00:04:38,420 --> 00:04:42,150
It is through the service operation that
our customer will really begin to see

94
00:04:42,150 --> 00:04:45,640
the value of the product that we've
delivered, so that they know that

95
00:04:45,640 --> 00:04:49,940
the product's solid, it's stable, it's
gonna do exactly what the customer wants.

96
00:04:49,940 --> 00:04:53,130
And that's where they're gonna actually
start having a better attachment to your

97
00:04:53,130 --> 00:04:56,570
service, and wanting to actually
integrate a little bit more, or

98
00:04:56,570 --> 00:04:58,490
to actually get you to
deliver more services.

99
00:04:58,490 --> 00:04:59,890
And that's what we hope we can do.

100
00:04:59,890 --> 00:05:00,650
>> Yeah.

101
00:05:00,650 --> 00:05:03,044
So, when we're doing service operations,

102
00:05:03,044 --> 00:05:06,160
a big part of what we deal
with is management, right?

103
00:05:06,160 --> 00:05:10,050
Actually managing the operation,
managing our resources, our people,

104
00:05:10,050 --> 00:05:11,550
the services themselves.

105
00:05:11,550 --> 00:05:13,090
There's a lot of stuff
that gets dealt with.

106
00:05:13,090 --> 00:05:17,933
And the service operations service book,
it covers recommended best practices for

107
00:05:17,933 --> 00:05:19,660
doing that, right?

108
00:05:19,660 --> 00:05:22,180
Now, ITIL does have a few
different definitions of

109
00:05:22,180 --> 00:05:25,770
the types of management that happen, and
I want to call out just a couple of them.

110
00:05:25,770 --> 00:05:29,730
Actually, if you grab the service
operations book, there's a good six or

111
00:05:29,730 --> 00:05:31,540
seven different management types in there.

112
00:05:31,540 --> 00:05:33,620
But there's just a few I want
to make sure that we understand,

113
00:05:33,620 --> 00:05:35,998
these are the ones that have
a tendency to show up the exam.

114
00:05:35,998 --> 00:05:39,470
The main one we have is
IT operations management.

115
00:05:39,470 --> 00:05:44,522
And that's that overall vision of
managing the delivery of a service,

116
00:05:44,522 --> 00:05:46,150
our IT operations.

117
00:05:46,150 --> 00:05:49,970
The day to day activities of your IT
department are delivering a service or

118
00:05:49,970 --> 00:05:51,530
making that service possible.

119
00:05:51,530 --> 00:05:53,360
And that's what we call
IT operations management.

120
00:05:53,360 --> 00:05:56,578
So that's the big guy that's
over the whole thing.

121
00:05:56,578 --> 00:05:58,287
>> We also have technical management.

122
00:05:58,287 --> 00:06:01,206
Any time we deliver a service or
a skill over to a customer,

123
00:06:01,206 --> 00:06:05,197
we want to make sure that we stand behind
it with the expertise that we have either

124
00:06:05,197 --> 00:06:08,840
in an application or
whatever service that we're delivering.

125
00:06:08,840 --> 00:06:11,788
So we need to make sure that we
manage either human resources or

126
00:06:11,788 --> 00:06:13,670
that we have the technical expertise.

127
00:06:13,670 --> 00:06:18,086
And when the customer does ask us to
do something that we're not just gonna,

128
00:06:18,086 --> 00:06:19,130
well, maybe?

129
00:06:19,130 --> 00:06:20,270
Maybe it can be done?

130
00:06:20,270 --> 00:06:22,470
That we know what's really going on.

131
00:06:22,470 --> 00:06:26,350
So being able to manage that technical
aspect of whatever we provide,

132
00:06:26,350 --> 00:06:28,020
is also an important part of it.

133
00:06:28,020 --> 00:06:31,010
>> And a key concept to remember on the
exam is that technical management is what

134
00:06:31,010 --> 00:06:33,610
covers managing your IT infrastructure.

135
00:06:33,610 --> 00:06:35,270
All right?
When we say infrastructure,

136
00:06:35,270 --> 00:06:38,740
were talking about servers,
Internet connections,

137
00:06:38,740 --> 00:06:40,450
network, networking in general, right?

138
00:06:40,450 --> 00:06:43,920
All your network systems,
your security monitoring.

139
00:06:43,920 --> 00:06:47,100
All the different components
that a systems administrator or

140
00:06:47,100 --> 00:06:49,280
a network administrator
would be working with.

141
00:06:49,280 --> 00:06:51,390
That all falls under technical management.

142
00:06:51,390 --> 00:06:55,850
And it's easy to confuse that with the
next one which is application management.

143
00:06:55,850 --> 00:06:58,720
Because when we think of a particular
server we don't normally think of it

144
00:06:58,720 --> 00:07:00,950
as just a generic piece of hardware.

145
00:07:00,950 --> 00:07:02,690
We think, oh that's my web server.

146
00:07:02,690 --> 00:07:04,460
Or that's my email server.

147
00:07:04,460 --> 00:07:08,680
Well, the web server piece or
the email server piece, that's actually

148
00:07:08,680 --> 00:07:12,490
an application running on top of some
infrastructure, the physical server.

149
00:07:12,490 --> 00:07:17,070
So technical management is focused
on that IT infrastructure.

150
00:07:17,070 --> 00:07:20,170
Application management is managing
an application life cycle.

151
00:07:20,170 --> 00:07:22,798
And we're not gonna go crazy
development in here, but

152
00:07:22,798 --> 00:07:26,512
if you do waterfall or XP or any of
those various development methodologies,

153
00:07:26,512 --> 00:07:30,420
they've got a whole life cycle they
follow, similar to our service life cycle.

154
00:07:30,420 --> 00:07:34,290
But with an application it's
either development or procurement.

155
00:07:34,290 --> 00:07:37,380
Either you make the application yourself,
or you buy it from somebody else.

156
00:07:37,380 --> 00:07:41,230
Then there's design and
deployment as you get it in place.

157
00:07:41,230 --> 00:07:42,370
Then there's operation.

158
00:07:42,370 --> 00:07:44,920
We run that application
as long as we need it.

159
00:07:44,920 --> 00:07:48,633
And then we retire the application by
either upgrading it to a new version, or

160
00:07:48,633 --> 00:07:52,250
replacing it with some other software,
or just canceling it altogether.

161
00:07:52,250 --> 00:07:54,328
That's the application life cycle, and

162
00:07:54,328 --> 00:07:56,710
application management
focuses around that.

163
00:07:56,710 --> 00:07:59,287
And you'd have to be
a pretty big company to

164
00:07:59,287 --> 00:08:04,020
warrant having employees that were
specifically assigned to applications.

165
00:08:04,020 --> 00:08:07,840
Now I've worked at some companies that
large, most companies aren't though.

166
00:08:07,840 --> 00:08:14,280
But you might have specific network admins
that just support the email servers.

167
00:08:14,280 --> 00:08:15,010
Right?
Or

168
00:08:15,010 --> 00:08:18,130
DBAs are a better example of this as
we have database administrators, so

169
00:08:18,130 --> 00:08:22,050
they're managing this database, and the
database software that it's running on,

170
00:08:22,050 --> 00:08:24,520
and they might not have a clue
about the hardware underneath it.

171
00:08:24,520 --> 00:08:28,900
They let the sysadmins deal with it, so
you might have divisions inside of it.

172
00:08:28,900 --> 00:08:31,980
And that's what I wanted to highlight here
is that operations management is that

173
00:08:31,980 --> 00:08:34,680
overall but then we divide it up.

174
00:08:34,680 --> 00:08:36,926
And, technical management,
application management,

175
00:08:36,926 --> 00:08:38,710
those are the two kind of common ones.

176
00:08:38,710 --> 00:08:42,780
There are others that focus around things
like IT finance management and others,

177
00:08:42,780 --> 00:08:46,130
but they're kind of less common.

178
00:08:46,130 --> 00:08:48,011
So it's not something they
really drive on the exam.

179
00:08:48,011 --> 00:08:52,830
All right, so with service operation,
we know that it centers

180
00:08:52,830 --> 00:08:57,220
around keeping our services running,
keeping them optimal, allowing for change.

181
00:08:57,220 --> 00:09:00,110
These are the things that
service operation is all about.

182
00:09:00,110 --> 00:09:03,740
Well, we achieve that through
several different processes.

183
00:09:03,740 --> 00:09:07,770
And at first glance it looks like
service operations has less processes

184
00:09:07,770 --> 00:09:10,080
than the other areas, and so
this might be a shorter one.

185
00:09:10,080 --> 00:09:12,860
But it's actually a pretty
good amount of data.

186
00:09:12,860 --> 00:09:14,960
We start with event management.

187
00:09:14,960 --> 00:09:19,570
So event management, we'll see a little
bit more later, is when things

188
00:09:19,570 --> 00:09:23,990
aren't quite going right, when something
happens and we have to take action, right?

189
00:09:23,990 --> 00:09:25,630
So event management,

190
00:09:25,630 --> 00:09:29,750
how we respond to when something differs
from the way that we want it, right?

191
00:09:29,750 --> 00:09:31,689
Our standard norm is not being maintained.

192
00:09:32,690 --> 00:09:34,260
>> We also have incident management.

193
00:09:34,260 --> 00:09:39,110
Incident management is when we have
an unexpected interruption to the services

194
00:09:39,110 --> 00:09:44,030
that we are trying to provide, and we have
to have a way to deal with those too.

195
00:09:44,030 --> 00:09:46,910
So as incident management
is really about that

196
00:09:46,910 --> 00:09:49,900
unexpected interruption than what we have.

197
00:09:49,900 --> 00:09:51,830
>> So incidents are unexpected.

198
00:09:51,830 --> 00:09:55,130
The converse to that is
a request fulfillment.

199
00:09:55,130 --> 00:09:56,700
Request fulfillment is our next process,

200
00:09:56,700 --> 00:10:00,240
which is expected things,
right or regular routine things.

201
00:10:00,240 --> 00:10:02,830
These aren't emergencies,
we don't need to light up the sirens and

202
00:10:02,830 --> 00:10:04,270
get everybody out of bed.

203
00:10:04,270 --> 00:10:06,170
It's just something in routine
that needs to be done.

204
00:10:06,170 --> 00:10:09,510
And so we need to have mechanisms
in place for those regular,

205
00:10:09,510 --> 00:10:11,170
routine, pre-authorized changes.

206
00:10:11,170 --> 00:10:12,500
And that's request fulfillment.

207
00:10:12,500 --> 00:10:14,520
>> Yeah and we also have problems.

208
00:10:14,520 --> 00:10:15,390
And lot of times,

209
00:10:15,390 --> 00:10:21,590
this is where it gets easy to confuse
the term problems and instances.

210
00:10:21,590 --> 00:10:24,880
So when we talk about instance,
the unexpected interruption.

211
00:10:24,880 --> 00:10:28,270
Problems are things that really arise or
have been there for a long time and

212
00:10:28,270 --> 00:10:31,350
we now have to deal with
them as they do arise.

213
00:10:31,350 --> 00:10:35,347
>> Yeah, it's probably a good idea
right here to differentiate those

214
00:10:35,347 --> 00:10:37,250
because it does get confusing.

215
00:10:38,350 --> 00:10:41,610
The way I think of it, here's the way that
I remember that makes this kind of easy,

216
00:10:41,610 --> 00:10:47,440
is that the incident is typically
a symptom, and the problem is the cause.

217
00:10:47,440 --> 00:10:49,820
And like Ronnie said that the problem
may have been there a long time,

218
00:10:49,820 --> 00:10:50,910
it may have been there forever.

219
00:10:50,910 --> 00:10:51,540
Right?

220
00:10:51,540 --> 00:10:54,170
But we're just now seeing
symptoms based on it.

221
00:10:54,170 --> 00:10:56,170
So think about when a person gets sick.

222
00:10:56,170 --> 00:11:00,290
So if I get sick and
I have a runny nose or a fever, right?

223
00:11:00,290 --> 00:11:02,730
The fever, the runny nose,
those are symptoms.

224
00:11:02,730 --> 00:11:04,250
What's the actual cause?

225
00:11:04,250 --> 00:11:06,920
Well, maybe I've got the flu virus, right?

226
00:11:06,920 --> 00:11:13,560
So the flu virus itself is the actual
problem, but the fever, the runny nose,

227
00:11:13,560 --> 00:11:18,080
those are the incidents, right and that's
how your service operations will run.

228
00:11:18,080 --> 00:11:21,450
You'll get calls from your end users
calling in saying, this isn't working.

229
00:11:21,450 --> 00:11:22,690
Well that's the incident, right.

230
00:11:22,690 --> 00:11:25,128
The incident is,
this person is having this issue, right.

231
00:11:26,340 --> 00:11:28,070
But what's causing that?

232
00:11:28,070 --> 00:11:32,670
And we might able to fix the incident
without fixing the problem, and

233
00:11:32,670 --> 00:11:35,960
that's why ITIL divides
those up separately.

234
00:11:35,960 --> 00:11:37,750
Sometimes they can't
be addressed together.

235
00:11:37,750 --> 00:11:39,380
Sometimes you just don't
have enough information,

236
00:11:39,380 --> 00:11:41,740
but we need to get our users back up and
running first.

237
00:11:41,740 --> 00:11:44,500
So incident management is all
about getting people up and

238
00:11:44,500 --> 00:11:46,430
running again as quickly as possible.

239
00:11:46,430 --> 00:11:50,430
Problem management is our long term
solution to getting this thing solved.

240
00:11:50,430 --> 00:11:54,240
Easy to mix up, right, that
terminology is really easy to confuse.

241
00:11:54,240 --> 00:11:57,880
And let's do an event, too,
because event's kind of easy to mix up.

242
00:11:57,880 --> 00:12:01,280
What's the difference between an event and
an incident?

243
00:12:01,280 --> 00:12:05,680
Well, an event is the actual occurrence of
something that deviates from our baseline.

244
00:12:05,680 --> 00:12:08,860
Now, when a user calls in with an incident

245
00:12:08,860 --> 00:12:11,290
that might not actually
be tied to an event.

246
00:12:11,290 --> 00:12:15,190
This might just be something that's
exposing them to an issue that nobody

247
00:12:15,190 --> 00:12:16,200
else is.

248
00:12:16,200 --> 00:12:19,160
But also,
events might not require an action.

249
00:12:19,160 --> 00:12:21,670
It might just be some performance
monitor that we're tracking, just for

250
00:12:21,670 --> 00:12:22,790
historical data.

251
00:12:22,790 --> 00:12:25,809
And so it's not really tied
to a incident or problem,

252
00:12:25,809 --> 00:12:28,100
it's just data that we're gathering.

253
00:12:28,100 --> 00:12:31,580
So that makes a little bit of a gray
area there, and it does get confusing.

254
00:12:31,580 --> 00:12:34,220
We'll see more as we break
each of those processes apart.

255
00:12:34,220 --> 00:12:39,550
Now the last process that we have inside
of service operation is access management.

256
00:12:39,550 --> 00:12:42,410
And this is a nice short one,
cuz this one's pretty easy.

257
00:12:42,410 --> 00:12:44,660
It's just controlling people's
access to the service.

258
00:12:44,660 --> 00:12:47,980
When you offer a service you
probably don't offer it to

259
00:12:47,980 --> 00:12:49,680
everyone in the world for free.

260
00:12:49,680 --> 00:12:51,070
Some people do, right?

261
00:12:51,070 --> 00:12:52,360
But usually you don't.

262
00:12:52,360 --> 00:12:55,855
Normally you offer it to select customers
or select internal employees or

263
00:12:55,855 --> 00:12:57,215
you do offer it to the public but

264
00:12:57,215 --> 00:13:00,075
you don't allow everybody to
access each other's information.

265
00:13:00,075 --> 00:13:03,395
You create isolation,
that's all access management.

266
00:13:03,395 --> 00:13:06,015
And so we need a process in place
to be able to control that.

267
00:13:06,015 --> 00:13:07,695
Who gets access to what and when.

268
00:13:09,480 --> 00:13:12,880
So those are the primary processes that
we'll see inside of service operations.

269
00:13:12,880 --> 00:13:16,450
Now, the key thing to remember,
aside from those, is that

270
00:13:16,450 --> 00:13:20,620
these processes are pretty generic, and
most organizations are gonna use them,

271
00:13:20,620 --> 00:13:23,800
but you will likely have additional
processes in your company that

272
00:13:23,800 --> 00:13:27,460
are tailored specifically to
whatever it is you do, right.

273
00:13:27,460 --> 00:13:29,050
Every organization is unique.

274
00:13:29,050 --> 00:13:33,190
They offer a different product and so, you
may have to have additional processes to

275
00:13:33,190 --> 00:13:34,950
manage the product that
you're involved in.

276
00:13:34,950 --> 00:13:37,730
So just keep that, bear that in mind.

277
00:13:37,730 --> 00:13:40,040
Doesn't apply to everybody though so
ITIL doesn't cover it.

278
00:13:40,040 --> 00:13:42,770
It's supposed to be a general
best practices framework.

279
00:13:42,770 --> 00:13:44,660
You can't really get into
the specific nitty-gritty.

280
00:13:44,660 --> 00:13:45,480
They tried that, right?

281
00:13:45,480 --> 00:13:49,290
Back when we had the massive volumes of
data, but to get everything concise and

282
00:13:49,290 --> 00:13:53,002
usable, that's kind of been trimmed out.

283
00:13:53,002 --> 00:13:56,860
All right, so that's a pretty good
overview of service operation.

284
00:13:56,860 --> 00:14:00,990
What we're gonna do now is we're just
gonna dive into each of those different

285
00:14:00,990 --> 00:14:02,770
processes, and kinda,
see what they do, right.

286
00:14:03,900 --> 00:14:06,090
So, let's get started
with event management.

287
00:14:06,090 --> 00:14:09,790
And event management is well tracking for
those events and

288
00:14:09,790 --> 00:14:11,690
really the act of tracking itself.

289
00:14:11,690 --> 00:14:13,180
And looking for
where we have deviations, right?

290
00:14:14,340 --> 00:14:17,420
Now, here's where we start to see
a little bit of confusion in terminology

291
00:14:17,420 --> 00:14:18,880
too if we're not careful,

292
00:14:18,880 --> 00:14:22,170
because you don't necessarily monitor
every single thing that there is.

293
00:14:22,170 --> 00:14:26,130
There are some things that you're just not
able to monitor and generate events on.

294
00:14:26,130 --> 00:14:31,890
But at a minimum you monitor your
configuration items, your CIs.

295
00:14:31,890 --> 00:14:34,390
Remember back in change
management we said that a CI,

296
00:14:34,390 --> 00:14:38,970
configuration item, was any asset that
we could alter the properties of, right.

297
00:14:38,970 --> 00:14:40,990
Anything that we could change.

298
00:14:40,990 --> 00:14:42,540
So if you have a server and

299
00:14:42,540 --> 00:14:46,340
you apply a software update to it
that's a change to that item, right.

300
00:14:46,340 --> 00:14:48,780
You may not change its base behavior but

301
00:14:48,780 --> 00:14:53,150
you're modifying the software which
could lead to incidence, right?

302
00:14:53,150 --> 00:14:54,870
So, we need to be able to track that.

303
00:14:54,870 --> 00:14:55,930
It could be performance counters.

304
00:14:55,930 --> 00:15:00,230
We could say all of my servers should be
operating at below 80% CPU utilization.

305
00:15:00,230 --> 00:15:04,090
And then one day I have a server at 82%,
right.

306
00:15:04,090 --> 00:15:06,870
That's an event,
we've crossed that threshold, and

307
00:15:06,870 --> 00:15:08,830
that's what event management is all about.

308
00:15:08,830 --> 00:15:13,530
We define a baseline, what we expect
things to be and then we monitor for

309
00:15:13,530 --> 00:15:14,680
when we cross it, right?

310
00:15:14,680 --> 00:15:18,050
And you'll see where they refer
to it in ITIL as a baseline, or

311
00:15:18,050 --> 00:15:22,590
they refer to it as normal operations,
NO, or standard normal operations,

312
00:15:22,590 --> 00:15:23,850
you'll see a few variations of it.

313
00:15:23,850 --> 00:15:27,300
But that's just what we expect
our servers to be doing.

314
00:15:28,320 --> 00:15:30,960
>> We also can measure this against
our service level agreements

315
00:15:30,960 --> 00:15:32,950
that we have with the customer, too.

316
00:15:32,950 --> 00:15:35,990
That way, they can actually go ahead and
be able to say,

317
00:15:35,990 --> 00:15:40,400
look, here's what we're expecting to see,
and this is not what's happening.

318
00:15:40,400 --> 00:15:43,690
So, it gives us that basis to
be able to now go ahead and

319
00:15:43,690 --> 00:15:47,710
do the things that we need to do to be
able to manage the events that come along.

320
00:15:47,710 --> 00:15:50,743
So you might have where you go well
somebody else made this change that

321
00:15:50,743 --> 00:15:51,750
wasn't supposed to.

322
00:15:51,750 --> 00:15:53,093
It's unauthorized, and

323
00:15:53,093 --> 00:15:56,210
that gives us now an event that
we can now do something about.

324
00:15:56,210 --> 00:16:00,705
>> Yeah, SLAs are important to remember
because It's not necessarily that we have

325
00:16:00,705 --> 00:16:02,170
a problem on our network.

326
00:16:02,170 --> 00:16:08,550
So let's say that I ordered a fiber
optic line for our building.

327
00:16:08,550 --> 00:16:12,560
And they promised me a 99% uptime on it.

328
00:16:12,560 --> 00:16:15,027
That was the SLA on that fiber
line running to the building.

329
00:16:15,027 --> 00:16:16,200
Okay?

330
00:16:16,200 --> 00:16:20,230
And throughout the year during
business hours I had 100% uptime.

331
00:16:20,230 --> 00:16:21,730
Everything was fine.

332
00:16:21,730 --> 00:16:25,370
But every now and then, in the middle
of the night, that line would drop out.

333
00:16:25,370 --> 00:16:29,220
It didn't impact my business, but the line
dropped out, and by the end of the year,

334
00:16:29,220 --> 00:16:30,030
I only had 95% uptime.

335
00:16:31,390 --> 00:16:34,300
Well, technically, the SLA was violated.

336
00:16:34,300 --> 00:16:38,140
And while it didn't occur during business
hours, well it didn't impact my business.

337
00:16:38,140 --> 00:16:41,860
There was no like incident or
whatever as a result of it.

338
00:16:41,860 --> 00:16:43,350
There was still this problem.

339
00:16:43,350 --> 00:16:46,490
This thing that occurred throughout
the year and the SLA was violated.

340
00:16:46,490 --> 00:16:49,530
So, we have to be able to track that so
we can deal with it.

341
00:16:49,530 --> 00:16:52,555
Just because it didn't happen
during business hours this year,

342
00:16:52,555 --> 00:16:54,428
doesn't mean that it won't next year.

343
00:16:54,428 --> 00:16:57,905
We just got lucky this time,
and next year maybe it will, so

344
00:16:57,905 --> 00:17:02,310
they need to be addressed, and so
SLAs will change your baseline.

345
00:17:02,310 --> 00:17:04,710
You have a baseline of what's
considered acceptable, but

346
00:17:04,710 --> 00:17:08,170
if you've entered into some kind of SLA,
some service-level agreement,

347
00:17:08,170 --> 00:17:12,380
just because you maintain the baseline
doesn't mean you met the SLA, so you might

348
00:17:12,380 --> 00:17:16,350
as well turn the SLA into your baseline
and that's what a lot of organizations do.

349
00:17:16,350 --> 00:17:19,790
All right, so what can lead to this?

350
00:17:19,790 --> 00:17:23,040
What could cause an event, right?

351
00:17:23,040 --> 00:17:25,450
Well it's really anything that we choose.

352
00:17:25,450 --> 00:17:27,330
You can create your own scripts and

353
00:17:27,330 --> 00:17:30,230
monitoring systems to generate
events based on anything.

354
00:17:30,230 --> 00:17:33,804
But some common examples
unauthorized changes.

355
00:17:33,804 --> 00:17:37,150
I see where somebody's gone and
modified a setting on a server.

356
00:17:37,150 --> 00:17:39,440
A change in the Windows registry.

357
00:17:39,440 --> 00:17:42,080
An edited configuration file on Linux.

358
00:17:42,080 --> 00:17:44,790
A new kernel extension in Mac OS.

359
00:17:44,790 --> 00:17:47,580
Something has been modified
in the source code.

360
00:17:47,580 --> 00:17:49,130
We can just monitor for changes.

361
00:17:49,130 --> 00:17:52,520
And whenever a change happens, good or
bad, we don't care about that.

362
00:17:52,520 --> 00:17:55,886
We need to be able to match
that change to a change ticket.

363
00:17:55,886 --> 00:17:58,456
And if there wasn't a change ticket,
that's an unauthorized change,

364
00:17:58,456 --> 00:18:00,110
that's an event, all right.

365
00:18:00,110 --> 00:18:03,820
Hasn't necessarily caused an incident,
hasn't necessarily caused a problem.

366
00:18:03,820 --> 00:18:04,710
But it's an event, right?

367
00:18:04,710 --> 00:18:07,560
That's that differentiator
that we have that says

368
00:18:07,560 --> 00:18:10,040
why an event is separate from an instance.

369
00:18:10,040 --> 00:18:11,390
>> We all know, we also,

370
00:18:11,390 --> 00:18:14,970
might want to take into account what
we call server performance too.

371
00:18:14,970 --> 00:18:19,550
And we have a lot of customers that are
trying to use a particular service that

372
00:18:19,550 --> 00:18:21,140
we're offering on a server.

373
00:18:21,140 --> 00:18:24,500
We may go ahead and tell the server
that we need to monitor and

374
00:18:24,500 --> 00:18:27,480
be able to track once
the processor hits over 50% or

375
00:18:27,480 --> 00:18:32,460
we're actually using too much RAM or
this GIO is actually getting too high.

376
00:18:32,460 --> 00:18:35,290
And we can trigger those that will
actually give us the alert to let us know

377
00:18:35,290 --> 00:18:38,890
that here's something that
actually has happened now.

378
00:18:38,890 --> 00:18:43,310
>> Network intrusion, right, if a hacker
or an unauthorized external user or

379
00:18:43,310 --> 00:18:47,060
even an unauthorized internal user gets
into a system that they shouldn't have.

380
00:18:47,060 --> 00:18:48,540
We'll see that in our audit logs and

381
00:18:48,540 --> 00:18:51,160
we may have alerting kind
of built off of that.

This was a service ticket

So for example I worked in an insurance

so that's a real benefit if

And so you might notice a trend that

00:46:37,050 --> 00:46:39,450
So you might have tickets

And you use labels to track that,

Maybe we need to do a little more training

basic troubleshooting steps so that they
don't have to call up the service desk

every time they have an issue.

00:47:23,170 --> 00:47:26,720
These are things we can address

Now if you've done good logging

00:47:30,810 --> 00:47:33,690
It can be really hard

00:47:33,690 --> 00:47:35,230

00:47:35,230 --> 00:47:37,030
If you don't know the systems

If you don't know what's going on.

But the categorization may be really hard.

This might be one of those

When I listed these steps,

And the reason I did is because you don't

Oh, prioritization.

00:48:19,360 --> 00:48:22,950
>> When we talk about prioritization,

00:48:22,950 --> 00:48:25,880
being able to assign
a priority to an incident so

00:48:25,880 --> 00:48:28,900

00:48:28,900 --> 00:48:33,830
A lot of times when we hear about

00:48:33,830 --> 00:48:36,510
have all the knowledge that we need so we
might actually have to assign it a higher

00:48:36,510 --> 00:48:40,922
priority or another one so that way
it can be escalated when necessary.

00:48:40,922 --> 00:48:43,470
Usually the prioritization

00:48:43,470 --> 00:48:47,320
One is what we call urgency and

00:48:48,690 --> 00:48:53,640
>> So impact, that's what's gonna
be dictating how much of our

00:48:53,640 --> 00:48:57,185
regular business processes are basically
being interrupted or affected.

00:48:57,185 --> 00:48:59,435
Because they might not be interrupted,

00:48:59,435 --> 00:49:01,705
So how big of a deal is this?

00:49:01,705 --> 00:49:06,405
Is this incident just affecting one user,

00:49:06,405 --> 00:49:09,870
Are they still able to work, or are they

00:49:09,870 --> 00:49:11,180

00:49:11,180 --> 00:49:14,290
We need to know how this is impacting

00:49:15,680 --> 00:49:19,882
And then urgency, that's how long

00:49:19,882 --> 00:49:24,870
So, sorry,

00:49:24,870 --> 00:49:30,250
If we're doing proactive event detection,

00:49:30,250 --> 00:49:34,390

00:49:34,390 --> 00:49:35,890

00:49:35,890 --> 00:49:39,430
And we're saying, all right this is

00:49:39,430 --> 00:49:43,270

00:49:43,270 --> 00:49:45,710
You might have an SLA that says

00:49:45,710 --> 00:49:47,540
Well you just went down.

00:49:47,540 --> 00:49:50,170
Okay you've got two hours

00:49:50,170 --> 00:49:52,750

00:49:52,750 --> 00:49:56,860
So if you've only got 2 hours,

00:49:56,860 --> 00:49:58,820

00:50:00,188 --> 00:50:05,345
We need to know how much time we have

1017
00:50:05,345 --> 00:50:10,099
they always define it as the time

1018
00:50:10,099 --> 00:50:11,043
But a lot of us, and

1019
00:50:11,043 --> 00:50:15,055
it's the mistake I made right there at
the beginning of my sentence a minute ago,

1020
00:50:15,055 --> 00:50:18,596

00:50:18,596 --> 00:50:22,839
Because impact doesn't normally kick in

00:50:22,839 --> 00:50:24,770

1023
00:50:24,770 --> 00:50:29,040
And so the urgency that time frame might

00:50:29,040 --> 00:50:32,470

1025
00:50:32,470 --> 00:50:34,650
they always start at right

1026
00:50:34,650 --> 00:50:36,750
So how much time do we have to get on it?

00:50:36,750 --> 00:50:40,820
So impact and urgency, those are what's

1028
00:50:40,820 --> 00:50:43,660
and for the priority,

00:50:43,660 --> 00:50:44,770
You can pick whatever you wanna call it.

1030
00:50:44,770 --> 00:50:47,420
You might say I've got high,

00:50:47,420 --> 00:50:50,054
High priority, normal priority,

00:50:50,054 --> 00:50:53,930

00:50:53,930 --> 00:50:58,500
One of the ones that I always see,

1034
00:50:58,500 --> 00:51:03,030
low because how do you feel

00:51:03,030 --> 00:51:05,350

And you're looking at and you're like,

00:51:07,770 --> 00:51:10,580
I'm really passionate about this and

00:51:10,580 --> 00:51:12,150
People get frustrated.

00:51:12,150 --> 00:51:14,780
So many companies have moved
away from that terminology and

00:51:14,780 --> 00:51:18,450
so like the last organization

00:51:18,450 --> 00:51:20,030
Sev one, sev two, sev three.

00:51:20,030 --> 00:51:22,840
So it's severity one,

00:51:22,840 --> 00:51:26,990
And if anybody asked and they said,

What does that mean?

And we would say,

00:51:30,360 --> 00:51:32,460
So in their minds they would say,

1047
00:51:32,460 --> 00:51:34,120
They know this is a problem.

1048
00:51:34,120 --> 00:51:35,400
Severe.

00:51:35,400 --> 00:51:38,840
They wouldn't know that 3 was
our lowest priority, right?

00:51:38,840 --> 00:51:44,300
But we could say, if they inquire more,

00:51:44,300 --> 00:51:49,360
like building on fire, or the entire

00:51:49,360 --> 00:51:54,140
Yours is sev 3, it's pretty close to

people would understand.

00:51:54,820 --> 00:51:57,270
It gave people a more warm, fuzzy feeling.

00:51:57,270 --> 00:52:00,560
It's entirely up to you what

How big that impact is, and

that we've gotta exercise to

If we're losing money right now

00:52:12,940 --> 00:52:15,360
We need to get going right now.

1061
00:52:15,360 --> 00:52:16,830
We can't wait, right?

1062
00:52:16,830 --> 00:52:18,760
But if the impact hasn't kicked in yet,

00:52:18,760 --> 00:52:21,490
we might be able to wait a bit
