1279
01:03:58,260 --> 01:04:02,060
That's a common thing to do and you're
attaching the incident to the problem,

1280
01:04:02,060 --> 01:04:04,200
so now they're kinda in
these separate entities.

1281
01:04:04,200 --> 01:04:05,340
That's useful if there's a workaround.

1282
01:04:05,340 --> 01:04:10,476
If there's no workaround, then usually the
incident leads right into the problem so

1283
01:04:10,476 --> 01:04:13,840
we keep them together, but
that's entirely up to you.

1284
01:04:13,840 --> 01:04:17,340
All right, that incident closure,
is one of the easier stops right?

1285
01:04:17,340 --> 01:04:18,140
The problem is done.

1286
01:04:18,140 --> 01:04:21,520
So, we do need to verify that
the end user is satisfied.

1287
01:04:21,520 --> 01:04:25,650
Whoever reported this in, just
because we think we fixed the problem,

1288
01:04:25,650 --> 01:04:27,170
we may not have actually addressed it for
them.

1289
01:04:27,170 --> 01:04:28,970
So, we need to make sure
that their satisfied, and

1290
01:04:28,970 --> 01:04:30,560
if they are, we close the ticket.

1291
01:04:30,560 --> 01:04:33,220
We document what happened,
we put everything in there so

1292
01:04:33,220 --> 01:04:37,240
it's available for reference in
the future if the incident ever reoccurs.

1293
01:04:37,240 --> 01:04:38,990
But then we close it, and we walk away.

1294
01:04:38,990 --> 01:04:40,580
Kick your feet up on the desk and
take a break, right?

1295
01:04:42,454 --> 01:04:48,430
Now unfortunately, things don't always
stay fixed, it is possible to misdiagnose.

1296
01:04:48,430 --> 01:04:53,100
We may have seen the incident,
tracked it back to a problem, and

1297
01:04:53,100 --> 01:04:55,950
resolved the problem as far as we knew.

1298
01:04:55,950 --> 01:04:57,320
Deployed it and

1299
01:04:57,320 --> 01:05:01,690
now we're back in business, but
we may not have fully patched the problem.

1300
01:05:01,690 --> 01:05:05,640
Or there may have actually been a
secondary problem that we just didn't see

1301
01:05:05,640 --> 01:05:08,620
until we only fixed part
of our overall problem.

1302
01:05:08,620 --> 01:05:12,150
And in that scenario we may
get a new incident back again.

1303
01:05:12,150 --> 01:05:15,220
All right, now here's where things
get a little bit tricky because

1304
01:05:15,220 --> 01:05:19,040
you could just create an all new incident
and then start working the problem again.

1305
01:05:19,040 --> 01:05:23,760
But it's better if you can to
reopen the previous incident.

1306
01:05:23,760 --> 01:05:28,340
That you closed it, but you reopen it so
that you can keep that relationship.

1307
01:05:28,340 --> 01:05:31,770
That you know hey, this is actually
tied to this previous incident.

1308
01:05:31,770 --> 01:05:35,140
And most ticketing software won't
require you to open the original ticket.

1309
01:05:35,140 --> 01:05:38,290
It'll generate a new one and
it'll link it to the original one so

1310
01:05:38,290 --> 01:05:40,000
you can see how that occurred,

1311
01:05:40,000 --> 01:05:44,028
because it might be a completely different
user reporting the new one, right.

1312
01:05:44,028 --> 01:05:48,930
So maybe Ronnie called in one day and
said the website was slow, and

1313
01:05:48,930 --> 01:05:52,410
so we located a problem and we fixed it.

1314
01:05:52,410 --> 01:05:57,180
But then five days later, Nate calls
in and says the website is slow, well,

1315
01:05:57,180 --> 01:05:58,610
I don't want to go and

1316
01:05:58,610 --> 01:06:02,615
reopen Ronnie's ticket because
Ronnie's not involved in this one.

1317
01:06:02,615 --> 01:06:06,435
I wanna go in and create a new ticket cuz
now Nate is the person who reported there,

1318
01:06:06,435 --> 01:06:07,555
the end-user.

1319
01:06:07,555 --> 01:06:11,265
But I'm gonna link those together to say,
it's the same problem.

1320
01:06:11,265 --> 01:06:12,985
They're both reporting
the website as slow.

1321
01:06:14,335 --> 01:06:15,885
I say it's the same problem ,is it?

1322
01:06:15,885 --> 01:06:17,265
Didn't that get solved?

1323
01:06:17,265 --> 01:06:17,895
Let's find out.

1324
01:06:17,895 --> 01:06:20,230
And we start to build our
diagnosis from there.

1325
01:06:20,230 --> 01:06:21,490
Try and figure out that issue.

1326
01:06:21,490 --> 01:06:25,370
So that resolution recovery and
incident closure,

1327
01:06:25,370 --> 01:06:29,610
those are important, but it might not
quite fix things at the end of the day.

1328
01:06:29,610 --> 01:06:31,520
And then we have to reopen that ticket.

1329
01:06:31,520 --> 01:06:33,490
So that's kinda that last stage.

1330
01:06:33,490 --> 01:06:37,540
Now, that was a lot of stages,
let's just recap that real quick, right?

1331
01:06:37,540 --> 01:06:41,980
We did incident identification, so knowing
that the problem has occurred, right?

1332
01:06:41,980 --> 01:06:43,330
Then, or, I say problem.

1333
01:06:43,330 --> 01:06:44,710
Knowing that the incident has occurred.

1334
01:06:44,710 --> 01:06:46,390
We don't necessarily know the problem.

1335
01:06:46,390 --> 01:06:48,040
Then, incident logging.

1336
01:06:48,040 --> 01:06:50,140
We log it, put it on record.

1337
01:06:50,140 --> 01:06:52,100
Incident categorization, right?

1338
01:06:52,100 --> 01:06:55,130
We flag it with various labels, so
that we can use that for analysis later.

1339
01:06:56,180 --> 01:07:00,090
Incident prioritization, so
we flag how urgent this is,

1340
01:07:00,090 --> 01:07:03,460
so do we need to get on this
incident right now, or can it wait?

1341
01:07:04,472 --> 01:07:09,480
Initial diagnosis,we try and
isolate the issue and fix it if we can.

1342
01:07:09,480 --> 01:07:12,830
If not, we move to incident escalation.

1343
01:07:12,830 --> 01:07:14,910
We move it up to the next
tier of support personnel.

1344
01:07:15,980 --> 01:07:17,650
Then investigation and diagnosis.

1345
01:07:17,650 --> 01:07:20,940
We actually dive in and try and
find what the real cause of this is.

1346
01:07:20,940 --> 01:07:25,060
What the problem is and that's when
we come up with our resolution and

1347
01:07:25,060 --> 01:07:26,150
recovery right.

1348
01:07:26,150 --> 01:07:27,710
We solve the problem.

1349
01:07:27,710 --> 01:07:31,970
We put a resolution in place, and
now we're back up and running.

1350
01:07:31,970 --> 01:07:34,600
That leads to closure,
we shut the ticket down.

1351
01:07:34,600 --> 01:07:38,430
And then lastly,
if the problem isn't truly solved,

1352
01:07:38,430 --> 01:07:41,040
we reopen if necessary, all right?

1353
01:07:41,040 --> 01:07:44,300
So those are the steps
recommended by ITIL.

1354
01:07:44,300 --> 01:07:49,310
To go through and service a ticket,
service an incident that comes in.

1355
01:07:49,310 --> 01:07:53,540
There's a few extra little things that
we might add to this in our environment,

1356
01:07:53,540 --> 01:07:55,190
which we'll see in some
of the other processes.

1357
01:07:55,190 --> 01:07:58,270
And there's some of these things that
we might choose to consolidate, right?

1358
01:07:58,270 --> 01:07:59,960
No sense in having a lot
of things separate.

1359
01:07:59,960 --> 01:08:03,730
Like prioritization and categorization.

1360
01:08:03,730 --> 01:08:07,680
A lot of people will assign priorities
by categories, so they combine those.

1361
01:08:07,680 --> 01:08:09,900
So your environment may look
a little bit different.

1362
01:08:09,900 --> 01:08:13,675
But these are all the different components
that are really being addressed as part of

1363
01:08:13,675 --> 01:08:14,753
incident management.

1364
01:08:16,656 --> 01:08:20,658
All right, I think that is pretty much as
far as we can go on incident management

1365
01:08:20,658 --> 01:08:22,455
without driving everybody nuts.

1366
01:08:22,455 --> 01:08:24,290
>> [LAUGH]
>> If you want to learn more,

1367
01:08:24,290 --> 01:08:27,380
definitely check out
the service operation manual.

1368
01:08:27,380 --> 01:08:32,130
Because it goes into great depth,
showing all sorts of reports and

1369
01:08:32,130 --> 01:08:33,040
information schemes.

1370
01:08:33,040 --> 01:08:36,325
And all sorts of really good
best practices in there.

1371
01:08:36,325 --> 01:08:40,435
But, for ITIL foundation, that's basically
what's involved with incident management.

1372
01:08:40,435 --> 01:08:41,625
>> Yeah.

1373
01:08:41,625 --> 01:08:43,585
Moving on from incidences,

1374
01:08:43,585 --> 01:08:48,560
which really are the uninterrupted
work that we have in our business.

1375
01:08:48,560 --> 01:08:49,310
Uninterrupted work.

1376
01:08:49,310 --> 01:08:49,810
What did I say?

1377
01:08:51,220 --> 01:08:54,670
Interruptions to our regular work
is what I was trying to say.

1378
01:08:54,670 --> 01:08:59,000
With incidences we not have things
that we have to do each and every day.

1379
01:08:59,000 --> 01:09:03,270
Changes that end up occurring and
as the service desk, as people that are in

1380
01:09:03,270 --> 01:09:08,570
the service operations we still need to
respond to what we call regular requests.

1381
01:09:08,570 --> 01:09:12,910
And the way that we do that is through a
process that we call request fulfillment.

1382
01:09:12,910 --> 01:09:16,280
>> Yeah, and it's gonna be one of the
responsibilities of the service desk to

1383
01:09:16,280 --> 01:09:17,550
identify what they're dealing with.

1384
01:09:17,550 --> 01:09:20,590
Whether it is an incident, and
needs to through full incident management.

1385
01:09:20,590 --> 01:09:21,870
Or if it's just a request.

1386
01:09:21,870 --> 01:09:24,420
And request we've already kind of planned
out exactly what they're going to do.

1387
01:09:24,420 --> 01:09:28,890
We've got our chart of steps, our
policy or whatever on how to handle it.

1388
01:09:28,890 --> 01:09:32,570
That's no big deal on that one, and the
service desk will typically will resolve

1389
01:09:32,570 --> 01:09:36,350
whatever that request was, unless is
requires elevated privileges, right?

1390
01:09:36,350 --> 01:09:38,530
So it is definitely
a process we need to tackle,

1391
01:09:38,530 --> 01:09:42,910
but we don't have all that much time left
on our timer here so why don't we do this.

1392
01:09:42,910 --> 01:09:47,510
Let's go ahead and wrap it up here and
we're gonna come back with a part

1393
01:09:47,510 --> 01:09:51,130
two because we still have, we've got
request fulfillment, problem management,

1394
01:09:51,130 --> 01:09:53,140
and access management still to get to.

1395
01:09:53,140 --> 01:09:55,820
But we'll split those off
into a separate episode so

1396
01:09:55,820 --> 01:09:58,120
we don't blow our minds here all in one.

1397
01:09:58,120 --> 01:10:00,240
Instant management was a lot to cover.

1398
01:10:00,240 --> 01:10:01,550
So we definitely wanna stop there and

1399
01:10:01,550 --> 01:10:04,620
give that a moment to sink
in before we move on.

1400
01:10:04,620 --> 01:10:08,510
So, let me remind you guys
if you have any questions

1401
01:10:08,510 --> 01:10:10,620
live during the show you can ask.

1402
01:10:10,620 --> 01:10:14,720
You can go to http://itpro.tv/live and
you'll see the chat box beneath the video.

1403
01:10:14,720 --> 01:10:15,500
Post your questions there.

1404
01:10:15,500 --> 01:10:18,070
We monitor and answer during the show.

1405
01:10:18,070 --> 01:10:21,710
If you have any questions after the show,
well you can go to our Q&A forums.

1406
01:10:21,710 --> 01:10:26,550
At the top of every page on ITProTV you'll
see a link that says Q&A, click on it.

1407
01:10:26,550 --> 01:10:29,610
It'll take you to the forums, and you can
post your questions there, we monitor and

1408
01:10:29,610 --> 01:10:30,700
answer after the show.

1409
01:10:30,700 --> 01:10:33,950
We want to make sure you guys have
the information you need to be successful.

1410
01:10:35,100 --> 01:10:37,160
All right, well,
I hope you guys enjoyed today's episode.

1411
01:10:37,160 --> 01:10:39,150
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

1412
01:10:39,150 --> 01:10:40,170
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

1413
01:10:40,170 --> 01:10:41,868
>> And we'll see you next time.

1414
01:10:41,868 --> 01:10:51,868
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Service Operation Part 2
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,097 --> 00:00:35,801
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening.

3
00:00:35,801 --> 00:00:38,090
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:38,090 --> 00:00:38,970
I'm your host Don Pezet.

5
00:00:40,050 --> 00:00:41,250
Back again with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

6
00:00:41,250 --> 00:00:41,920
How's it going Ronnie?

7
00:00:41,920 --> 00:00:43,010
>> It is going well today.

8
00:00:43,010 --> 00:00:48,145
We are ready for
another episode into IT foundations.

9
00:00:48,145 --> 00:00:51,720
>> [LAUGH]
>> And so, we're getting into, what is it?

10
00:00:51,720 --> 00:00:52,610
Request fulfillment.

11
00:00:52,610 --> 00:00:54,120
>> Yep.
>> Is what we're moving into.

12
00:00:54,120 --> 00:00:56,790
>> Now in our last episode we
started service operation and

13
00:00:56,790 --> 00:00:59,620
we spent the bulk of our time
talking about incident management.

14
00:00:59,620 --> 00:01:01,781
Which is really important.

15
00:01:01,781 --> 00:01:04,597
But, we didn't get to some of
the processes that were still available.

16
00:01:04,597 --> 00:01:08,483
So in this episode, we're picking up as a
part two to the service operation episode

17
00:01:08,483 --> 00:01:10,440
and continuing on with those processes.

18
00:01:10,440 --> 00:01:11,370
And you're exactly right, Ronnie.

19
00:01:11,370 --> 00:01:14,500
The first one we need to
tackle is request fulfillment.

20
00:01:14,500 --> 00:01:19,900
Now, incident management and request
fulfillment are very, very similar.

21
00:01:19,900 --> 00:01:25,420
In both scenarios you typically have an
end-user call, email, whatever, reach out

22
00:01:25,420 --> 00:01:30,650
to the support desk or the service desk
and ask about something they need changed.

23
00:01:30,650 --> 00:01:34,050
In an incident,
it's an unanticipated thing.

24
00:01:34,050 --> 00:01:37,170
It's some kind of deviation from what
we expect our network to be doing.

25
00:01:37,170 --> 00:01:40,240
It's an issue that we
need to get resolved.

26
00:01:40,240 --> 00:01:42,630
But requests fulfillment
is very different.

27
00:01:42,630 --> 00:01:44,980
This is just a normal activity.

28
00:01:44,980 --> 00:01:48,440
It is a change that's being
made to the network but

29
00:01:48,440 --> 00:01:53,430
it's a minor change and
it's typically pre-authorized and

30
00:01:53,430 --> 00:01:56,640
that means it doesn't have to
go through change management.

31
00:01:56,640 --> 00:02:00,160
This is something that your service desk
personnel will have the authority to go

32
00:02:00,160 --> 00:02:04,340
ahead and implement without testing,
without going through change management,

33
00:02:04,340 --> 00:02:06,730
without having to get specific approval.

34
00:02:06,730 --> 00:02:11,870
This is a low impact activity that
they can take with generally no or

35
00:02:11,870 --> 00:02:13,670
extremely little risk.

36
00:02:13,670 --> 00:02:15,620
That doesn't mean we don't
apply any oversight to it.

37
00:02:15,620 --> 00:02:17,250
But it means that they can just go and

38
00:02:17,250 --> 00:02:19,980
get the job done without invoking
the rest of all of our processes.

39
00:02:19,980 --> 00:02:20,690
>> Yeah.

40
00:02:20,690 --> 00:02:23,900
For example,
we may get somebody who calls up and says,

41
00:02:23,900 --> 00:02:26,190
hey I forgot what my password is.

42
00:02:26,190 --> 00:02:27,820
And I need my password reset.

43
00:02:27,820 --> 00:02:31,830
Well that doesn't necessarily require
an escalation up to somebody that's

44
00:02:31,830 --> 00:02:34,100
working on the servers to
be able to approve that.

45
00:02:34,100 --> 00:02:35,840
We might wanna go ahead and
say, all right.

46
00:02:35,840 --> 00:02:38,970
At this level, go ahead and
allow that to be done.

47
00:02:38,970 --> 00:02:42,200
It could be that someone's machine just
needs to be replaced because they're

48
00:02:42,200 --> 00:02:44,370
no longer able to get access
to it due to malware.

49
00:02:44,370 --> 00:02:47,005
We may just go ahead and replace that and
machine out that, as well.

50
00:02:47,005 --> 00:02:51,110
So there's many different things that
we can do right here that will help to

51
00:02:51,110 --> 00:02:56,330
relieve some of the overburdening
pressure on some of our upper level tier

52
00:02:56,330 --> 00:03:00,580
with some of the things that we
can just do at the lowest level.

53
00:03:00,580 --> 00:03:01,980
>> Yeah, and
it may not even be a bad thing.

54
00:03:01,980 --> 00:03:04,690
It may be a good thing like,
hey we hired a new employee.

55
00:03:04,690 --> 00:03:07,470
So that new employee,
they need a user account created and

56
00:03:07,470 --> 00:03:10,400
they need some permissions assigned so
they can get in and do some work, right?

57
00:03:10,400 --> 00:03:13,420
They need an email, mail box setup so

58
00:03:13,420 --> 00:03:18,420
those are not problems or
incidents, this is just an activity.

59
00:03:18,420 --> 00:03:20,400
>> Regular things.
>> Yeah it's a request and

60
00:03:20,400 --> 00:03:24,860
we're fulfilling that request so that term
request fulfillment is just kind of taking

61
00:03:24,860 --> 00:03:28,080
the kind of negativity away from it and
saying this is a standard item,

62
00:03:28,080 --> 00:03:29,650
this is what's gonna happen.

63
00:03:29,650 --> 00:03:32,740
So these are separated from incidents.

64
00:03:32,740 --> 00:03:36,270
When a service desk personnel
receives that communication in

65
00:03:36,270 --> 00:03:38,370
they identify which it's going to be.

66
00:03:38,370 --> 00:03:40,610
If it sounds like an incident,
if it's not normal stuff,

67
00:03:40,610 --> 00:03:44,270
it needs to go through incident management
and they'll shift it off to that process.

68
00:03:44,270 --> 00:03:48,280
But, if it's just request fulfillment,
then they'll handle the request and

69
00:03:48,280 --> 00:03:52,210
it's possible that the end user
calls it in as an incident and

70
00:03:52,210 --> 00:03:55,730
the service personnel just has to
convert it over to being a request.

71
00:03:55,730 --> 00:03:58,690
It's not something critical.

72
00:03:58,690 --> 00:04:01,850
The end-user might think that it is but
at the end of the day it isn't.

73
00:04:01,850 --> 00:04:03,400
So no escalation.

74
00:04:03,400 --> 00:04:05,730
It gets resolved right
there at the first tier.

75
00:04:05,730 --> 00:04:06,250
And it's done.

76
00:04:07,730 --> 00:04:11,200
>> Normally with this level of request
fulfillment we are following fairly strict

77
00:04:11,200 --> 00:04:15,910
policies to ensure that our users are
getting the exact service that they need

78
00:04:15,910 --> 00:04:18,350
and getting it resolved
as quickly as possible.

79
00:04:18,350 --> 00:04:21,420
So here you'll see the use of things like
scripts so that we can make sure that

80
00:04:21,420 --> 00:04:25,800
we're actually doing everything that
really can fulfill what their wish is, and

81
00:04:25,800 --> 00:04:29,590
that way we make sure that we're actually
covering everything that we need to.

82
00:04:29,590 --> 00:04:30,660
>> You've gotta be careful with this.

83
00:04:30,660 --> 00:04:32,540
These are pre-authorized changes.

84
00:04:32,540 --> 00:04:35,500
That means they're gonna implement
a change in your network,

85
00:04:35,500 --> 00:04:38,160
creating a user account,
resetting somebody's password.

86
00:04:38,160 --> 00:04:42,875
They're gonna implement that without
someone else giving them review, right.

87
00:04:42,875 --> 00:04:45,920
Rview will happen afterwards,
but prior to the change,

88
00:04:45,920 --> 00:04:47,740
nobody's double checking their work.

89
00:04:47,740 --> 00:04:51,400
So, you will typically have very strict
policies in place detailing exactly what

90
00:04:51,400 --> 00:04:51,990
they can do.

91
00:04:51,990 --> 00:04:54,930
If you have a script like Ronnie said,

00:05:49,680 --> 00:05:52,300
That way they know that hey, whoa,

00:05:55,340 --> 00:05:56,210
>> Yeah.

an incident that's when

So it's possible you

It can happen.

00:29:07,390 --> 00:29:10,490

00:29:10,490 --> 00:29:13,540

00:29:14,560 --> 00:29:19,470
A normal service operation NSO that's in

00:29:22,850 --> 00:29:25,810
So the change ticket is not saying

00:29:29,220 --> 00:29:30,820

00:29:30,820 --> 00:29:33,160

00:29:33,160 --> 00:29:34,750

00:29:34,750 --> 00:29:37,870

00:29:37,870 --> 00:29:42,750

00:29:42,750 --> 00:29:48,050

00:29:48,050 --> 00:29:51,520

00:29:55,010 --> 00:29:58,050

00:29:58,050 --> 00:30:01,620

00:30:01,620 --> 00:30:05,470
>> Because problems can become more

00:30:05,470 --> 00:30:07,170
more people get involved,

00:30:07,170 --> 00:30:10,670

00:30:10,670 --> 00:30:13,130

00:30:13,130 --> 00:30:17,300

00:30:17,300 --> 00:30:20,750

00:30:20,750 --> 00:30:24,780
no one else goes ahead and continues

00:30:27,990 --> 00:30:30,810

00:30:32,070 --> 00:30:34,370

00:30:48,270 --> 00:30:51,570

00:30:51,570 --> 00:30:53,150
If it does resurface,

00:30:53,150 --> 00:30:55,640

00:30:55,640 --> 00:30:59,170

00:30:59,170 --> 00:31:00,370

00:31:01,340 --> 00:31:05,380

00:31:06,630 --> 00:31:09,190

When you offer a service it's rare

Biometrics and so

00:38:09,600 --> 00:38:11,570
Don, a lot of this sounds

A lot of people will get pigeon holed and

The account's been active.

776
00:40:28,240 --> 00:40:31,370
That user could still use the whole
system, they just never got terminated.

777
00:40:31,370 --> 00:40:32,790
They never got removed from our system.

778
00:40:32,790 --> 00:40:34,540
Their access was never revoked.

779
00:40:35,690 --> 00:40:37,710
We always need to be on the watch for
that.

780
00:40:37,710 --> 00:40:39,070
There's of things that could cause it.

781
00:40:39,070 --> 00:40:43,110
This could be an employee who is
terminated, employee could die.

782
00:40:43,110 --> 00:40:46,940
Don't need access if they're dead,
I assume.

783
00:40:46,940 --> 00:40:50,280
Who knows what people do in their
spare time when they're dead?

784
00:40:50,280 --> 00:40:53,000
So those are some kind of
drastic scenarios there.

785
00:40:53,000 --> 00:40:54,780
The employee was completely removed.

786
00:40:54,780 --> 00:40:55,940
It might not be so

787
00:40:55,940 --> 00:41:00,590
much that they're removed,
as just their job role has changed.

788
00:41:00,590 --> 00:41:04,680
Maybe they got certain access because
they were attached to a project and

789
00:41:04,680 --> 00:41:07,270
the project is over and
now that the project is over,

790
00:41:07,270 --> 00:41:08,830
they don't need that
level of access anymore.

791
00:41:08,830 --> 00:41:11,790
They still need access, they still need
to be able to get into the system for

792
00:41:11,790 --> 00:41:14,520
their normal operations activities but

793
00:41:14,520 --> 00:41:18,850
the extra access they got as a part
of that project is no longer needed.

794
00:41:18,850 --> 00:41:22,360
So we need to go back in,
remove the extra access.

795
00:41:22,360 --> 00:41:26,180
So in that scenario, we're actually just
reducing their access, not eliminating,

796
00:41:26,180 --> 00:41:29,220
just reducing,
as opposed to granting access.

797
00:41:29,220 --> 00:41:31,130
So it does kind of go both ways.

798
00:41:31,130 --> 00:41:37,060
So demotion, transfer,
termination, any number

799
00:41:37,060 --> 00:41:41,100
of scenarios are things that might cause
somebody's level of access to change.

800
00:41:42,350 --> 00:41:43,990
>> We can also take a look at logging and

801
00:41:43,990 --> 00:41:48,170
tracking the access that our users
are also needing to the service.

802
00:41:48,170 --> 00:41:50,540
We might do this, not only for
historical purposes,

803
00:41:50,540 --> 00:41:54,235
but this way, we actually can be
able to provide better for them.

804
00:41:54,235 --> 00:41:58,930
If we have too many users at one time, it
might give us a hint that we might need to

805
00:41:58,930 --> 00:42:02,535
add in additional servers or we might
need to change our service to provide for

806
00:42:02,535 --> 00:42:05,300
a better experience for the user.

807
00:42:06,490 --> 00:42:10,730
>> Outside of ITIL this is commonly
known as auditing or accounting.

808
00:42:10,730 --> 00:42:14,000
It's really the same thing and
here, we just call it logging and

809
00:42:14,000 --> 00:42:16,270
tracking, it's the same idea.

810
00:42:16,270 --> 00:42:19,970
All four could really be
interchanged as terms.

811
00:42:19,970 --> 00:42:21,705
On the exam, you see logging and tracking.

812
00:42:21,705 --> 00:42:26,840
We need a log, to keep a record of
when people access the system, and

813
00:42:26,840 --> 00:42:30,550
when they access the system,
we need to understand what they're doing.

814
00:42:30,550 --> 00:42:33,180
>> They might be accessing
multiple servers as part of their

815
00:42:33,180 --> 00:42:35,200
ongoing activities just as
they work in your system.

816
00:42:36,290 --> 00:42:37,560
We need to be able to track that and

817
00:42:37,560 --> 00:42:41,960
keep a record of it, that way we
can detect any unauthorized access.

818
00:42:41,960 --> 00:42:45,470
When we see someone accessing
the system with old credentials or

819
00:42:45,470 --> 00:42:48,610
credentials that shouldn't even be active
anymore, or an account that's unknown,

820
00:42:48,610 --> 00:42:49,750
that kind of thing.

821
00:42:49,750 --> 00:42:54,100
If an incident occurs, we want to be
able to go and check and see who was in

822
00:42:54,100 --> 00:42:58,030
the system when that incident occurred,
especially when it comes to security.

823
00:42:58,030 --> 00:43:01,400
So this does normally fall under
the realm of IT security and

824
00:43:01,400 --> 00:43:05,670
in their world, it's usually
called auditing and accounting.

825
00:43:05,670 --> 00:43:08,140
Those are the different kinda names there,

826
00:43:08,140 --> 00:43:10,340
which basically corresponds
with logging and tracking.

827
00:43:11,580 --> 00:43:15,500
>> Lastly, we can take a look at removing
or restricting access to a user.

828
00:43:15,500 --> 00:43:16,730
We wanna make sure that we do this,

829
00:43:16,730 --> 00:43:21,250
especially because users identities do
change in our system, whether it's due to

830
00:43:21,250 --> 00:43:25,830
a promotion or a transfer, or the very
fact that they've just been terminated.

831
00:43:25,830 --> 00:43:29,840
We don't want to give access to people
that don't really need it anymore.

832
00:43:29,840 --> 00:43:32,050
We wanna be able to have
the control that we need so

833
00:43:32,050 --> 00:43:34,960
that we can provide the best
possible service that we can.

834
00:43:36,500 --> 00:43:38,390
>> That's basically what it boils down to,

835
00:43:38,390 --> 00:43:40,970
access management should
never be a guessing game.

836
00:43:40,970 --> 00:43:46,150
Access management is all about having a
policy in place, a set of procedures that

837
00:43:46,150 --> 00:43:51,770
say, here's how people request access,
here's how we grant them the access.

838
00:43:51,770 --> 00:43:55,670
Here's how we monitor them to ensure they
still need it and then here's how we

839
00:43:55,670 --> 00:43:59,970
remove the access when they no longer need
it and it's black and white, plain as day.

840
00:43:59,970 --> 00:44:04,720
We define that policy and then we turn it
over to whoever the rights' manager is,

841
00:44:04,720 --> 00:44:08,180
whoever it is that's in charge
of granting that access and

842
00:44:08,180 --> 00:44:10,940
that might be your service desk,
it might not.

843
00:44:10,940 --> 00:44:13,960
In a high security environment,
the service desk might

844
00:44:13,960 --> 00:44:17,650
not have the authority to do that,
so it might have to get escalated.

845
00:44:17,650 --> 00:44:20,150
It's up to you to define that for
your organization.

846
00:44:20,150 --> 00:44:21,380
For most organizations though,

847
00:44:21,380 --> 00:44:26,060
they'll let the service desk handle that
because those are easy, low risk tickets.

848
00:44:26,060 --> 00:44:28,650
A new employee is hired,
we need to grant them some access.

849
00:44:28,650 --> 00:44:30,300
It's pretty common.

850
00:44:30,300 --> 00:44:35,010
Now, we might not let them set
permissions on a file or on a server but

851
00:44:35,010 --> 00:44:37,120
we might let them manage
group memberships.

852
00:44:37,120 --> 00:44:39,650
So I might have a group
called accountants, and

853
00:44:39,650 --> 00:44:42,600
the service desk is allowed to put
people in the accountants group, or

854
00:44:42,600 --> 00:44:44,750
take people out of the accountants group.

855
00:44:44,750 --> 00:44:48,210
Then, on the admin side,
we've added permissions to that group.

856
00:44:48,210 --> 00:44:51,490
So the service desk is not able to
modify the permissions themselves,

857
00:44:51,490 --> 00:44:54,720
they're just allowed to modify
who's in this one particular group.

858
00:44:54,720 --> 00:44:57,940
They can stick people in, take them out,
to grant and remove the permissions and

859
00:44:57,940 --> 00:45:01,350
that's normally how we see that
implemented in production.

860
00:45:01,350 --> 00:45:04,190
What worked for you might be different,
everybody can have their own solution.

861
00:45:04,190 --> 00:45:06,280
That's just a common scenario right there.

862
00:45:07,990 --> 00:45:12,490
With that we've wrapped up the last
process inside of service operation.

863
00:45:12,490 --> 00:45:16,740
So let's recap all the different things
we talked about in the last two episodes.

864
00:45:16,740 --> 00:45:19,160
We started out with the event management.

865
00:45:20,260 --> 00:45:21,940
That's just tracking of events,

866
00:45:21,940 --> 00:45:27,190
whenever our system differs from the
baseline of the normal service operation.

867
00:45:27,190 --> 00:45:29,020
We did incident management.

868
00:45:29,020 --> 00:45:31,870
When things don't go in line
with the baseline, when

869
00:45:31,870 --> 00:45:36,160
something unexpected occurs, we jump into
incident management to try and resolve it.

870
00:45:37,720 --> 00:45:41,460
After that we had requests fulfillment and
request fulfillment and

871
00:45:41,460 --> 00:45:43,100
incident management
start out the same way.

872
00:45:43,100 --> 00:45:47,730
They both start with a call to the service
desk and then from there they deviate.

873
00:45:47,730 --> 00:45:51,030
With incident management,
we have escalations and troubleshooting.

874
00:45:51,030 --> 00:45:54,870
With request fulfillment, we're just
performing a canned pre-authorized

875
00:45:54,870 --> 00:45:57,850
action like creating a user account and
we carry that through.

876
00:45:59,070 --> 00:46:01,360
If we went into incident management,
though, the follow up for

877
00:46:01,360 --> 00:46:03,990
that is our next one which
was problem management.

878
00:46:03,990 --> 00:46:09,210
We try and find the cause, the root
cause of that incident and correct it.

879
00:46:09,210 --> 00:46:10,990
Lastly, access management,

880
00:46:10,990 --> 00:46:13,150
which kind of just falls to
the side of all these other ones.

881
00:46:13,150 --> 00:46:14,740
The other ones are all
really closely related,

882
00:46:14,740 --> 00:46:20,060
and with access management we just control
people's ability to use the service.

883
00:46:20,060 --> 00:46:21,890
Those are our primary components.

884
00:46:22,920 --> 00:46:26,370
>> All these processes
really go into ensuring

885
00:46:26,370 --> 00:46:30,320
that we're providing the best thing
that we can for our customer.

886
00:46:30,320 --> 00:46:33,690
We're making sure that we're giving them
the day to day access that they need and

887
00:46:33,690 --> 00:46:36,570
that everything is meeting up to
those performance baselines or

888
00:46:36,570 --> 00:46:38,670
those baselines that we've set.

889
00:46:38,670 --> 00:46:42,170
Anything that deviates from that, this is
where we have a chance to correct that and

890
00:46:42,170 --> 00:46:43,520
that's what we wanna
make sure that we can do.

891
00:46:45,600 --> 00:46:49,080
Ladies and gentlemen, with that,
we've wrapped up service organization.

892
00:46:49,080 --> 00:46:53,150
So we're ready to progress on
to the very last service area,

893
00:46:53,150 --> 00:46:55,020
which is continual service improvement.

894
00:46:55,020 --> 00:46:58,460
I know we referred to it multiple
times throughout the last two episodes

895
00:46:58,460 --> 00:47:00,300
>> So it's that logical next step.

896
00:47:00,300 --> 00:47:04,730
So we hope to see you on that video but in
the meantime, let me just remind you guys,

897
00:47:04,730 --> 00:47:08,580
if you have questions on any of this,
please let us know.

898
00:47:08,580 --> 00:47:10,690
Live during the show you
can got itpro.tv/live and

899
00:47:10,690 --> 00:47:13,700
you'll see the chat box beneath the video.

900
00:47:13,700 --> 00:47:14,790
Post your questions there.

901
00:47:14,790 --> 00:47:16,970
We monitor and answer during the show.

902
00:47:16,970 --> 00:47:20,370
If you have questions after the show,
use our Q&A form.

903
00:47:20,370 --> 00:47:23,470
At the top of every page you'll
see a link that says Q&A.

904
00:47:23,470 --> 00:47:26,305
You can jump right in there and
post your questions.

905
00:47:26,305 --> 00:47:28,365
We monitor and answer after the show.

906
00:47:29,795 --> 00:47:32,495
I hope you guys enjoyed today's video or
show, or segment, or

907
00:47:32,495 --> 00:47:33,565
whatever we're calling these things today.

908
00:47:33,565 --> 00:47:35,240
I don't know why I've started
saying video all of a sudden.

909
00:47:35,240 --> 00:47:36,905
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'll file that away with

910
00:47:36,905 --> 00:47:40,595
service integration,
my new made up word for the day but

911
00:47:40,595 --> 00:47:43,265
hope you guys enjoyed it,
really hope to see you next time.

912
00:47:43,265 --> 00:47:45,875
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

913
00:47:45,875 --> 00:47:46,825
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

914
00:47:46,825 --> 00:47:48,605
>> And we'll see you next time.

915
00:47:48,605 --> 00:47:58,605
[MUSIC]

3

4
00:00:33,920 --> 00:00:37,008
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening, and

5
00:00:37,008 --> 00:00:39,081
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:39,081 --> 00:00:40,520
I'm your host Don Pezet.

7
00:00:40,520 --> 00:00:42,100
Back again with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:42,100 --> 00:00:43,210
How's it going Ronnie?

9
00:00:43,210 --> 00:00:44,045
>> It is cold.

10
00:00:44,045 --> 00:00:47,280
[LAUGH] It is plain cold in Florida.

11
00:00:47,280 --> 00:00:48,545
It's not supposed to be this cold.

12
00:00:48,545 --> 00:00:49,420
It is cold.

13
00:00:49,420 --> 00:00:50,076
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

14
00:00:50,076 --> 00:00:52,070
this is one of those nice chilly days for
us.

15
00:00:52,070 --> 00:00:53,961
Probably be our coldest one on record for
the year.

16
00:00:53,961 --> 00:00:55,540
>> So far.

17
00:00:55,540 --> 00:00:57,270
>> But that's not gonna stop us-
>> That's right.

18
00:00:57,270 --> 00:00:59,960
>> From jumping right back
into ITIL Foundations.

19
00:00:59,960 --> 00:01:04,320
In fact, this will more than likely be our
final episode for ITIL Foundations because

20
00:01:04,320 --> 00:01:08,750
the only area we haven't hit is
the continual service improvement.

21
00:01:08,750 --> 00:01:11,910
And that's what we're gonna be
tackling in this episode right here.

22
00:01:11,910 --> 00:01:16,030
All of the other service areas that
we talked about, service strategies,

23
00:01:16,030 --> 00:01:17,115
service design.

24
00:01:17,115 --> 00:01:22,660
We did service transition and then service
operation, the four main areas there.

25
00:01:22,660 --> 00:01:26,350
That's stuff that companies do all
the time, getting the service created,

26
00:01:26,350 --> 00:01:28,110
getting it into production.

27
00:01:28,110 --> 00:01:31,710
And then using it, actually making
it available to the customer.

28
00:01:31,710 --> 00:01:35,070
But once that's all done, what do we do?

29
00:01:35,070 --> 00:01:36,430
We don't just sit back.

30
00:01:36,430 --> 00:01:39,500
We look at what we've got and
we see how we can make it better.

31
00:01:39,500 --> 00:01:44,440
And that's how we really get into
this area which is continual service

32
00:01:44,440 --> 00:01:47,480
improvement, and
that key word there is continual.

33
00:01:47,480 --> 00:01:50,740
This is not something that you just
do once and you call it a day.

34
00:01:50,740 --> 00:01:53,600
You continually look for
ways to make that service better and,

35
00:01:53,600 --> 00:01:57,240
by making it better I mean increasing
the value to the customer.

36
00:01:58,600 --> 00:02:02,780
>> Remember that we might think
we provide the perfect service.

37
00:02:02,780 --> 00:02:07,510
But because the very fact that business
changes, our needs change, the customers'

38
00:02:07,510 --> 00:02:11,515
needs changes, we always have to be
in that cycle of reviewing our work,

39
00:02:11,515 --> 00:02:14,640
making sure it's actually
the best possible.

40
00:02:14,640 --> 00:02:18,686
And so ITIL includes that in as part of
the foundation that we all have to do when

41
00:02:18,686 --> 00:02:20,194
we are providing a service.

42
00:02:20,194 --> 00:02:24,233
Is that we can't just sit back and expect
that everything's gonna go 100% right.

43
00:02:24,233 --> 00:02:28,545
Nor can we expect that what we did today
is actually even good even for tomorrow.

44
00:02:28,545 --> 00:02:33,220
>> Yeah, so when we talk about continual
service improvement we're not typically

45
00:02:33,220 --> 00:02:35,430
just talking about a single service.

46
00:02:35,430 --> 00:02:40,490
We're talking about just our operations as
a whole, all the services that we offer.

47
00:02:40,490 --> 00:02:44,460
So when I say that we're gonna be
improving value to our customer,

48
00:02:44,460 --> 00:02:49,140
we're improving the value by maintaining
the proper service portfolio.

49
00:02:49,140 --> 00:02:53,710
So as we do improvements, yes,
we might be improving a single service.

50
00:02:53,710 --> 00:02:57,200
It might be something that we're making
better, more efficient, less expensive,

51
00:02:57,200 --> 00:02:59,240
whatever it is that we
do to make that better.

52
00:02:59,240 --> 00:03:03,620
But it might also be adding additional
services, services that shore up some kind

53
00:03:03,620 --> 00:03:07,300
of gap that we had, that maybe we
have identified some kind of missing

54
00:03:07,300 --> 00:03:10,360
component that's stopping us from
meeting our strategy, our goals.

55
00:03:10,360 --> 00:03:14,770
So there's all sorts of different types
of improvements that are out there,

56
00:03:14,770 --> 00:03:18,230
and the people at ITIL that
have drafted all of this,

57
00:03:18,230 --> 00:03:20,200
they can't predict every possible outcome.

58
00:03:20,200 --> 00:03:23,250
And they don't even know what type
of business you're operating in.

59
00:03:23,250 --> 00:03:25,890
So what we're looking at
here is just a framework.

60
00:03:25,890 --> 00:03:28,270
A framework of what we
can do to go through and

61
00:03:28,270 --> 00:03:33,330
address our services and find unique
ways that match our individual business.

62
00:03:33,330 --> 00:03:37,220
To make them better, make them more
efficient and keep that path going on.

63
00:03:37,220 --> 00:03:43,420
So that's what CSI is and that's kind of
where we're gonna be jumping into this.

64
00:03:43,420 --> 00:03:48,260
CSI, one fallacy that I kinda wanted to
deal with right here in the beginning.

65
00:03:48,260 --> 00:03:49,650
A lot of people think we go ahead and

66
00:03:49,650 --> 00:03:54,050
deploy the service, and
then we start applying CSI afterwards.

67
00:03:54,050 --> 00:03:58,770
But continual service improvement actually
starts way back in the very beginning,

68
00:03:58,770 --> 00:04:01,000
even before the service is in production.

69
00:04:01,000 --> 00:04:01,740
And you might say,

70
00:04:01,740 --> 00:04:05,590
well how am I suppose to make a service
better if it's not even there?

71
00:04:05,590 --> 00:04:07,250
Well, simply reviewing.

72
00:04:07,250 --> 00:04:10,760
Reviewing the plans, reviewing
the strategies that have come up with,

73
00:04:10,760 --> 00:04:14,080
reviewing the design,
the service design package, that SDP.

74
00:04:14,080 --> 00:04:16,220
Reviewing that and
looking for weaknesses and

75
00:04:16,220 --> 00:04:18,880
areas to improve,
that's all a part of CSI.

76
00:04:18,880 --> 00:04:20,280
Now we don't normally call it that,

77
00:04:20,280 --> 00:04:23,010
we don't say oh yeah, I'm doing
continual service improvement right now.

78
00:04:23,010 --> 00:04:26,240
We just say, oh, we're doing
another peer review of this design.

79
00:04:26,240 --> 00:04:27,711
We're having another
brainstorming session.

80
00:04:27,711 --> 00:04:30,122
That is continual service improvement.

81
00:04:30,122 --> 00:04:34,500
So it really happens throughout
the entire life cycle of a service,

82
00:04:34,500 --> 00:04:37,000
not just after it's reached production.

83
00:04:37,000 --> 00:04:37,560
>> Yeah.

84
00:04:37,560 --> 00:04:40,570
We do this intuitively,
if we've done a project before and

85
00:04:40,570 --> 00:04:42,650
we've realized,
we've made mistakes in the past.

86
00:04:42,650 --> 00:04:47,920
As we begin the new project, we go back
and say, what can I do better this time?

87
00:04:47,920 --> 00:04:51,920
As we continue to do that it ingrains
in us, it becomes more a part of us.

88
00:04:51,920 --> 00:04:54,387
